DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Man Executed for Killing Sheriff's Deputy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with execution carried out; put number of previous executions in past tense; ADD byline. DELETES final graf pvs, outdated material. Pick up 8th graf pvs, `In a...
DOC.TEXT: Wilbert Lee Evans, who said he deserved another chance for helping prison workers during a death-row escape, was executed Wednesday night in Virginia's electric chair for the 1981 murder of a sheriff's deputy. Evans, 44, was put to death 3{ hours after the U.S. Supreme Court denied a stay of execution. Gov. L. Douglas Wilder also refused a request for clemency as Evans awaited his execution at the State Penitentiary. Evans was led into the death chamber in the prison's basement, strapped into the electric chair and administered two 55-second surges of 2,500 volts each, said Wayne Farrar, spokesman for the state Department of Corrections. He was pronounced dead at 11:09 p.m. Bart Stapert, assistant director of the Virginia Coalition of Jails and Prisons, said he met with Evans and the inmate told him: ``I want to say to the family of Mr. Truesdale I'm dead. You don't have to hate me any more.'' Evans was sentenced to die for shooting Alexandria Deputy Sheriff William Truesdale on Jan. 27, 1981. Truesdale was returning Evans to the Alexandria jail after a hearing when Evans grabbed the deputy's gun and shot him. The Supreme Court issued its ruling at 7:30 p.m. Justice Thurgood Marshall, who opposes capital punishment in all cases, was the lone dissenter in the 8-1 vote. Evans' attorneys based final efforts to save him on his actions during the May 1984 breakout of six death row inmates at the Mecklenburg Correctional Center. The lawyers contended that Evans, who did not join the escapees, intervened to save prison guards and nurses from harm. In his dissent, Marshall said: ``A system of capital punishment that would permit Wilbert Evans' execution, notwithstanding as-to-now unrefuted evidence showing that death is an improper sentence, is a system that cannot stand.'' It was the 141st execution in the United States since the Supreme Court reinstated the death penalty in 1976, and the 10th in Virginia. In a letter hand-delivered to the governor's office Wednesday afternoon, Evans' attorneys presented evidence from an internal State Police and Corrections Department report on the escape. ``Only you, Governor, can prevent the commonwealth from foisting upon Wilbert Evans tonight an unconstitutionally cruel and unusual punishment,'' said the letter signed by attorney Arthur F. Mathews. The letter included excerpts of statements from prison guards and nurses that Evans protected them during the escape. One nurse said Evans stopped inmates Earl Clanton and Linwood Briley from molesting her. Of the escapees, Clanton, Briley and his brother, James Briley, have been executed. The other three remain on death row. Evans said Wednesday in a telephone interview from the penitentiary that he was keeping busy ``doing legal work,'' writing his will and conferring by telephone with his attorneys. ``You've got to keep your hope up,'' he said. Evans described his feelings as a mixture of hope and caution, clamminess and nervousness. Last Saturday, U.S. District Judge Robert R. Merhige Jr. granted Evans a stay. Merhige concluded the trial jury's finding of future dangerousness as a reason for imposing the death sentence was thrown into question by Evans' actions during the Mecklenburg incident. A three-judge panel of the 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals overturned the stay Tuesday. The appeals panel accepted the state's argument that Evans was seeking clemency, a matter for the governor, not a question for the courts.

DOC.HEAD: Financial Adviser Resigns; Says Financial Crisis Looms
DOC.TEXT: The investment banker who helped rescue New York City from the brink of bankruptcy in the 1970s said Wednesday that the city faces a worse financial crisis now. Felix Rohatyn, 62, said he would step down as chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corp. by the end of the year to spend more time with his wife, Elizabeth, who is recovering from recent surgery. The assistance corporation was created in June 1975 to assist the city financially by using sales tax revenues to back bonds issued by the city. New York was near bankruptcy at the time and Rohatyn was one of the architects of its recovery. Rohatyn, also a member of the city's Council of Economic Advisers, criticized union leaders demanding ``unrealistic'' pay hikes from the city. Rohatyn suggested that pension money now earmarked for a teachers' pay raise instead go into city coffers. Rohatyn, who has no direct say in the contract negotiations, said the state's fiscal problems and ``a much more serious'' city budget crisis prompted him to speak out at the oversight group's meeting Wednesday. The problems are financial, economic and social and are of proportions that ``I haven't seen in 40 years,'' said Rohatyn. On Oct. 1, the city gave the United Federation of Teachers a 5.5 percent pay increase in a one-year contract. The increase was predicated on rearranging the city's pension contribution to the teachers retirement fund and making a more optimistic forecast of the dividends earned. Rohatyn said that if the rearranged city contribution results in extra money, it should go to help New York. ``Credible fiscal balance is necessary for full and free access to the credit markets. Social balance dictates the fewest number of layoffs possible,'' he said in a letter to City Council Speaker Peter Vallone and the Financial Control Board. ``Both objectives will be served by dedicating whatever pension savings are deemed prudent to ... the framework of an overall comprehensive city financial plan.'' UFT President Sandra Feldman said Rohatyn ``is really meddling with things that are not really his affair.'' Mayor David Dinkins said later Wednesday that if the state Legislature fails to pprove changes in pension earnings assumptions to finance half of the raise, the city would not be liable for the difference. Rohatyn said similar demands from other unions are ``pushing the city closer and closer to a real crisis.'' However, Barry Feinstein, president of Teamsters Local 237, which represents 12,000 city workers, said pension assumptions were raised four times during Mayor Ed Koch's administration, the last time to balance the budget. Dinkins succeeded Koch in January. Among the problems cited by Rohatyn are a $1.8 billion budget gap already plugged for fiscal 1991 and a predicted shortfall of at least $2 billion through fiscal 1992. Standard & Poors Corp. last week placed the city on its ``credit watch'' list, meaning the bond rating agency is reviewing the city's ability to pay interest and principal on $13 billion in general obligation bonds. It did not change its bond rating for the city. There are potential layoffs of city workers and city agencies are preparing to cut $1 billion over the next 21 months. Officials predict a statewide budget deficit of up to $3 billion in the fiscal year starting April 1, 1991.

DOC.HEAD: Fifth Member of Cambodian Dance Troupe Elects to Stay In US
DOC.TEXT: The star of a Cambodian dance troupe decided to remain in the United States Wednesday when the rest of the company went home, her lawyer said. Yim Devi was the fifth dancer in the 32-member Cambodian Classical Dance Company to defect during its national tour, the first U.S.-Cambodian artistic exchange since 1971. Devi's attorney, Martin Garbus, refused to describe Devi's act as a defection, saying her passport is valid until December. ``She's going to explore her options,'' he said. ``She might stay two days, she might stay a week. Who knows? She may want to pursue her studies here.'' Devi was among several troupe members who reported receiving death threats during their tour. Tour organizers alleged that a network of Cambodian-Americans was pressing the dancers to defect.

DOC.HEAD: Top Banking Regulator Accepts Contributions From Failed S&L Executives
DOC.TEXT: Florida's top banking regulator accepted campaign contributions from directors of 40 percent of the financial institutions that have failed in the state since 1985, a newspaper reported Wednesday. Since 1985, 39 financial institutions supervised by Comptroller Gerald Lewis, the only elected state banking regulator in the country, have failed. The directors of 16 contributed to Lewis' re-election campaigns beginning in 1982, The Miami Herald reported. From 1982 through this year, Lewis received more than $25,000 from those directors, it said. In at least five cases, Lewis received contributions from businessmen who later received permission to open state-chartered institutions, the newspaper said. Among his backers were the directors of two of the states largest S&Ls, CenTrust in Miami and First American Bank and Trust in North Palm Beach, both of which failed this year. Republican Chris Comstock, who is vying for Lewis' post, said the Democratic incumbent ``has compromised himself by taking of huge amounts of money from the people he regulates.'' Lewis, the state's chief financial officer since 1974, said he could not recall specific details of campaign contributions made eight years ago. He said no contribution ever influenced his decisions. His office could not prevent the bank failures, Lewis said. ``If we closed down those institutions, it shows we did act,'' Lewis said. ``The fact is that we have taken aggressive actions against institutions that failed.'' The S&L crisis is expected to cost taxpayers billions of dollars nationwide. Florida has one of the highest S&L failure rates in the country. In September 1982, Fort Lauderdale businessman Scott Gettemy gave $3,000 to Lewis' campaign, the maximum allowed by state law. In 1984, the Intercapital Savings Bank was incorporated with Gettemy as a director, according to state records. It failed two years later. Miami businessmen Said Haddad, Juan Martinez, Raul Sanchez, M.A. Schofman and Cayetano Midolo gave thousands of dollars for Lewis' 1982 re-election. Less than two years later, they opened the Trust Bank, which failed in 1988. The newspaper cited three other similar cases. Comstock, a financial adviser in St. Petersburg who worked as a bank examiner for the New York State Department of Banking before moving to Florida in 1982, said the donations created conflicts of interest. ``It tends to prevent him from acting promptly when the situation warrants,'' Comstock said. ``I don't think he's done a good job regulating banks.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Lifts Gag Order on Gag Order After Newspaper Ignores It
DOC.TEXT: A judge who imposed a gag order on coverage of a murder trial, then ordered reporters not to report the gag order, has changed his mind. The Daily Press of Newport News, ignoring a prohibition by Circuit Judge Morris B. Gutterman, reported both his gag order and the order against reporting that he imposed it. The newspaper also appealed the order, joined by the Richmond Times-Dispatch, The Richmond News Leader and The Virginian-Pilot and The Ledger-Star of Norfolk. Gutterman lifted his orders after the newspapers' attorneys met with him in his chambers Tuesday. ``The action seems beyond belief to me,'' said Rod Smolla, a law professor at the College of William and Mary's Marshall-Wythe School of Law and director of the Institute of the Bill of Rights Law. ``It seems to me ... that it is unconstitutional for a judge to issue a gag order on the press in a criminal trial. Then to issue a second gag order to keep the first secret only compounds the problem,'' he said. Smolla said he'd never heard of a judge issued a gag order over his own gag order. Gutterman declined to comment on the case. David C. Kohler, an attorney representing Richmond Newspapers Inc., said Gutterman was concerned about what the jury in the murder trial of Herbert G. Fisher might see in the newspapers. Fisher is accused of killing his wife. When the trial opened Monday and the jury was out of the courtroom, Gutterman ordered reporters not to make public any courtroom activity that the jury did not see. Juries often are taken from the courtroom while attorneys argue points of law, such as what evidence the jury should hear. Gutterman also ordered reporters not to publish any account of his order. ``We thought it was clearly unconstitutional prior restraint,'' said Jack Davis, editor of the Daily Press. ``And we didn't think we needed to abide by it.'' Kohler said the U.S. Supreme Court has set out strict rules concerning gag orders. In a 1973 ruling on a Nebraska murder trial, the high court set out three criteria before judges can restrict coverage of criminal trials: a compelling reason for such an order, no alternative and effectiveness.

DOC.HEAD: Talking Pantyhose and Home Ports with Congress' Youngest Member
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX11 of Oct. 15
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Susan Molinari would like to become so-ooo powerful that she could change women's fashion. No more high heels or pantyhose. Ever. ``When people make jokes about God being a woman, I say, `I don't think so, because then we wouldn't have the babies or stockings,''' she said. ``That was something a man did.'' She rolls down the top of one black suede boot to prove she's a fashion rebel. ``I wear boots all the time so I can wear knee socks.'' Molinari has a way to go before Fashion Avenue takes its cue from her. But the New York Republican is becoming better-known around Capitol Hill, where she's been since winning a special election in March. Last month, just six months into her term, Molinari won her first big fight in Congress, defeating an amendment proposed by 21-term Rep. Charles Bennett, D-Fla. Bennett, a powerful member of the House Armed Services Committee, proposed closing the Navy home port on Staten Island, N.Y. - the heart of Molinari's district. The home port, which is about 90 percent complete, is opposed by New York Mayor David Dinkins and every member of the New York City congressional delegation except Molinari and Rep. Tom Manton, a Queens Democrat. Closing the home port would be cheaper than opening it, Bennett argued. But Molinari, who at 32 is the youngest member of Congress, stood boldly on the House floor and hit her fellow congressmen where they live. ``Your base could be next,'' she warned ominously. The House voted 230 to 188 in favor of Molinari's substitute amendment to save the base. She was ecstatic. That evening, Guy Molinari offered a champagne toast to his daughter's big feet, an admission that they were finally large enough to fill his shoes. Susan Molinari, an only child, succeeded her father to Congress. She is only the second daughter in history to do so. (Winnifred Mason Huck, R-Ill., followed her father, William Mason Huck, R-Ill., when he died in 1921.) After five terms in Congress, Guy Molinari retired last year to run, successfully, for Staten Island borough president. To try for the House, Susan Molinari gave up a seat on the New York City Council that she had won in 1985. As the lone Republican in the 35-member body, she was minority leader from Day One and received such perks as a city car, extra staff and an office in City Hall. But, she said during a recent interview, ``There was a certain level of frustration in being a member of the New York City Council.'' For example, she could never become chairwoman of a committee, and getting bills passed could be tough. Plus, she said, ``some of the most important problems that are confronting my district are environmental problems, and those have to be handled on the federal level because of our proximity to New Jersey.'' Staten Island is downwind of New Jersey's huge petrochemical industry and Molinari believes that's why her constituents have such a high rate of respiratory ailments. So while she's now one of 435 and still in the minority to boot, Molinari feels it's a lot easier to get things done in Congress than she had anticipated. ``I expected the place to be more arcane in terms of participation in committees and ability to get legislation passed, to speak on the floor,'' she said. ``In fact, I find it's a pretty open institution. I find it less political than I ever expected it to be.'' Of course, Molinari came to Washington with many advantages her fellow freshmen lack. ``I have always received a lot of benefits both politically and personally having Guy Molinari as my father,'' she admitted. ``However, having a record of 6{ years in the City Council, people did have something to judge.'' The fact that her father was New York state chairman of George Bush's election committee in 1988 didn't hurt, either. Bush appeared at a fund-raiser for Susan Molinari in February, partly to repay the debt to her father. The event pulled in about $150,000. Susan Molinari said she hopes to continue some of the work her father started in Congress - and especially to see the home port open and running. But she said she disagrees with her father on some key issues, particularly those that define differences in gender and generation. For one thing, she's pro-choice while he's anti-abortion. ``That's something that pre-dates my political involvement,'' she said, admitting that the two of them don't even discuss the issue anymore. She said she also places a higher priority on the issues of day care and parental leave. Molinari said she's fitting pretty well into the Washington life, renting an apartment in nearby Alexandria, Va., and going home on weekends to campaign. Having just won her congressional seat, Molinari is up for re-election in November along with all other House members. But she said it's hard being apart from her husband, John Lucchesi, who runs a car service, and the rest of her family on Staten Island. ``There's a certain loneliness that comes with being removed from them but when you get to go home - and not to sound, like gooey - but the night that you sleep in bed with your husband means more because you haven't done it in five days.''

DOC.HEAD: Pope Approved Two Married Priests, Cardinal Says
By STEPHEN R. WILSON
DOC.TEXT: A Brazilian cardinal has disclosed that two married men in his country became priests with the approval of the pope, and says the church should seriously consider the ordination of more married men. Cardinal Aloisio Lorscheider said papal approval of the two ordinations came on condition the two men live with their wives as ``brother and sister,'' meaning they must abstain from sex. The disclosure by Lorscheider, which appeared in the Italian magazine Famiglia Cristiana (Christian Family) in the third week of a monthlong gathering of bishops, appeared to be an attempt to keep the question of married priests alive. Pope John Paul II has resolutely opposed waiving the celibacy rule for priests, and conservative bishops kept the subject off the agenda of the bishops' synod, which among other issues is dealing with the diminishing number of candidates for the priesthood worldwide. Lorscheider, one of more than 200 bishops attending the synod, said allowing ordination of married men could help alleviate the shortage of priests in some areas. ``There are Christian communities, not only in the Third World, which desire the Eucharist and can't receive it,'' he said. ``We need to seriously study the issue.'' Roman Catholic church rules require priests to be celibate and forsake marriage. Protestant and some Eastern-rite Catholic churches allow married priests. The celibacy rule is based on the view that sex and marriage would distract the priest from giving his complete attention to the work of God. Lorscheider, archbishop of Fortaleza, Brazil, did not identify the priests. A Vatican spokesman, Monsignor Piero Pennacchini, identified one of them as Ivo Schmidt, who had been serving as permanent deacon of the diocese of Federico Westphalen, a city of 500,000 people in southern Brazil. The spokesman said he was still checking on the second married priest. Italian newspapers reported he apparently lives in the state of Pernambuco in northeastern Brazil. Both ordinations are said to have occurred at least four years ago. Pennacchini and other Vatican and church officials noted that exceptions to the celibacy rule have been made for priests from other denominations who convert to Roman Catholicism. Dozens of married Episcopalians have done so in the United States, for example. They are allowed to continue living normal married lives.

DOC.HEAD: Imported Animals Causing Problems in Australia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Australia and New Zealand are cursing the introduction of rabbits, foxes, opossums and other foreign animals, which breed virtually unchecked because their natural predators were not brought along. ``New Zealand could be said to be facing a creeping ecological disaster with the impact of introduced species on our environment,'' said Philip Woollaston, its conservation minister. ``We have a long and inglorious history of introducing new and alien elements into our environment. Homesick settlers brought familiar plants and animals to a country that looked foreign to them. ``It has taken a long time for us to shake off the settler mentality of wanting to create a Southern Hemisphere European country.'' Some alien species were assets. Sheep, cattle and various crops have become economic mainstays of both countries, but the lists of foreign pests are long. New Zealand's includes goats, chamois, opossums, wasps and deer. Predators or parasites sometimes have been brought in as controls, but they often created new problems. ``Foxes were once thought to be the answer to the rabbit menace,'' Woollaston said. ``Fortunately, they did not take hold in New Zealand as they have in Australia, where they have done terrible damage to indigenous fauna. ``Unfortunately, stoats and weasels, which also were introduced for rabbit control, have found New Zealand a very suitable habitat.'' The opossum, introduced from Australia in the 19th century for its fur, now is the main threat in New Zealand. The government has declared war on the animal, which outnumbers the 3.1 million New Zealanders about 23 to 1. Opossums devastate foilage in many forests and carry a form of tuberculosis that has infected other species, particularly cattle. There has been little resistance to poison pellets intended to kill opossums, even though other animals also die. Agriculture Minister Jim Sutton said New Zealand needs a major research project to find biological methods of wiping out the opossum through disease or sterility without harming other species. ``We have to do the research ourselves because this is a uniquely New Zealand problem,'' he said. Sutton said opossums could withstand a death rate of 5 million a year without a permanent reduction of their numbers. Margaret Evans, mayor of the North Island city of Hamilton, has suggested an opossum-hunting program to give jobs to the unemployed. Foxes and rabbits were brought to Australia by Europeans to be bred for hunting. They now are blamed for contributing to the extinction of 18 marsupial species and threatening 30. Victoria state alone has about 25 million rabbits. Officials estimate they cost the national wool and cattle industries $100 million a year, which does not include environmental damage. Steve Crabb, the state's environment minister suggests marketing fox pelts as an ``environmentally friendly'' alternative to other furs. While the rabbit destroys vegetation, the fox preys on birds, reptiles and farm animals. ``The fox did not co-evolve with our native wildlife, so these small animals have no defense mechanisms against it,'' said Clive Marks of the Keith Turnbull Research Institute. ``We've never had a predator like the fox. It's a very efficient killing machine.'' Australia has strict quarantine laws to keep out rabies and other animal diseases, and officials fear the fox as a carrier. ``Should we get rabies, our fox population would be the prime spreader of the disease,'' Marks said. Introduction of fleas carrying the rabbit-specific myxoma virus reduced the number of rabbits for a time until they developed immunities. As with the opossum in New Zealand, the best hope for controlling Australia's rabbits and foxes lies in research. Efforts are under way to genetically alter existing viruses so they will make the animals sterile. No one seems to know what to do about the Queensland cane toad. Australia's only toad and was introduced from South America in 1935 to control the cane beetle and has been an ecological disaster. Cane toads grow to 8 inches in length, eat virtually anything that moves and are prolific breeders. When cornered, they squirt a poison from neck glands that kills dogs, cats, even humans. Because of their bad experiences, Australia and New Zealand look closely at any proposals to introduce new species. New Zealand recently rejected plans to raise catfish on fish farms and thousands that had been in quarantine were destroyed. Sport fishermen feared catfish would escape and destroy the trout, another foreign creature that has flourished.

DOC.HEAD: Sandinistas Becoming Capitalists
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: The Sandinistas bullied private businesmen for a decade while in power and are taking them on again, this time as competitors. They don't show up at Chamber of Commerce luncheons yet, but many former Sandinista leaders who once espoused Marxism are now eyeing profit margins. A lot of this is going on, though exactly how much is not clear. Estimates of the number of Sandinista companies range from 20 or 30 to nearly 300, but there are no official records. The source of the money is also in doubt. President Violeta Chamorro's government found the treasury nearly empty when it took over in April. ``The companies are legal,'' said a government official who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``The question is where they got the means.'' Sandinista commercial interests now include stores, newspapers, radio stations, farms, real estate, export-import corporations and a television station. Some are owned outright by the Sandinista Front (FSLN) and others by members with the front as a minority stockholder. ``There is nothing wrong with a political party being in business within the framework of free enterprise,'' said Herti Lewites, the former Sandinista tourism minister, who is setting up some of the enterprises. ``If I can make every member of the FSLN rich, I will,'' he said. Lewites acknowledged that some Marxist activists find the sudden entrepreneurial impulses of their fellows perplexing. ``Some of our militants and people in the government cannot quite assimilate this yet,'' he said. One of the most visible Sandinista enterprises is Central American Airlines, or CAAL, which is to begin Miami-Managua flights beginning Oct. 27 using a rented Boeing 727 at the outset. The airlines will charge $275 roundtrip, the lowest fare between the two cities among carriers serving the region. The ticket is to include free cocktails. ``There is no reason why, within a year, we should not be flying to Europe also,'' said Lewites. The airline eventually plans flights to Los Angeles and San Francisco, Mexico City, Madrid, Spain, and London. Lewites has variously described the company's investors as Saudi Arabians, Greeks and Lebanese. In an interview last week he said the Sandinista Front had a 25 percent interest in the airline and his personal stake was 3 percent. But at Wednesday's news conference officially launching the airline, Lewites said there was no Sandinista ownership. ``I don't think even Herti's grandmother believes that,'' snickered a journalist from the Cuban government's Prensa Latina news agency. The Sandinistas led the long struggle that overthrew the late President Anastasio Somzoa in July 1979. Many of their leaders espoused Marxist ideology and had trained in communist countries. While in power, the Sandinistas frequently promised to support a mixed economy, with plenty of room for private investors. In practice the government seemed to make its economic policy as it went along. Nationalizations of companies and land often appeared arbitrary, or aimed at political enemies. The Sandinistas' economic policies and a U.S.-sponsored guerrilla war destroyed the economy. When the Sandinistas ran in free elections in February, te voters rejected them for a more conservative coalition led by Mrs. Chamorro. Most of the Sandinista companies are headed by former government officials, some of whom had left family businesses to join the Sandinista revolution. Opponents claim some of the companies were stolen or set up with government funds and equipment. Sandinista officials have said the party squirreled away money supplied over the years by sympathetic foreign governments and other sources. Some businesses require little or no investment. Fernando Guzman, a former Sandinista front official, has the party as a minority partner in several companies, including two import-export firms. ``The FSLN helped me get some of the contacts,'' he said. The Sandinistas established trading companies in the United States, Panama and elsewhere years ago to circumvent the U.S. embargo on trade with Nicaragua. Manuel Espinoza, who was former President Daniel Ortega's press officer, obtained a concession for a television station before the Sandinistas left power. As Lewites put it: ``The party must have resources. Things must change. We cannot live off politics alone. ``We are going to give the party a new image,'' he added. ``We are eliminating old taboos.''

DOC.HEAD: Thou Shalt Not Violate Government Ethics Rules
DOC.TEXT: It's not exactly Moses coming down from the mount with a set of tablets, but President Bush has an updated set of ``standards of ethical conduct'' for government officers and employees. For instance: Thou shalt not ``hold financial interests that conflict with the conscientious performance of duty.'' Thou shalt not ``solicit or accept any gift or other item of monetary value from any person or entity seeking official action from, doing business with, or conducting activities regulated by the employee's agency.'' Thou shalt not ``use public office for private gain.'' These rules are contained in an order Bush signed Wednesday ``to establish fair and exacting standards of ethical conduct for all executive branch employees.'' The order does not merely forbid. It seeks what every right-thinking citizen wishes for his country. Such as: -``Employees shall put forth honest effort in the performance of their duties.'' -``Employees shall disclose waste, fraud, abuse and corruption to appropriate authorities.'' The White House assures that these principles are not new for the Bush administration; that the president's executive order is ``minor fine-tuning'' of ethical standards put in place on April 12, 1989. On that day, Bush unveiled a fat package of proposals covering activities by executive branch employees as well as judges and Congress. It touched on campaign finance laws and acceptance of speech fees by congressmen. The new order covers executive branch employees and officers whose boss is George Bush. These are the same employees who stand to be furloughed in wholesale numbers if there is no budget agreement by Friday midnight. The order said some fundamental principles of ethical service are in place ``to ensure that every citizen can have complete confidence in the integrity of the federal government.'' It frowns on employees using federal property ``for other than authorized activities'' and forbids moonlighting jobs outside of government for most employees, ``including seeking or negotiating for employment.'' It says employees should obey the laws bearing on equal opportunity regardless of race, color, religion, sex, national origin, age or handicap. And it thinks employees, like Caesar's wife, must be above suspicion: ``Employees shall endeavor to avoid any actions creating the appearance that they are violating the law ....'' The rest is more governmentese than Bible. Who is responsible for administering the order? The Office of Government Ethics. What will that office do? It will do ``promulgating ... developing, disseminating and periodically updating.'' And, of course, ``ensuring.'' One of the minor changes the document makes from the 1989 order is allowing lower-paid, full-time, non-career government employees to engage in moonlighting. All the while, of course, adhering to standards of conduct expected of a government employee.

DOC.HEAD: Los Angeles City Council Votes Down Restaurant Smoking Ban
DOC.TEXT: The City Council has snuffed out a proposed smoking ban in restaurants, deciding instead to consider having partitions and ventilation systems clear the air for non-smoking diners. The council deadlocked 6-6 on the outright ban Tuesday before voting 8-4 to draft the compromise ordinance for restaurants serving more than 50 patrons. Los Angeles already prohibits smoking in supermarkets, elevators and at public meetings and requires non-smoking areas in all large restaurants. Smaller cities, including San Luis Obispo, Sacramento and Aspen, Colo., have passed restaurant smoking bans, but Los Angeles, with its nearly 4 million residents, would have become the first major city to do so. ``Why shouldn't Los Angeles be a leader here?'' asked Councilman Marvin Braude, who proposed the unsuccessful measure. ``This ban is inevitable. Let's move forward and do it today.'' Restaurant lobbyists hailed defeat of the measure but attacked the compromise proposal that requires partitions and vents as a similar threat to the economic survival of many establishments. ``It's not a great compromise if we're going to put restaurants out of business,'' said Rudy Cole, executive director of a coalition known as RSVP, Restaurants for a Sensible Voluntary Policy (On Smoking). The group claims to represent 1,000 of thses to adopt quotas in hiring and promotion,'' Bush said Tuesday. He said that if the measure reached his desk, he would ``be compelled to veto it.'' The Senate on Tuesday night approved the measure, 62-34, short of the two-thirds support that sponsors would need to override the threatened veto. Fifty-three Democrats and nine Republicans joined in supporting the measure, while 34 Republicans were opposed. Civil rights forces said they could count on the votes of three absent senators and thus needed only two more to reach the 67 required for an override. But the roll call revealed that despite many concessions they had gained no new support since July 18 when an earlier version cleared, 65-34. The House was due to vote today on the bill, which would effectively overturn six Supreme Court decisions handed down last year. It has been the civil rights movement's top priority on Capitol Hill in recent months. Provisions range from a ban on racial harassment in the workplace to punitive damages in extreme discrimination cases. The major controversy, though, is over proposed changes in complex court rules governing job discrimination lawsuits. The changes would make it easier for those filing suit to win and harder for employers to defend themselves. The administration and business critics of the bill say employers would adopt quotas as a ready-made defense in case they were taken to court. Sponsors of the bill scoff at this notion. Civil rights leaders who visited with Bush in May in an effort to reach a compromise pla to ask for another chance to make the pitch for the bill and head off a veto. ``This is going to be a defining issue for the Bush administration and civil rights,'' said Ralph Neas, executive director of the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights. He said a veto could resemble the ``Bob Jones University fiasco,'' in which a storm erupted the Reagan administration's move to grant tax-exempt status to that institution despite charges that it practiced discrimination. Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., said, ``I believe there is a good chance that President Bush will sign this bill. But if he vetoes it, I think there is a good chance Congress will override the veto.'' Sen. Arlen Specter, R-Pa., who voted for the bill, held out hope that even after months of disagreement the administration and sponsors could reach a compromise. He said talks were getting under way again. A summer of negotiations that were revived briefly in September have produced nothing. Some lawmakers believe Bush will opt to ``pocket veto'' the bill, allowing it to die for lack of a signature after Congress adjourns and leaves Washington for the campaign trail. Both sides in the debate have acknowledged that the sheer complexity of the measure has led to confusion. ``It is not ... a battle between David Duke and the rest of us for the soul of the Republican Party,'' Sen. John C. Danforth, R-Mo., said. ``It is a quibbling over words that lawyers have been involved in.'' Sen. Howard M. Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, was critical earlier of Republicans for opposing the bill. ``Is this the Republican Party of Abraham Lincoln?'' he said. ``Or is this the Republican Party of David Duke?'' GOP lawmakers winced at the mention of Duke, a former Ku Klux Klan leader and current Louisiana state legislator who counts himself as a Republican even though GOP officials have taken enormous pains to repudiate him. ``I think bringing in David Duke is hitting below the belt a bit,'' said Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah. Metzenbaum came back to the floor contritely later and said it had been ``inappropriate and improper'' to associate Republicans with Duke.

DOC.HEAD: Concert Pianist Jorge Bolet Dead at 75
DOC.TEXT: Jorge Bolet, regarded as one of the last of the great romantic concert pianists, has died of heart failure at age 75. Bolet, who died Tuesday at his Mountain View home, retired from the concert stage last year because of declining health. His last public performance was at a Berlin recital June 8, 1989. ``There may be others who can play the notes, but Bolet, with his roots in an older tradition than most today ... has a feeling for the line, the elegance, the suave sound, the tapered phrase of high romanticism that is virtually unmatched today,'' Harold Schonberg said of the pianist in a 1978 review for The New York Times. Although not widely known early in his career, Bolet came to prominence during the past decade as the music of Franz Liszt enjoyed a resurgence of popularity. He made more than two dozen recordings for London/Decca Records in the 1980s, including nine of piano works by Liszt. He also recorded music by Brahms, Grieg, Rachmaninoff, Schumann, Tchaikovsky and Debussy. His last recordings, of two Chopin sonatas and selected nocturnes, were made in March. The Cuban-born Bolet also taught at Indiana University from 1970 to 1977 and headed the piano department at Philadelphia's Curtis Institute from 1977 to 1986.

DOC.HEAD: Texas Senator Faces Balancing Act in Handling Deficit Plan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS penultimate graf pvs `After his ...' with 1 graf to DELETE reference to capital gains and ADD push for oil industry tax breaks.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Budget-Taxes, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Lloyd Bentsen faces a difficult balancing act this week as he helps shepherd a deficit-reduction plan through the Senate. As chairman of the Finance Committee, he aims to promote a compromise that can pass a divided Senate. As a national Democratic leader, he knows that position could blunt his party's class-conscious attack on President Bush. So the Texas senator is doing his best to have it both ways - doing the former and talking the latter. Bentsen and Senate Republicans have crafted a moderate deficit-reduction plan, a collection of new taxes and spending cuts devoid of the soak-the-rich elements House Democrats put in their package. ``When the country has these serious problems, you've got to put the country first and not worry about the political consequences,'' he said. But Bentsen also expressed longing for what the House Democrats could do with their overwhelming majority and spiced his discussion with digs at Bush. ``I wanted to raise the tax rate on the top six-tenths of 1 percent of the people,'' he lamented. ``But there was no way I could get the bill out of committee.'' ``The American people were fed up with our not coming to an agreement and the president not ... bringing about the agreement, not seeing that kind of leadership,'' Bentsen said in a television appearance Sunday. He kept up the criticism in an interview Tuesday. ``I think the president should be here involved and exercising leadership'' instead of making campaign trips for Republican candidates, he said. What does not emerge is whether Bentsen has his own campaign trips at the back of his mind. Will the Democratic vice presidential nominee of 1988 seek the top job in 1992? ``I've got loads to lift here,'' he laughed. Those loads include a long list of unpopular tax increases and cuts in benefit programs, raising Americans' costs for everything from beer to doctors' visits. ``This gets in the way of any national political ambition anybody may have,'' said Jack DeVore, Bentsen's longtime spokesman. In 1988, another former Senate Finance chairman, Sen. Bob Dole, R-Kan., had his campaign for the GOP presidential nomination derailed in part because he drafted a deficit-reduction plan that included tax increases. Dole tried to make the deficit an issue, refused to sign a no-new-taxes pledge and was defeated by Bush. But Dole maintains that having served as chairman of the tax-writing committee actually was ``a big plus'' in his campaign. Compared with other candidates, he had a broad knowledge of federal programs that voters wanted to talk about. As for his loss, Dole said, ``That was partly our fault ... We sat on a lead we thought we had.'' The tax issue hurts most ``if you allow the opponents to characterize it,'' agreed David Moore, a political scientist at the University of New Hampshire. Bentsen's early refusal to exempt home heating oil from a proposed petroleum tax ``obviously could be an issue that could be used against him'' and must be handled skillfully, he said. But while taxes are at the center of GOP politics, Bentsen's compromising could renew suspicions in his party that he's not the populist he sometimes portrays himself to be, said Republican campaign consultant Eddie Mahe. After his vice presidential run, Bentsen rejoined private clubs he quit for the campaign and resumed his push for tax breaks for the oil industry. ``He wants his cake and wants to eat it, too,'' Mahe said.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Budget-Taxes, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 2 `INDEXING: Forgo ...' to CORRECT that wealthiest not affected
DOC.TEXT: Here are major provisions in a Democratic deficit-reduction plan approved by the House Tuesday: INDEXING: Forgo for one year the annual adjustments to income tax brackets and personal exemptions, which are designed to protect against inflation-caused bracket creep. That would mean higher income taxes in 1991 for everybody except the wealthiest. TAX RATES: Raise the 28 percent top rate paid by the wealthiest people - single people with taxable income over $97,620 and couples above $162,770 - to 33 percent. Impose a 10 percent surtax on those with taxable incomes over $1 million. GASOLINE: Unlike other plans, the bill contains no change in taxes on gasoline or heating oil. ALCOHOL: Raise the $12.50-a-gallon tax on 100-proof liquor by $1; double the beer tax to 32 cents a six-pack; raise taxes on most wines, including, for example, table wine, which would go from 3 cents a 750-milliliter bottle to 25 cents. TOBACCO: Raise the 16-cent cigarette tax by 4 cents in 1991 and another 4 cents in 1993. Snuff, cigars and other tobacco would face 25 percent tax increases each year. FLYING: Raise the 8 percent tax on airline tickets to 10 percent. LUXURIES: Impose a 10 percent tax on the portion of the price of cars above $30,000, private boats and planes above $100,000, jewelry above $5,000 and furs above $10,000. CAPITAL GAINS: Allow a person to avoid tax on half of up to $200,000 of capital gains earned in a lifetime; the gains could come from most investments but not from stocks. A person with annual income under $100,000 could avoid tax on an additional $1,000 a year of gains, including those on the sale of stock. No capital gain would be taxed at a rate above 28 percent. LOW-INCOME: Increase the earned-income tax credit, which benefits low-income families with children, as a way of offsetting some of the increased excise taxes. MEDICARE TAXES: Increase to $100,000 the maximum annual wage to which the 1.45 percent Medicare tax applies. The tax is withheld as part of the Social Security tax. MEDICARE PREMIUMS: Raise the $28.60 monthly premium for Medicare Part B insurance to $29.90 next year and $46.20 by 1995. MEDICARE DEDUCTIBLE: Raise to $100 through 1995 the present $75 deductible, which beneficiaries must pay before Medicare starts paying for doctor bills. SOCIAL SECURITY: Require all state and local government workers who are not covered by a public retirement plan to pay Social Security taxes.

DOC.HEAD: National Fire Academy Needs Money To Correct Violations
With PM-Budget-Taxes, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Students at the National Fire Academy sometimes are given a field assignment: Find as many fire code violations as you can at the nation's top fire safety training center. There are 180. Embarrassed federal fire officials hope federal budget-cutters this year don't ax the $4.6 million needed to comply with the Maryland state fire code. The money was part of a $78 billion spending package passed Tuesday by an appropriations conference committee. The center has corrected minor fire code violations in the past few years, but now needs $4.6 million to make structural changes to buildings that have failed inspections by the state fire marshal's office. The state last inspected the campus April 27 and plans to return Nov. 4. ``Not all of those 180 violations are considered life-threatening, but they do have a few that are serious,'' Deputy State Fire Marshal Bob Thomas said Tuesday. Inadequate exits in the campus dining hall and auditorium are the two most urgent problems, he said. ``This is our national fire station, and we need to make sure it is fit for duty,'' said Sen. Barbara Mikulski, D-Md., chairman of the Appropriations Subcommittee on Veteran's Administration, Department of Housing and Urban Development and Independent Agencies. The fire academy's money still must pass floor votes in both chambers and be signed by President Bush. The fire academy, part of the National Emergency Management Agency, has been based on a quiet campus of old, red-brick buildings in the Catoctin Mountains 70 miles northwest of Washington since 1980. Each year, thousands of career and volunteer firefighters attend training sessions to learn the latest in fire prevention and fire department management.

DOC.HEAD: Palestinians Boycott Hurd Meeting; Israel Again Rejects U.N. Probe
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Leads with 11 grafs to UPDATE with Palestinian leaders boycotting meeting with Hurd. Pickup 6th graf pvs, `Shamir's letter...'
DOC.TEXT: ALLYN FISHER=

Palestinian leaders today boycotted a planned meeting with British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd and denounced Israel's refusal to accept a U.N. investigation of last week's Temple Mount killings. Meanwhile, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir has appealed to President Bush to ``put the Temple Mount incident behind us'' but again rejected a United Nations probe of the killings at the sacred site, a spokesman said today. The Security Council voted unanimously on Friday to condemn the fatal police shootings of 19 Palestinians on Oct. 8 on Jerusalem's Temple Mount. The resolution ordered a three-member investigation team to be sent to Jerusalem. The police assault in Jerusalem's Old City began after Palestinians began hurling stones from the Temple Mount down on Jewish worshipers at the Western Wall, Judaism's holiest site. The appeal to Bush to repair torn U.S.-Israeli ties came in a letter sent after Shamir's Cabinet turned down the U.N. probe, said Shamir spokesman Avi Pazner. Israel's refusal to meet a U.N. investigating delegation has increased tension in U.S.-Israel relations, but a senior official said Israeli leaders were privately seeking a compromise. One proposal being studied, the official said, was to submit to the United Nations the results of Israel's own investigation. The Israeli report is expected to be ready by the end of the month. The Palestinian leaders' boycott of their planned meeting with the British foreign secretary came after statements attributed to Hurd in Israeli news reports that Britain opposed a Palestinian state. The British Consulate in Arab east Jerusalem issued a statement saying Hurd's remarks had been misreported. The 27 Palestinians who were to have met with Hurd instead signed a statement and had it delivered to him. ``Israel's refusal to cooperate with the (U.N.) secretary general's mission of investigation is symptomatic not only of its continued intransigence, but also of its contempt for the will of the Security Council and for the internationally recognized rights of the Palestinian people,'' the Palestinian statement said. Shamir's letter to Bush was sent Monday, a day after the Cabinet rejected the weekend Security Council resolution condemning the killings and ordering the U.N. probe. Pazner declined to make the letter public but summarized portions in a telephone interview. He said Shamir rejected a U.N. probe ``for the simple reason that this resolution ... contains only a one-sided condemnation and doesn't mention the attack on Jews. Above all it deals a blow to Israeli sovereignty'' over Jerusalem.'' Pazner said that in the letter, Shamir ``suggests to Bush to put the Temple Mount incident behind us and continue dialogue between Israel and Washington.'' The Mount is sacred to both religions, and Palestinians maintained they began throwing stones after rumors spread that a Jewish extremist group was marching to the site, which is under the control of Moslem clerics. The Old City is part of land that Israel annexed after capturing it from Jordan in the 1967 Middle East war. Most Western countries do not recognize Israel's annexation of predominantly Arab east Jerusalem and consider it to be occupied territory like the West Bank and Gaza Strip. News of Shamir's letter follows urging by both Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker III that Israel reverse its decision to boycott the U.N. mission. ``It is the only way Israel will be able to make its case to the Security Council,'' Baker said in Washington on Tuesday. Pazner insisted Shamir's letter to the president offered no compromise on the issue of a U.N. probe. But a senior official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the government was contemplating offering to give the United Nations a report on the shootings by a three-man Israeli investigating commission. The Israeli investigators, headed by former Mossad spy chief Zvi Zamir, were expected to finish taking testimony today and compile their report by the month's end. Israeli human rights activists already have criticized the Israeli invesgitation as inadequate, saying it cannot be truly independent since it is not headed by a judge and has no power to subpoena witnesses.

DOC.HEAD: IRA, Ulster Freedom Fighters Claim Separate Killings
DOC.TEXT: The Irish Republican Army said today it killed a former police reservist, and the Ulster Freedom Fighters said it gunned down a Catholic man. The former reservist, identified as Stephen Craig, 24, from Bangor in County Down, and a Roman Catholic civilian, Dermot McGuinness, 41, of north Belfast, died in separate shootings Tuesday night, police said. The Ulster Freedom Fighters is the military wing of the outlawed Ulster Defense Association, which claims to defend the Protestant majority in Northern Ireland. The McGuinness family made a plea that there be no attempt to avenge the killing. ``Grief is grief no matter what side of the community it affects and I would appeal to those considering retaliation to desist,'' said Pascal O'Hare, whose niece Mary is McGuinness' widow. ``Nothing has or can be achieved by it. Twenty years of violence in this country has got us nowhere,'' O'Hare said. Police said the two attacks occurred in predominantly Catholic areas about two miles apart. Police said in the first attack a gunman got out of a car, believed stolen from the Protestant stronghold Shankill area of west Belfast, and opened fire on McGuinness, who was returning home from a liquor store. Craig was shot and killed in a hotel parking lot an hour later, police said. He had been drinking with friends in the hotel and was shot as he waited for a taxi to take him home, police said. Legislator Cecil Walker, a member of the Ulster Unionist Party, which is committed to British rule in Northern Ireland, called today for a stepped-up police effort. ``There needs to be more covert operations,'' he said. ``The authorities are not looking at the situation seriously enough and until such time as they do then I'm afraid we're going to get more and more of these killings.'' The IRA said in a message to Belfast media Tuesday it was also responsible for an attack on two policemen in Belfast on Saturday. One of the policemen died Monday. The other was hospitalized in serious but stable condition. The mainly Catholic IRA wants to unite Northern Ireland with the Irish Republic. Protestant loyalists are fighting to maintain British rule.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Pay Respects to Vietnamese Statesman Le Duc Tho
With PM-US-Vietnam
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Vietnamese lined the streets of Hanoi today to pay their respects to Le Duc Tho, the silver-haired statesman best known for his role in the Paris peace talks that ended the Vietnam war. Vietnam's state radio said the funeral procession, accompanied by top Vietnamese leaders, made its way to the state Mai Dich cemetery, the resting place of many other of the country's dignitaries. The radio said Communist Party chief Nguyen Van Linh, other leaders and Tho's family escorted the flag-draped coffin. It did not say when the burial would take place. Tho died of an unspecified illness on Saturday in Hanoi, three days after his 79th birthday. In a eulogy, Linh praised Tho for his long career as a revolutionary and his contributions to the victory over U.S.-backed South Vietnam that led to Communist rule over a united Vietnam. The Vietnam News Agency said more than 130 Vietnamese and foreign delegations had paid respects to Tho on Tuesday as his body lay in state in a conference hall in the capital. His death marked another step in Vietnam's transition away from leadership by aged hard-liners and toward more pragmatic policies of economic reform and expanded ties with the West. Former party chief Le Duazation of agricultural land. RUSSIAN PLAN - Would end state control over businesses and property, with the private sector prevailing in most industries and private citizens, not agencies, as property holders. Some property would be sold at low or symbolic cost to labor collectives. Leasing might be possible, as would be private family property, but the republics would determine some forms of ownership. --- BUDGET, FINANCING= GORBACHEV PLAN - Federal budget would be financed through federal taxes. Republics and localities would also have the right to levy taxes. A central bank would be created to control money supply and credit, and the ruble would be the only legal tender throughout the country. YELTSIN PLAN: Strict control on state spending, reform of the banking system. Russia would issue its own currency. --- CENTRAL CONTROL= GORBACHEV PLAN - Central government to retain control of defense, energy production, nuclear power, highway and rail systems, space exploration, maritime affairs. Republics would control their own resources, although details apparently would be left to a proposed ``inter-republic economic committee,'' with as yet undefined enforcement powers. YELTSIN PLAN - Economic union would be on a voluntary basis; central government would control most national security affairs, although not all foreign relations. Republics largely would control their own energy resources.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
STOCKHOLM: academy said.
DOC.TEXT: Organic synthesis is the production of complicated biological compounds, using simple and cheap starting materials, the academy said. ``It is one of the prerequisites of our civilization,'' the academy said. The field has been rewarded with the Nobel Prize seven times before. The academy said Corey's successes lay in the fact ``that he has in a strictly logical way developed the principles of what is termed retrosynthetic analysis,'' one method of organic synthesis. It said Corey's method has been adapted for use with computers, speeding its use in the creation of new products. Corey has synthesized about 100 important drugs and other natural products, the academy said.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Cleared of Charges She Gave Drugs to Her Unborn Child
DOC.TEXT: An indictment charging a woman with providing cocaine to her unborn child has been thrown out by a Superior Court judge, who called the charge a violation of the woman's right to privacy. Judge Suzanne V. DelVecchio on Tuesday dismissed a drug distribution indictment against 24-year-old Josephine Pellegrini, a mother of three, for cocaine found in the system of her infant, Nathan. Prosecutors said they had pursued the case to discourage pregnant women from taking illegal drugs. But DelVecchio said in a 16-page ruling that ``there is no familiar bond more intimate and more fundamental than that between the mother and the fetus she carries in her womb.'' She added: ``This court will not permit the destruction of this relationship by the prosecution.'' Pellegrini of Brockton was indicted by a Plymouth County grand jury in September 1989 on charges of distributing cocaine to a minor and cocaine possession. A drug screening by doctors at Brockton Hospital found cocaine in the urine of her son, born July 2, 1989. After reviewing Nathan's medical records, authorities determined Pellegrini must have ingested cocaine shortly before Nathan's birth. Instead of prosecution, DelVecchio suggested ``education and making available medical care and drug treatment centers for pregnant women'' to deal with increased drug abuse. ``By imposing criminal sanctions, a woman may turn away from seeking prenatal care for fear of being discovered, thereby undermining the state's asserted interests,'' she said in the ruling. ``The state's interests would be further undermined when women seek to terminate their pregnancies for fear of criminal sanctions.'' Nancy Gertner, a lawyer who argued as a friend-of-the-court for dismissal, said the decision is a first in Massachusetts courts and could be used as a precedent nationwide. Geline Williams, the assistant prosecutor handling the case, said her office has not decided whether to appeal or to continue pursuing cocaine possession charges against Pellegrini.

DOC.HEAD: Semi-Submerged Soviet Ship Said to Pose Radiation Danger
DOC.TEXT: The radioactive hulk of a semi-submerged Soviet ship in a lake near the Finnish border poses a major environmental hazard, a Finnish radiation safety official said today. ``We have every reason to be worried and urgently need more information about the hulk,'' said Olli Vilkamo, senior inspector at the Finnish Center for Radiation and Nuclear Safety. The German-built ship, sunk in Lake Ladoga 30 miles from the Finnish-Soviet border, was reportedly used in Soviet secret military experiments during the 1950s. Lake Ladoga supplies drinking water for 5 million people in Leningrad, the second-largest Soviet city. It is the largest freshwater lake in Europe. Finnish officials first learned of the existence of the radioactive hulk from Finnish television journalists who had obtained a Soviet-made documentary on the subject, Vilkamo said. Finnish television broadcast the film Tuesday. The Soviet report said the ship contained 2,000 tons of radioactive water containing strontium 90, a deadly substance present in fallout from nuclear explosions. ``If the reports are true, then it's a lot ... and definitely there is a great risk here. Strontium 90 is extremely dangerous. Great caution has to be exercised in moving the hulk or pumping out the radioactive water,'' Vilkamo said. Finnish officials will assist Soviet authorities in every way possible, Vilkamo said but added that ``they have their own very good experts, and we are confident they can deal with it.'' A treaty between Finland and the Soviet Union obliges the two countries to report accidents and radioactive leaks to one another, but Vilkamo said he was uncertain whether the presence of the ship came under the agreement.

DOC.HEAD: Thieves Take 120 Pounds of Meat From Soup Kitchen
DOC.TEXT: Thieves broke through a window at the Community Soup Kitchen and stole 120 pounds of roast beef that was meant to feed lunch to more than 250 poor and homeless people. ``What a nasty, nasty thing,'' said William A. Sherry, a member of the soup kitchen's board of directors. ``Stealing food from a soup kitchen. I mean, how low can you get?'' But the robbers unwittingly left behind a small blessing. By leaving the soup kitchen's refrigerator open, they thawed 150 pounds of frozen fish sticks that made enough meals to feed lunch to the poor on Tuesday. David O'Sullivan, the coordinator of the soup kitchen, said he left 120 pounds of frozen, cajun-style roast beef in a locked storeroom, thawing for Tuesday's lunch. But when he arrived at work Tuesday, a window was shattered and the meat boxes were empty. ``It's really discouraging that people are stealing from those who need it most,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Main Road Blocked by Fires, Farm Evacuated
DOC.TEXT: Fire scorched nearly all 450 acres of the Ahihud collective farm today, driving out hundreds of families. A fire chief said it was the worst blaze ever in Galilee. The brush fire killed some cows, destroyed some homes in Ahihud and blocked a main highway in northern Israel. It threatened a nearby kibbutz and two Arab-Iraeli villages, all just east of the biblical city of Acre. Air force helicopters were rushed in to extinguish the blaze. The West Galilee fire chief, Yossi Ben-Ezra, said it was the worst fire ever in Galilee. ``It's terrible, my future is over,'' farmer Yehiya Damti of Ahihud said on Israel radio as he viewed his burned fields, barn and livestock. ``It just makes me want to commit suicide.'' The fire was one of several that broke out today in Galilee. Ben-Ezra said the cause of the fires was unclear, but unseasonably hot weather and dust storms had spread the flames. Palestinian activists often have called for setting fire to Israeli property as part of their 34-month uprising against Israeli rule in the occupied lands. Ben-Ezra said no clear evidence of arson had been found. He said about a 20-mile stretch of main highway linking Acre to the holy Jewish city of Safed had been closed for several hours because of the fire. About 100 families in Ahihud were evacuated by buses to a nearby settlement for several hours until the fire was brought under control. Eight people were treated for smoke inhalation, Ben-Ezra said. Air force helicopters also took several hours to put out fire in Yarka, an Arab village. It was the second straight day of brush fires in northern Israel. On Tuesday nearly 500 acres of woodland were scorched by an unexplained fire that destroyed some 300-year-old trees. Some of Tuesday's fires started accidentally and spread by the wind, Israeli newspapers said.

DOC.HEAD: Los Angeles Adopts Nation's Most Comprehensive AIDS Policy
DOC.TEXT: The City Council has embraced an extensive AIDS policy asserting sufferers' rights and promoting prevention with controversial methods including distribution of condoms and hypodermic sterilization kits. ``It is a policy that establishes a national model,'' Councilman Joel Wachs said. ``It is a reaffirmation of our city's unwavering commitment to stand by people with AIDS. ``It is fair to say that AIDS is nothing less than a national crisis.'' The City Council voted 11-1 Tuesday to adopt a policy that ``declares AIDS a natural disaster and a global emergency.'' About 112,000 people in Los Angeles County are infected with the AIDS virus and more than 60,000 of those people live within the city limits, the document said. The policy calls for increased spending on acquired immune deficiency syndrome at all levels of government. City departments have six months to plan implementation and determine costs. The community development department was ordered to estimate the policy's long-term fiscal implications. The document outlines new problems, such as training for city employees and distribution of AIDS prevention kits, including condoms and hypodermic needle-cleaning bleach kits, to people being released from jail. The county, not the city, runs the jail system and the county Board of Supervisors has twice gone on record against public distribution of condoms and bleach kits. The blueprint reinforces the city's stand against discrimination, the position that AIDS patients have a right not to disclose their condition and that casual contact doesn't spread AIDS. It gives city employees the right to withhold information on whether they have the disease. The policy also affirms that everyone with the disease has a right to dignity, respect, civil rights and a choice of care and treatment options. The policy urges the federal government to reverse immigration policies that exclude people who test positive to the HIV virus that causes AIDS. It also opposes mandatory HIV testing and mass quarantines of AIDS patients. Councilman Robert Farrell called it ``a document of love, commitment and passion.'' Colleague Michael Woo said: ``I feel we are being a beacon for the rest of the country.'' Mayor Tom Bradley urged cities nationwide to follow the lead. Councilman Ernani Bernardi was the lone dissenter. He said the only way to battle the AIDS epidemic is to identify those with the disease.

DOC.HEAD: Fundamentalists Seek Alcohol Ban at Tourist Hotels
DOC.TEXT: Islamic fundamentalists are seeking to ban alcohol and ``debauchery'' at some tourist hotels, in the latest move to impose Koranic law in areas where they took power in elections four months ago. Algerian dock workers, meanwhile, refused to unload the French car ferry Napoleon because it had previously transported French soldiers and military equipment to the Persian Gulf region. The dock workers delayed the ferry's unloading by two hours Tuesday as ``a sign of solidarity with Iraq,'' a union official said. The fundamentalists of the Islamic Salvation Front swept June 12 council elections, Algeria's first free vote since indpendence from France in 1962, and are the leading party going into legislative voting next spring. Fundamentalists on the provincial council of Bouira, east of the capital, said Tuesday that potential loss of tourist revenue does not outweigh the need to enforce Islamic law at the hotels. The hotels that are the target of their anti-alcohol campaign are frequented mostly by foreign tourists on their way to the rugged region, one of this North African country's main tourist attractions.

DOC.HEAD: Ukrainian Prime Minister To Resign Following Huge Protests
DOC.TEXT: The Ukrainian prime minister has decided to resign following huge street marches, classroom boycotts and hunger strikes by students opposed to his government, Tass said today. In the largest demonstration during the two-week protest, as many as 100,000 students reportedly marched today down the main street of Kiev, the Ukrainian capital. The official Soviet news agency said Ukrainian President Leonid Kravchuk told the republic's legislature this morning that the prime minister, Vitaly Masol, intends to resign. Tass quoted an unidentified parliamentary source as saying Masol informed the president of his decision to quit on Tuesday, but had not formally submitted his resignation by late today. Masol, 62, was appointed prime minister in June. Several dozen students began a hunger strike in Kiev two weeks ago to press for Masol's resignation, dissolution of parliament and new elections. Throughout the republic, thousands of students have supported the hunger strikers in street demonstrations and classroom boycotts. Rukh, the nationalist Ukrainian organization, said 100,000 students marched peacefully through Kiev today to the republic's Supreme Soviet building. Rukh spokesman Romanna Meinichenko said by telephone from Kiev that he had no information about Masol. Meinichenko said about 200 students are still on a hunger strike, some in front of the Supreme Soviet and the others in a tent camp in October Revolution Square in the city center. The hunger strikers also are demanding that the Ukraine nationalize Communist Party property and refuse to sign a new treaty linking the 15 Soviet republics with the central government. They want Ukrainians drafted into the Red Army to be permitted to serve within the republic's borders. Interfax, an unofficial arm of Radio Moscow, said 20,000 students boycotted classes in the Lvov region near the Polish border on Tuesday, and 40 students and instructors from the Polytechnic Institute staged a one-day hunger strike. It said 1,500 high school and trade school students picketed the building of the Lvov region Communist Party committee. On Monday, students went on strike in Kiev and up to 50,000 marched through the city to the Ukrainian parliament building, Interfax reported. Interfax said thousands of students carrying blue and yellow Ukrainian flags marched through Kiev again on Tuesday in an unsuccessful attempt to enlist worker support. The Ukraine is one of 13 Soviet republics seeking greater autonomy from the central government in Moscow.

DOC.HEAD: Douglas Campbell, World War I Flying Ace, Dead at 94
DOC.TEXT: Douglas Campbell, the first American-trained World War I to be called an ace for shooting down five enemy planes, has died of respiratory failure at age 94. Campbell, who died Tuesday at his Greenwich home, shot down six German planes over France during April, May and June of 1918. His exploits are recounted in the 1984 book ``Let's Go Where The Action Is: The Wartime Experiences of Douglas Campbell,'' by Jack Eder. Two American pilots, Maj. William Thaw and Capt. D.M.K. Peterson, had each previously downed five planes, but they trained in France with the Lafayette Escadrille, not under American commanders. Campbell left Harvard University after his senior year in 1917 to begin his military career with the 94th Squadron, known as the ``Hat in the Ring'' squadron, of the First Pursuit Group. He learned to fly at the Army Flying School in France, then flew the first American mission over enemy lines on March 6, 1918, with Eddie Rickenbacker, a race-car driver who became the leading fighter ace in American military history by shooting down 26 planes. Campbell was wounded by a bullet fragment during a dogfight over France, when he shot down his last German plane, but managed to fly back to base safely. He was discharged as a captain and received the American Distinguished Service Cross with four oak leaves. The French made him a Chevalier of the Legion of Honor and awarded him the Croix de Guerre with three palms. Campbell spoke modestly about his accomplishments. ``Because I was the first American to shoot down some planes, they gave me more medals than they should have,'' he said in a 1985 interview. He retired in 1963 from Panagra, the airline formed by W.R. Grace Co. and Pan American World Airways to serve Latin America, as a vice president and general manager of the company. Campbell is survived by his wife, Virginia Pope Campbell, two daughters, four sons, 12 grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. Services will be private.

DOC.HEAD: Nobel Winner: `I Thought I Was Still Asleep and Dreaming'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to UPDATE with chemistry winner's comments. Picks up 3rd graf pvs: ``It's an ...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Nobel-Science
DOC.TEXT: ``I thought I was still asleep and dreaming,'' Jerome I. Friedman, one of two Americans who won the Nobel Prize in physics, said today after hearing the news that he had been honored by the Swedish Academy of Sciences. Friedman and Henry W. Kendall won the prize with a third researcher, Canadian Richard E. Taylor, for work in the late 1960s that showed protons and neutrons, once thought to be fundamental particles, were made up of smaller components called quarks. American Elias James Corey of Harvard University won the prize in chemistry for research that simplified the production of plastics and other artificial fibers, paints and dyes, pesticides and drugs. Corey, 62, has synthesized about 100 important drugs and other natural products, the academy said. Corey said he was walking into the Harvard chemistry building today when a graduate student told him he had won. ``This is a statistically improbable event. There are so many scientists who are so deserving,'' he said. He said that for years people had said he was nominated, ``but I have maintained solid skepticism.'' ``My philosphy has been to try to be as logical as I can. I try to teach my science,'' Corey said. About 15 students celebrated outside Corey's office with cans of beer - they said they couldn't afford champagne. ``It's an overwhelming experience. I never expected it,'' Friedman said from his hotel room in Fort Worth, Texas, where he was attending a conference. Friedman, 60, and Kendall, 63, are professors at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Taylor, 60, born in Medicine Hat, Alberta, is a professor at Stanford University. Friedman lives in Brookline, Mass., and Kendall in Sharon, Mass. Taylor, contacted at his Stanford, Calif., home this morning, said he was surprised to hear he had been awarded the prize for his work on the quarks, now believed to be the basic building blocks of matter. ``One thing that's remarkable is how little you say when the conversation starts with the secretary of the academy in Sweden,'' said Taylor, who had been asleep when he was notified about 4 a.m. ``It's a big deal,'' he conceded. ``On the other hand, I know a great many people who have won the Nobel Prize. It's a great honor.'' The Nobelists, who will share the $700,000 physics prize, conducted a series of experiments at Stanford between 1968 and 1972 involving the acceleration of protons in order to better examine their structures. That process, Taylor said, started an even longer process where more quarks were discovered. ``This was one step in the chain to forge that essential understanding we have now of the elementary particles,'' he said. Taylor said he was most influenced by W.K.H. Panofsky, then director of the Stanford Linear Acceleration Center. ``It was his vision and hard work that generated the accelerator to do the experiment,'' Taylor said. ``I think of him as directly responsible.'' Panofsky is now director emeritus of the center, which is operated by Stanford for the Department of Energy. ``It was one of the profound contributions made'' to the field, Panofsky said when contacted at his Los Altos, Calif., home this morning. ``And it came out differently from the way the thing was intended. I'm very happy. That's about all I can say.'' Panofsky said he wasn't surprised that the three won the Nobel Prize nearly 20 years after the conclusion of their experiments. ``I knew it was clearly a classical achievement that changed the way one looked at the structure of things,'' he said. ``It was something that was clearly deserved for a long time, and it was sooner or later, one would hope, that this would happen.'' Friedman said curiosity led them to it. ``As human beings, we have great curiosity about how nature works. ... human beings try to understand everything,'' he said. ``One never knows what the application of basic research will be,'' he added. ``Knowing what the structure of matter is, ultimately has to have some effect on how you model the entire structure of things.''

DOC.HEAD: Two More Corruption Cases Against Bhutto
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 5th graf, `They say...' with 1 graf to RESTORE dropped word `aid.' Pickup 6th, `But growing...'
DOC.TEXT: The army-backed caretaker government today filed two more corruption cases against Benazir Bhutto, intensifying the legal pressure on the ousted prime minister a week before national elections. Today's action brought to six the number of cases before special one-judge tribunals set up to try corruption charges against the 37-year-old former prime minister, her husband and key members of her ousted government. Justice Mohammad Amir Malik set a hearing for Saturday to determine whether Ms. Bhutto should stand trial. Some legal experts doubt that any of the cases against Ms. Bhutto will be completed before parliamentary elections on Oct. 24. They say Pakistan's judicial process is slow and cumbersome and that the courts seem reluctant to step up the process for fear that Western countries, especially the United States, will cut off millions of dollars in economic and military aid if Ms. Bhutto is disqualified. But growing resentment over U.S. influence in this Moslem country of 110 million people has become an election issue, and many fear Ms. Bhutto will be disqualified just before the poll to spite Washington. President Ghulam Ishaq Khan, meanwhile, sought to dispel fears expressed by some that the election will be canceled and martial law imposed. ``The whole nation is looking forward to the holding of peaceful, free, fair and impartial elections and the smooth transfer of power to the popularly elected government,'' Ishaq Khan said in a letter to top government leaders and Gen. Mirza Aslam Beg, the army chief of staff. The letter was made public today by Kamal Azfar, an aide to caretaker Prime Minister Ghulam Mustafa Jatoi. Ms. Bhutto was dismissed Aug. 6 by Ishaq Khan, who charged her 20-month-old government was so corrupt and so incompetent that it could no longer function. She is challenging the decision in the courts. The charges filed today allege Ms. Bhutto used hundreds of millions of dollars in secret service funds to buy political favors and used government and military aircraft to transport supporters in Parliament during a no-confidence vote last year. She is being tried on similar charges before another special tribunal in Lahore and one in Karachi, her hometown. If convicted, she could be banished from politics for seven years. Ms. Bhutto has steadfastly denied any wrongdoing. At least seven former Cabinet ministers, including her father-in-law, Hakim Ali Zardari, have been charged with corruption before tribunals and more than 100 supporters in her Pakistan People's Party have been arrested. Her husband of nearly three years, Asif Ali Zardari, also has been arrested and jailed in the abduction of a Pakistani-born British man in April. Zardari, 38 and a candidate for Parliament, was charged with extortion and kidnapping before a special anti-terrorism tribunal. He has been denied bail and ordered held until Tuesday, the day before the election. Ms. Bhutto was allowed to visit her husband for two hours today, their first visit since his arrest a week ago.
