Reductions would be required not just from factories, refineries and chemical plants, but also from smaller businesses such as dry cleaners and furniture refinishers, and even from garbage incinerators. Sen. David Durenberger, R-Minn., who led Senate negotiators on the industrial emissions section of the bill, said he believed an acid rain agreement could be reached by the end of the week. Rep. Gerry Sikorski, D-Minn., said he expects attempts by Midwest lawmakers to push for additional measures to reduce the cost of meeting new acid rain controls, but he said negotiators of all points of view who want to get a bill enacted into law ``will not put up with a lot of grandstanding at this point.'' Wednesday's compromise followed long closed-door negotiations, often late into the night against the deadline of an Oct. 26 adjournment, that began last weekend and for a time were bogged down over whether to give the steel industry additional time to comply with the new pollution controls. It was agreed to give steel companies another 20 years, to the year 2020, to cut cancer-causing emissions from coke ovens. The industry had argued the ovens would be forced to shut down without the extension. The negotiations immediately turned to the bill's acid rain provision, which would require electric utilities to cut annual emissions of sulfur dioxide by 10 million tons by the end of the decade. The Bush administration has estimated the bill, if enacted, would cost the economy between $21 billion and $25 billion a year once fully in effect. Environmentalists argue much of that amount will be gained in reduced health care costs from cleaner air. Congressional sources said Wednesday that while some minor issues remained to be worked out, House and Senate members agreed on requiring industry to install new equipment aimed at cutting toxic emissions from large factories by 90 percent over the next decade. Toxic chemical emissions from smaller polluters would be reduced by about 75 percent. The emissions cuts would be achieved by requiring companies to install the most effective pollution control technology available for a particular industry. Under the compromise, the Environmental Protection Agency also would be required to direct polluters to take additional measures after the turn of the century if the agency determines people near industrial plants are not being assured of ``an ample margin of safety'' against cancer-causing pollution. If those assurances are not met, plants could be closed. The legislation would regulate more than 250 types of pollution sources. In addition, the compromise would for the first time require new safeguards and response programs in the event of accidental releases of toxic chemicals, Both the House and Senate approved clean air bills by a wide margin earlier this year. But the conference committee negotiations aimed at resolving differences in the bills has at times slowed to a virtual standstill. A breaktrough came Oct. 10 when the two sides reached agreement on measures to reduce smog-causing pollution from automobiles and trucks.

DOC.HEAD: Critics Attack Gorbachev's Plan for Transition to Market Economy
DOC.TEXT: Critics attacked President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's toned-down economic reform plan on Wednesday, and an architect of a more radical transition program protested the retreat by offering his resignation. The reaction came two days after Gorbachev won the Nobel Peace Prize and the day after he unveiled his comparatively slow plan for building a Western-style market economy in the Soviet Union. Grigory Yavlinsky, co-author of the original 500-day plan, offered his resignation as deputy prime minister of Russia, the largest of the 15 Soviet republics. In a speech to the Russian parliament, which adopted the 500-day plan on Sept. 11, Yavlinsky did not mention Gorbachev by name. But he predicted the president's reforms would set off disastrous price increases. ``The market will be entered in this situation not through (economic) stabilization, but through growing inflation,'' he said. ``All that the 500-day program and I, personally, promised in ... living standards cannot be achieved now.'' Boris Yeltsin, president of Russia and Gorbachev's main political rival, on Tuesday criticized the president's plan, calling it a ``catastrophe'' that is ``doomed to fail'' within months. Leaders in the Baltic republics of Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia have shown little willingness to go along with the national reform plan. Their regional economies are more westernized and efficient than the rest of the Soviet system, and they have announced their desire both for political independence and rapid moves toward free enterprise. Several other republics, particularly Georgia and the Ukraine, also are pushing for autonomy and may reject Gorbachev's plan. Approval of Gorbachev's plan is not even certain in the national legislature, which is scheduled to begin debating it Friday. Two legislators told The Associated Press they doubted it would pass. ``It's not detailed enough. It doesn't go far enough,'' said one of the lawmakers, who spoke on condition they not be identified. Gorbachev's plan is an attempt to merge the radical 500-day plan - drafted by economists headed by Yavlinsky and economist Stanislav Shatalin - with several other proposals, including a far more conservative plan presented by Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov. Yavlinsky, 38, accused Ryzhkov's cabinet of putting the conservative plan into effect ``through the back door'' while the national legislature engaged in ``endless delays'' in choosing a reform program. The Russian parliament voted last month to proceed on its own with the 500-day plan, but has yet to take concrete steps to do so. Yavlinsky formally tendered his resignation to the Russian lawmakers, but they postponed acting on it. ``This was a speech by a hot-headed youth, not a mature statesman,'' said the republic's prime minister, Ivan Silayev, who urged the parliament to reject the resignation. Gorbachev is scheduled to defend his plan in a speech to the national legislature on Friday. The 542-member Supreme Soviet could vote on it as early as Saturday, although some lawmakers said a longer debate was likely. The four-stage Gorbachev plan would begin by reducing the national budget deficit, now about $100 billion, and cutting the money supply, which has grown rapidly in recent years, spurring inflation. Western experts estimate Soviets have saved billions of dollars worth of rubles in banks or under their mattresses, because there is little to buy in state stores. Efforts also would be made in the first stage to improve production of consumer goods, now in short supply, and to boost agricultural output through land reform. Each republic would be allowed to decide whether to break collective farms into private plots. In the second stage, at an unspecified date, prices on roughly 70 percent of all goods and services would be freed to respond to market forces. The central government would continue to set prices on fuel, key raw materials and necessities such as bread, milk and sugar. Small private businesses also would be encouraged during the second stage, and a social welfare net would be established to help workers who lose their jobs. The third stage would emphasize establishing a free market for housing, a modern banking system and entrepreneurship. The final stage would end government monopolies in many industries and allow the ruble to be freely traded against other world currencies, encouraging foreign investment in the Soviet Union. Unlike the 500-day plan, Gorbachev's proposal contains no time schedule. It says that similar transitions in other countries have taken 1{ to 2 years. Growing shortages of staples such as meat, gasoline and paper have eroded public support for Gorbachev, and skepticism over his plan appears widespread. ``I think in the existing situation, all the plans (for economic reform) are unrealistic,'' said Ninel Ilyicheva, 55, a publishing house worker. ``I don't see that Gorbachev is really accomplishing anything. I only hear him talk and talk and talk all the time.'' Vladimir Orlov, 46, a Soviet army major, said he considers Gorbachev ``a smart person'' who ``hasn't said his final word yet'' on the economy.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Buy 350,000 Tons of US Corn
DOC.TEXT: After a five-month absence, the Soviet Union has bought some U.S. corn for delivery by the end of the year, the Agriculture Department said Wednesday. Officials said private exporting companies sold 350,000 metric tons to the Soviets under terms of the current long-term supply agreement between the two countries. No prices or other details were disclosed. The pact, including a three-month extension, expires Dec. 31. A new five-year agreement will begin at that time. Although the Soviet Union recently bought some U.S. soybean meal, it had not purchased significant quantities of wheat or corn since last May. Department officials have speculated Moscow delayed purchases to see how 1990 harvests turned out in both the Soviet Union and the United States. Other factors mentioned have included Russian hard currency problems, the direction of U.S. farm legislation and whether the United States might extend credit. Rumors have circulated in the grain trade for weeks that the Soviet Union was or soon would be in the market for more U.S. corn. Market prices have been under pressure from this fall's huge harvest, estimated by the department at 8.02 billion bushels, up 7 percent from the 1989 crop. Large sales to foreign buyers must be reported daily to USDA by exporters. Sales of wheat and corn to the Soviet Union for delivery during the year that ended Sept. 30 totaled 20.3 million tons, including nearly 16.5 million tons of corn and more than 3.8 million tons of wheat. In addition, the Soviets in 1989-90 bought 342,300 tons of soybeans, 1.37 million tons of soybean meal, and 7,300 tons of barley. The 350,000 tons reported Wednesday were the first corn sales for the three-month extension, although soybean meal sales amount to 355,000 tons. A metric ton of 2,205 pounds is equivalent to 39.4 bushels of corn. Thus, the 350,000 tons would be about 13.8 million bushels. Corn prices have been averaging about $2.23 per bushel at the farm level, according to USDA's five-day average. Thus, the latest sale could have a farm value of about $31 million.

DOC.HEAD: Student Unrest in Ukraine Prompts Resignation
DOC.TEXT: Street demonstrations, student hunger strikes and classroom boycotts forced the resignation Wednesday of the prime minister of the Ukraine, the second most populous Soviet republic. The ouster of Prime Minister Vitaly Masol signalled an upsurge in the separatist movement in the Ukraine, known as the Soviet breadbasket. The Ukrainian parliament also passed a resolution embracing other student demands, including the transfer of ownership of Communist Party property to the government and refusal to sign a new treaty of union proposed by Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev, the state news agency Tass reported. The parliament earlier proclaimed Ukraine's right to overrule national laws and barred Ukrainian youths drafted by the Soviet military from serving outside the republic. The unrest in the Ukraine and criticism of Gorbachev's economic program struck new blows at the Soviet president's attempts to maintain a semblance of central authority. Radicals have rejected Gorbachev's proposed treaty of union, which would redefine political and economic links among the 15 republics, nearly all of which have declared some form of sovereignty from the central government. Yeltsin and others want the republics to negotiate forms of cooperation among themselves. Tens of thousands of students in the Ukrainian capital of Kiev celebrated their victory by marching Wednesday evening through October Revolution Square, which they renamed Independence Square to reflect the growing separatist movement, said spokeswoman Natalia Preobrazhenskaya. Members of the Ukrainian legislature, opposition leaders and students addressed the festive rally, called to celebrate the end of a hunger strike that started on Oct. 2, she said. The students began the hunger strike demanding the Ukrainian government move faster to achieve independence from the Soviet Union. By the end, about 200 students were going without food, pressing for the resignation of Masol, dissolution of parliament and new elections for the republic. News media that reported Masol's resignation did not indicate whether parliament would be dissolved or new elections scheduled. The Ukraine was independent briefly after the 1917 Bolshevik Revolution. The eastern Ukraine had been part of czarist Russia from about the year 1700, when the nomadic warriors known as Cossacks threw their allegiance from Poland to Russia. The western Ukraine was part of Poland until World War II. Masol told Ukrainian President Leonid Kravchuk of his decision to quit Tuesday, and submited his resignation Wednesday, Tass said, quoting an unidentified parliamentary source. Masol, 62, was appointed prime minister in June. Doctors sent an appeal to the Ukrainian legislature on Wednesday warning the students' health was being damaged by their hunger strike. Rukh, a nationalist Ukrainian organization, said 100,000 students marched peacefully through Kiev to the republic's Supreme Soviet building on Wednesday. The figure could not be confirmed independently. The protests also spread to other Ukrainian cities, reported Interfax, an independent news agency. In Lvov, along the Polish border, 20,000 students boycotted classes on Tuesday and 40 students and instructors from the Polytechnic Institute staged a one-day hunger strike, Interfax reported. It said 1,500 high school and trade school students picketed the building of the Lvov regional Communist Party committee. On Monday, students went on strike in Kiev, and up to 50,000 marched through the city to the Ukrainian parliament building, Interfax and the Postfactum news agency reported. Thousands of students carrying blue and yellow Ukrainian flags marched through Kiev again on Tuesday in an unsuccessful attempt to enlist worker support, Interfax said. It did not give a precise crowd estimate.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Opposes Senators' Move To Block Arms Sale to Saudi Arabia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 14th graf pvs bgng, `But when,' with 2 grafs to UPDATE with AIPAC denying it was surprised; SUBS 21st graf pvs bgng, `Aides to,' with 3 grafs to UPDATE with motions in the House
DOC.TEXT: The Israeli government and its influential lobby find themselves in an awkward position: they oppose a move by a number of pro-Israeli senators to block a $7.5 billion arms sale to Saudi Arabia. The senators, led by Alan Cranston, D-Calif., and Bob Packwood, R-Ore., submitted a resolution opposing the sale hours after leaders of the American Israel Public Affairs Committee urged them to back off, said sources familiar with the affair. ``This is the first time that pro-Israel forces have ever tried to block opposition to a major arms sale to one of Israel's enemies,'' said one Capitol Hill source. The administration last month notified Congress that it plans to sell the Saudis $7.54 billion in tanks, antitank missiles, rocket launchers, Apache gunships and other weapons deemed necessary to block an attack from Iraq. If Congress doesn't oppose the deal by Oct. 27, it goes into effect. The administration is banking on support for its anti-Iraq policy to push the sale through Congress, where pro-Israeli lawmakers probably would have balked at the unprecedented sale to an Arab state. The State Department reasoned that lawmakers would be unpopular with their constituents if they opposed selling weapons to a country where more than 150,000 American troops are deployed. Israel and its lobbyists in Washington have objected - often successfully - to every major Saudi arms sale in the past decade, building an almost legendary reputation of influence in the process. But AIPAC, bowing to reality, decided to hold its fire until the administration presents to Congress a second package for the Saudis next January, sources said. That proposal, estimated at over $10 billion, is expected to include the latest F-15 jet fighters and is of significantly greater concern to Israel and its supporters than the largely land-based arsenal being proposed now. ``We're concerned about both deals,'' said AIPAC spokeswoman Toby Dershowitz. ``We're working with Congress and the administration to satisfy the concerns about Saudi needs in this crisis and Israel's security needs,'' she said. The lobby's strategy to withhold opposition to the first sale also grew out of concern about jeopardizing various proposals in the House and Senate to help Israel get millions of dollars in emergency weapons against a threatened Iraqi attack. A delegation of Jewish leaders went to Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney last month and promised him it would not oppose this current sale. Similar assurances were given by AIPAC to the State Department's policy planner, Dennis Ross. And one of the Jewish community's top leaders, Max Fisher, paid a call on President Bush and offered his support, too. Imagine, then, the administration's surprise when it discovered last week a well-advanced plan by a group of senators to oppose large portions of the Saudi sale. But when Ross called AIPAC director Tom Dine to complain, he was in for an even bigger surprise. AIPAC, which has been credited by critics and supporters alike for having vast pull in Congress, didn't know about the lawmakers' plan, the sources said. AIPAC denies Dine was surprised. ``We've been in consultation with the Congress all along on the best way to achieve our mutual objectives,'' said Dershowitz. ``Alan (Cranston) did this on his own,'' said the senator's spokesman, Murray Flander. ``He didn't consult AIPAC.'' Dine, worried that AIPAC's credibility was on the line, went to see Cranston and asked him to desist. Another AIPAC leader called Packwood, sources said. But Cranston objected, and submitted his resolution of disapproval of the Saudi sale, along with cosponsors Packwood, Arlen Specter, R-Pa., Frank Lautenberg, D-N.J., and Paul Simon, D-Ill. On the Senate floor, Cranston asked if the idea is to sell the Saudis what they need now to deter Iraq, why is the administration proposing to sell them 150 MiA2 tanks which haven't been built yet and won't be delivered until 1993? In addition, Cranston argued, the weapons could fall into enemy hands in the volatile region, as did U.S. arms in Kuwait. Furthermore, Cranston said, ``We may, as momentary brothers in arms, forget who the Saudis consider to be their real, longtime, irreconcilable enemies,'' namely Israel. Reps. David Obey, D-Wis., and Mel Levine, D-Calif., also introduced a resolution seeking to turn down the Patriots, 150 M1A2 tanks and 12 Apaches, about $4.5 billion of the $7.5 billion package. The sales, Obey said Wednesday, ``would accelerate the arms race in the Middle East caldron which already has massive amounts of advanced military weapons and equipment.'' Aides to Cranston say he is waiting to see whether the Senate adopts a host of measures designed to provide Israel with as much as $1 billion in weapons before deciding whether to forge ahead with the anti-Saudi resolution. Senior lawmakers, including Appropriations Committee Chairman Robert Byrd, D-W.Va., have serious concerns about the pro-Israel amendment, however, and may seek to kill it, said congressional sources.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Department To Require Prisoners To Attain 12th-Grade Skills
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 1 graf with list of 10 prisons in pilot program
DOC.TEXT: Federal prison inmates soon will be required to attend classes until they can read at the 12th-grade level and complete a high-school equivalency degree, the Justice Department said Wednesday. If they refuse to do so, they will be consigned to the lowest-paying prison jobs and they could be subjected to disciplinary actions, the department said. Federal prisoners are currently required to attend classes if they cannot read or perform math problems at the eighth-grade level. Under the higher standards, inmates will be required to master 12th-grade academic skills by attending prison classes, the department said. Tougher literacy standards are intended to raise the chance that inmates will not return to crime once they are released from prison. ``For most who cannot read, competing in the legitimate work world is impossible,'' Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said in remarks prepared for delivery to an international conference on prison literacy in Ottawa. ``We live in a complex world, and the pressure of competition for good-paying jobs, and indeed success in virtually every aspect of modern life, hinges on literacy,'' Thornburgh said. The higher standards are being imposed at a time when 20 percent of the 58,000 federal inmates cannot read at the eighth-grade level and 40 percent have a hitory of drug or alcohol abuse. The Education Department says up to 30 million U.S. adults are illiterate. ``We believe there is a straight-line relationship between literacy levels and an individual's likelihood of involvement in substance abuse,'' Thornburgh said. Many former inmates who cannot read ``turn to drug abuse as an escape, or else come to rely on selling drugs to survive,'' Thornburgh said. The Bureau of Prisons began the mandatory literacy program in the early 1980s. Inmates who did not pass tests of sixth-grade reading and math skills were required to attend classes. The standard was raised later to mastery of eighth-grade skills. The 12th-grade standard, now being enforced as part of a pilot program at 10 facilities, will take effect throughout the federal prison system early next year, said Gregory L. Bogdan, a Bureau of Prisons spokesman. Under the old policy, all federal prisoners must take the reading and math skills tests, no matter what degrees they may have earned, Bogdan said. Under the new policy, inmates who can document that they have at least a high school diploma will not have to take any tests and will be exempt from the class requirement, he said. Inmates are required to attend classes for 90 days. Those who refuse to do so could face disciplinary action such as loss of privileges, additional work hours and possible transfer to an institution with a higher level of security, Bogdan said, although he added, ``I'm not aware of anyone that's ever refused to that extent.'' Inmates who attend classes for 90 days but refuse to continue after that will be consigned to earning the lowest wages in prison jobs, said Bogdan, who once worked as a teacher and principal of the school at the Lewisburg, Pa., federal penitentiary. ``Our job in the education department was to motivate these guys, force the exposure'' to academic subjects, Bogdan said. Inmates also are required to work while in prison, either as clerks and orderlies or in the Federal Prison Industries Program. Inmates earn between 11 cents and 36 cents an hour doing ordinary prison jobs but can earn as much as $1.05 an hour in prison industry jobs. But prisoners who refuse to attend school classes can't earn more than 11 cents an hour in menial jobs or 44 cents an hour in prison industry, Bogdan said. There are also other incentives for completing the program, he said. An inmate who becomes eligible for parole would not want any comments about disciplinary actions to be seen by the parole board, he said. Class attendance also would enhance an inmate's chances to be placed in a halfway house toward the end of a prison sentence, Bogdan said. Last year, 10,546 federal inmates completed eighth-grade requirements and 3,100 finished high-school equivalency programs, Thornburgh said. Another 1,781 finished programs that taught English as a second language. A total of 15,000 federal inmates were enrolled last year in continuing education classes, the attorney general said. ``There is a general consensus that basic literacy not only helps the prisoner after release but, equally important, contributes to a better life while in prison and to a safer environment for both staff an inmates,'' Thornburgh said. The 10 prisons participating in the pilot literacy program are the Federal Correctional Institutes at McKean, Pa.; Fairton, N.J.; Lexington, Ky.; Morgantown, W.Va.; Jesup, Ga.; Sheridan, Ore.; Pleasanton, Calif.; Sandstone, Minn.; Bastrop, Texas; and El Reno, Okla.

DOC.HEAD: Hungary to Join Council of Europe; At Least 3 Others to Follow
DOC.TEXT: The Council of Europe agreed Wednesday to admit Hungary as its first East European member as part of an expansion plan that officials hope will give the low-profile council a larger international role. Hungary will formally become the 24th council member at a Nov. 6 ministrial meeting in Rome. On Nov. 5, Hungarian officials will sign the European Human Rights Convention, a prerequisite for joining the oldest postwar organization striving for European unity and cooperation. The council, founded in 1949 and based in this city on the French-German border, is best known for its human rights convention. Its work long has been overshadowed by the more powerful 12-nation European Community, based in Brussels. Council officials said four other East European countries are in line to join. Last year, as the Iron Curtain disappeared, Czechoslovakia, Poland, the Soviet Union and Yugoslavia were all given a ``special guest status.'' The council requires that its candidate members be parliamentary democracies. The Soviet Union does not yet meet that requirement. The council's goal is to expand into an organization that unites all of Europe and North America in a single security structure. To that effect, the council is seeking to become the home of a parliamentary assembly of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe that groups the United States, Canada and 32 European nations. The other Council of Europe members are Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Iceland, Ireland, Italy, Liechtenstein, Luxembourg, Malta, the Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, San Marino, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and Britain.

DOC.HEAD: Sandinistas Launch New International Airline in Nicaragua
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with other Nicaraguan carrier, details, minor editing. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Sandinista investors announced Wednesday the formation of a new international airline, highlighting the group's switch from the revolutionary to the entrepreneurial after a decade of beating up on big business. Central American Airlines will start flying the Miami-Managua route on Oct. 27 for $275 roundtrip, the lowest fare between the two cities among carriers serving the region. The ticket is to include free cocktails. At a news conference, Herty Lewites, the former tourism minister under the Sandinistas, said, ``The Sandinista Front has zero (investment) in this company.'' But a journalist from Cuba's state Prensa Latina news agency quipped, ``I don't think even Herty's grandmother believes that.'' Insiders involved with the airline say Sandinista party investment is as high as 25 percent. Lewites established the only money-making state enterprises in Nicaragua during the Sandinista era, earning the nickname of Commander Dollar. Top investors in the airline include Lewites, former Sandinista Finance Minister William Hupper and Xavier Chamorro, a relative of President Violeta Chamorro. Lewites said 68 percent of the airline is locally owned and 32 percent by ``Saudi Arabians and Greek Arabs,'' and that the initial investment has been $1 million. ``The Sandinista Front (commonly known by its Spanish initials FSLN) will not be able to get to power again by way of arms, but by votes, and elections cost a lot of money,'' Lewites said. ``I'm going to give (the Front) as much as I can.'' Nicaragua's next presidential elections are scheduled for 1996. Mrs. Chamorro and a 14-party coalition ended a decade of Sandinista rule in Feb. 25 elections. The Miami-Managua route, the only one the airline will fly for its first three months, will use a Boeing 727 rented for $35,000 a month from a U.S. company, Lewites said. The company is planning to buy its own commercial jet next February. Plans also include flights to Los Angeles and San Francisco, Mexico City, Madrid, Spain, and London. After the Sandinista's election loss the United States lifted the 1985 trade embargo against Nicaragua. U.S. airlines that fly to Nicaragua or plan to include American, Pan Am and Continental. Regional airlines with Miami-Managua service include Aviateca, the Guatemalan carrier; Lacsa, the Costa Rican airline; and Sahsa, from Honduras. There is a state domestic airline, Aeronica, which also flies to Miami and to most of Central America. The new airline, called CAAL for its Spanish initials, is among many private enterprises the Sandinista Front and its militants have started after the electoral defeat. The Sandinistas led the long struggle that overthrew the late President Anastasio Somoza in July 1979. Many of their leaders espoused Marxist ideology and had trained in communist countries. The leftist policies and a U.S.-sponsored guerrilla war destroyed the economy, leading to voters casting their ballots for the more conservative coalition led by Mrs. Chamorro.

DOC.HEAD: Season's First Snowstorm Hits Northern Plains
DOC.TEXT: A low-pressure system moving across the upper Mississippi Valley brought snow to Minnesota and the Dakotas on Wednesday, and showers and thunderstorms to northern Wisconsin and Upper Michigan. Snow fell over northern and western Minnesota and the Dakotas, with snowfall totals of 4 to 8 inches expected, and up to 12 inches of snow possible near Lake Superior. Strong wind circulated around the storm system crossing the upper Mississippi Valley, reducing visibility in blowing snow. North Dakotans battled sloppy, slippery roads in their first dose of winter-like weather. Barnes County authorities advised no travel in the Valley City area when gusty north wind and snow kept visibility near zero. ``We've had about four semi accidents and three or four car accidents, and numerous cars in the ditch with no damage so we really didn't count those,''said Dan Anderson, Barnes County Sheriff's dispatcher. In South Dakota, some meetings were canceled in the Mobridge area, and two schools closed early. Classes offered by Standing Rock College of Fort Yates, N.D., were called off in Mobridge. Thunderstorms over northern Wisconsin produced dime-size hail south of Berlin during the morning. And before the snow moved in, thunderstorms over northeastern Minnesota that produced hail an inch in diameter at Cloquet. Showers and thunderstorms over Upper Michigan produced 0.97 inch of rain during the six hours up to 7 a.m. A line of thunderstorms developed from eastern Iowa to northeastern Oklahoma. Strong northwesterly wind blew were over the central high Plains region during the night, gusting to 74 mph in northeastern Colorado at Grover and to 65 mph in southeastern Wyoming. Showers and thunderstorms associated with a warm front were scattered from eastern Texas and eastern Oklahoma through the central Gulf Coast region to the Florida Peninsula during the afternoon. A storm system over the Pacific Ocean spread rain and strong wind toward Washington state and toward the southern panhandle of Alaska. Afternoon temperatures were only in the 30s from the northern half of the high Plains region to northern Minnesota. Wednesday's low for the Lower 48 states was 7 above zero at West Yellowstone, Mont.

DOC.HEAD: Troops in Gulf Getting Pretzels, Pound Cakes, Near-Beer
DOC.TEXT: There's no home cooking in the Saudi desert for American GIs, but some are now enjoying the familiar tastes of cookies, cakes and Kool-Aid. The treats are courtesy of American companies and individuals who have donated a wide variety of food, drinks, games, exercise equipment and other goods. They're being shipped to the Arabian desert by the Pentagon's Defense Logistics Agency. Among the food items donated: 20,000 three-ounce bags of pretzels from Atlanta; 400 bushels of apples from Albany, N.Y.; 150,000 boxes of cookies from Reading, Calif.; 50,000 cans of sardines from Prospect Harbor, Maine, and 12,500 pound cakes from Hileah, Fla. To wash the goodies down: 2,000 cases of near-beer, 11,000 cases of Gatorade and 47 tons of juices. Also making the 7,000-mile trip to Saudi Arabia are 1,000 pairs of dumbbells from Opelika, Ala.; 1,000 high-visibility footballs from Chicago, and 1,000 flying rings and boomerangs from Palo Alto, Calif. Among the most ambitous mailings was a donation by the Chicago-based retailer Montgomery Ward of 450 video cameras, along with blank recording tapes and return mail envelopes to enable soldiers to give the folks back home a picture of life in Operation Desert Shield. People or companies wishing to send items to the troops in the Middle East should call the Defense Logistics Agency, which determines whether the goods are acceptable and arranges for shipment of approved items directly to Saudi Arabia. The agency screens donations through a special hotline phone number, 703-274-3561.

DOC.HEAD: Consumer Groups Urge Boycott of Cars Without Air Bags
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf: The figure etc., to insert Toyota's ratio
DOC.TEXT: Three auto consumer groups asked Americans on Wednesday to refuse to buy any car not equipped with air bags. They chastised most Japanese automakers for lagging behind U.S. and European counterparts in plans to install the crash-protection devices. Chrysler, which is providing drivers' air bags in virtually all of its 1991 cars, drew a limited salute from the three groups, Motor Voters, the Center for Auto Safety, and the U.S. Public Interest Research Group. But even Chrysler was faulted for not equipping its popular minivans with air bags, and for not moving more quickly to make them standard equipment for front-seat passengers in cars. The three consumer organizations staged news conferences and demonstrations in 12 cities to propose the boycott, and focused their ire on Japanese economy models. Rosemary Dunlap, president of Motor Voters, noted that many automakers equip their luxury vehicles with air bags, but not the lower-priced ones, claiming the $320 devices would drive away bargain hunters. But Chrysler, she noted, has several economy models - variations of the Dodge Shadow and Plymouth Sundance - with driver air bags as standard equipment. ``If Chrysler can put air bags in a car for under $8,000, what's Honda's excuse for leaving them out of the Civic CRX, which costs over $11,000?'' she asked. Honda has announced it will make air bags standard equipment in all cars in 1994. Currently, the only Honda-built car sold in the United States with air bags is the top-of-the-line Acura Legend, retailing for over $20,000. According to industry projections for the current model year, 45 percent of Ford's cars and 33 percent of General Motors' cars will be sold with at least a driver air bag. Six companies, BMW, Isuzu, Mercedes-Benz, Porsche, Saab, and Volvo, equip all their U.S. cars with air bags, while five others - Hyundai, Peugeot, Suzuki, Sterling and Yugo - have no such models. The figure for Toyota is 27 percent, for Nissan 20 percent, for Mazda 15 percent, and for Mitsubishi, 1 percent. As of this year, federal law required all cars to be equipped with front-seat ``passive restraints'' - meaning either air bags or motorized shoulder harnesses. The exception is that if a driver air bag is installed, the automaker is free to wait until 1994 to equip the same model with a passenger bag. Meanwhile, that car can be marketed with normal seat and shoulder beats on the passenger's side. ``The Japanese auto industry's three-year delay in installing air bags condemns over 7,500 Americans to death and another 125,000 to serious injury,'' said Clarence Ditlow, director of the Center for Auto Safety. ``Air bags are lifesavers - there is no good reason why consumers should be forced to choose between safety and economy,'' said Lucinda Sikes, an attorney for U.S. PIRG. ``We are calling ... for air bags in economical as well as luxury models; for the front seat passenger as well as the driver; and in light trucks and minivans as well as passenger cars.''

DOC.HEAD: 200,000 Paperbacks for the Troops
DOC.NOTE: Eds: HarperCollins in 4th graf is correct
DOC.TEXT: The Association of American Publishers announced plans Wednesday to send more than 200,000 paperbacks to Operation Desert Shield forces in the Persian Gulf. They titles will run the gamut from mysteries to adventure tales and techno-thrillers, the association said. Jack Hoeft, chairman of the trade group's paperback publishing division, said paperbacks have been a link with home for U.S. servicemen overseas since World War II, when 130 million specially printed Armed Services Editions were sent to U.S. fighting forces. The books are being contributed by Avon, Ballantine, Bantam, Berkley, Dell, HarperCollins, Penguin USA, Pocket Books, St. Martin's Press, Warner and Zebra Books and should begin reaching U.S. troops by early November. About half of the paperbacks will be put in ``Oasis Packages'' being prepared by the United Services Organizations. These are gym bags which will also include writing paper, audio cassettes and sunglasses. The rest will be distributed by the Defense Department to troops already in the Persian Gulf and to those embarking for service there.

DOC.HEAD: East German Secret Police Said To Have Perpetrated Big Scam
DOC.TEXT: Former East German secret police are responsible for a scam that raked in $2 billion from the two Germanys' July 1 monetary union, the newspaper Sueddeutsche Zeitung reported Wednesday. The newspaper, which cited Berlin Justice State Secretary Wolfgang Schomburg as its source, telexed its report to other news organizations in advance of Thursday's publication. The fraud scheme was first revealed on Tuesday. Officials said then that four people were arrested for allegedly bilking the Bonn government of $333 million by falsifying trade accounts to qualify for a conversion of transfer rubles into German marks. The German mark became East Germany's official currency on July 1. The Sueddeutsche Zeitung, with headquarters in Munich, quoted Schomburg as saying the actual amount that was swindled is closer to $2 billion. He also said that three of the four suspects belonged to a ``special detail'' of the now-disbanded Stasi secret police, the daily reported. Government officials believe the fraud started after suspects presented the German Foreign Trade Bank in Berlin with false documents purportedly showing exports of East German goods to East European nations. That apparently qualified the suspects to receive a special rate for converting transfer rubles into German marks.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Passes Bill To Pay Reparations to Seneca Indians
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to CORRECT day of vote to Tuesday, sted Wednesday
DOC.TEXT: The Senate has passed a bill directing the government to pay $35 million to the Seneca Indians, admitting that Congress wrongly forced the tribe to lease its land for 115 years to the city of Salamanca, N.Y. ``We took advantage of the Seneca Nation and now we ought to correct this injustice,'' said Sen. Daniel P. Moynihan, D-N.Y., who introduced the bill in the Senate along with Sen. Alfonse D'Amato, R-N.Y. The Senate passed the measure by voice vote late Tuesday. The bill, originally sponsored by Rep. Amo Houghton, R-N.Y., passed the House on Oct. 10. Administration officials, however, have said the government is not financially liable for the low rents paid to the Senecas and they oppose the measure because of its cost. President Bush has 10 days in which to sign it, veto it or simply allow it to pass into law unsigned. The bill would ratify an agreement reached by Salamanca, three nearby villages and the Seneca Nation to replace a 99-year lease accord expiring Feb. 19, 1991. The lease arrangements date to the 1860s and '70s, when whites moved onto Seneca lands in western New York to work on railroads and drill for oil. They leased the land at extremely low rents from individual Senecas. In 1875, Congress confirmed these leases, despite their dubious legality. Fifteen years later, Congress extended the leases for 99 years with no provision to raise the rents. Thus, about 85 percent of the city of Salamanca is leased from the Senecas, at rents that were frozen as low as $1 per year. Under the bill, the federal government would pay $35 million to the tribe to make up for some of its financial loss. The state of New York must also pay $25 million, which will require state legislation.

DOC.HEAD: Rare Stamps To Be Turned Over To United Germany
DOC.NOTE: Eds; CORRECTS dates in 2nd graf to 1851-1852, picks up 3rd graf prv ``This is...''
DOC.TEXT: Eight valuable postage stamps that have been locked in a vault for 14 years because East and West Germany both claimed ownership will be turned over to the united government, the Customs Service said Wednesday. The stamps, which are worth more than $1 million, include 1847 issues from Mauritius, four Hawaii missionary stamps from 1851-1852 and two from British Guiana (Guyana). ``This is, 3rd graf prv

DOC.HEAD: Cambridge Celebrates with Three Nobel Winners
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Stands for UNDATED story listed on AM-News Digest.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Nobel-Science, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Harvard Professor Elias James Corey cracked open his fortune cookie at a Chinese restaurant last week and read the good news: ``You will soon receive a high prize or award.'' Wednesday, the news materialized via a graduate student: He had won the Nobel Prize in chemistry. A few miles down the Charles River, two scientists at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology on Wednesday learned they had won the award in physics. Corey, a Harvard professor since 1959, won for work in organic synthesis. His experiments helped make hundreds of medications more readily available and affordable. Jerome I. Friedman and Henry W. Kendall, both of MIT, won for proving the existence of quarks, particles smaller than a proton or a neutron. They shared the award with Richard E. Taylor, a Canadian scientist at Stanford University in California. The three had delved into the heart of the atom in experiments conducted at the Stanford Linear Accelerator Center in the late 1960s and early '70s. Each Nobel is worth about $700,000. At Harvard, young chemists popped open beer cans and applauded Corey as he emerged from his office Wednesday morning. ``It never occurred to me I'd be a professor,'' the 62-year-old son of Lebanese immigrants told a news conference. ``One's expectations were not very high. Of course, I never would have dreamed I would be so successful.'' But MIT Professor John Sheehan knew Corey was headed for greatness. ``He was an excellent student,'' Sheehan said. ``He had a little something special, something extra.'' The three physicists were recognized for work that has helped scientists understand the basic structure of the universe. Their experiments with the atom and its smaller components have given scientists ``a better understanding of the way the world is put together,'' said Eugene Mollove, a MIT science writer. The discovery became the basic model of particle physics. ``As human beings, we have great curiosity about how nature works,'' said Friedman, 60, who lives in the Boston suburb of Brookline. ``Knowing the structure of matter ultimately has to have some effect on how you model the entire structure of things.'' Friedman learned of the award when his wife woke him with the news. ``I thought I was still asleep and dreaming,'' he said from a hotel in Fort Worth, Texas, where he was attending a conference. Friedman stepped down as head of the MIT physics department this year to pursue teaching and research. Kendall joked that it was ``very civilized'' of the Nobel committee to phone him with the news at 5 a.m. He said the work was done during the ``golden age'' of governmental subsidies for science. ``It was done 20 years ago, so I found it delightful and unexpected,'' Kendall said. Kendall, 63, who lives in the Boston suburb of Sharon, has been chairman of the Union of Concerned Scientists since 1973. The group has opposed weapons such as the B-2 stealth bomber and called for more safety precautions at nuclear power plants. ``He's a rare breed of scientist who's been able to come out of the laboratory and work quite vigorously for the benefit of humankind,'' said Howard Ris, the union's executive director. ``Isn't it wonderful for once when two guys who weren't working to get it'' got the prize, said Martin Deutsch, an emeritus professor at MIT. ``They did their work because they wanted to know about the world.'' Taylor, contacted at his Stanford, Calif., home Wednesday morning, said he was surprised to hear the group had received the prize. Taylor, 60, was born in Medicine Hat, Alberta, is a Stanford University professor. Taylor said he was asleep when he got the good news in a telephone call about 4 a.m.: ``One thing that's remarkable is how little you say when the conversation starts with the secretary of the academy in Sweden.''

DOC.HEAD: Group Burns Order on Courthouse Steps
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of the anti-abortion group Operation Rescue burned a court order on the steps of the U.S. Courthouse on Wednesday, accusing the judge who signed it of violating their constitutional rights. U.S. District Judge Louis Oberdorfer ruled Oct. 4 that any organization or individual that pays the bills of Operation Rescue is liable for fines resulting from anti-abortion protests that violate a permanent injunction the judge issued earlier this year. Oberdorfer issued the order after attorneys for the National Organization for Women and Planned Parenthood of America produced evidence that Operation Rescue kept donations in bank accounts of allied organizations. Randall Terry, the group's leader, called Oberdorfer's latest order ``a frontal assault on freedom of association.'' ``The judge is in the hip pocket of the abortion industry,'' Terry said. In July, Oberdorfer had held Operation Rescue and several of its organizers in contempt of a preliminary injunction that prohibited demonstrators from blocking the entrances to local abortion clinics during protests last November. Oberdorfer made the injunction permanent in January. Operation Rescue has been the subject of numerous court injunctions around the country barring anti-abortion protesters from interfering with the operation of abortion clinics. For violating Oberdorfer's injunction, the group was ordered to pay $6,013 in damages to three local abortion clinics, plus attorneys' fees, which have tentatively been set at $42,000. As a result of Oberdorfer's latest order, Terry vowed to take the organization ``underground'' by closing its national headquarters in Binghamton, N.Y., and its bank accounts. ``We will keep doing everything that we are doing,'' Terry said, but the group will function ``without a national office that just sits there as a target for these harassing lawsuits.'' ``We will become a moving target,'' he said. Terry also invited supporters to attend three days of anti-abortion protests in the nation's capital Nov. 15-17 that he called ``D.C. Project II.'' Terry declined to say if protesters would block the entrances to abortion clinics, as they did during last year's ``D.C. Project.'' But the leaflet distributed by Operation Rescue referred to ``child-saving activity.'' NOW's attorney, Laurence J. Eisenstein, said: ``There is no doubt these same people who were held in contempt once, intend to be held in contempt again.'' ``It is clear they intend to engage in the hiding of assets which this order is meant to prevent,'' Eisenstein said. Patricia Ireland, the executive vice president of NOW, replied in a statement that ``with his penchant for martyrdom, Randall Terry would like the courts and the press to believe that Operation Rescue has been crippled by unjust fines.'' ``Today's showboating is yet another attempt to duck the group's responsibility for repeat violations of the law,'' Ireland said. ``They are playing shell games with their assets in an attempt to avoid vines that they do not wish to pay.'' Eisenstein said he had produced evidence in civil depositions that money donated to Operation Rescue had been turned over to the Pro-Life Trust Fund. Other donations had been given on Operation Rescue's behalf to the Committee to Protect the Family Foundation, which Eisenstein said has paid at least $80,000 of the group's bills this year. Much of the $43,500 that was put in a Pro-Life Trust bank account earlier this year, was in the form of checks made out to Operation Rescue and endorsed by Terry, Eisenstein said.

DOC.BYLINE: Walesa Campaigns in Krakow, Given Honorary Citizenship ^By ANDRZEJ STYLINSKI
DOC.TEXT: Solidarity leader Lech Walesa appeared to upstage his presidential rival Wednesday when he campaigned in Tadeusz Mazowiecki's home turf and was greeted by larger crowds than met Mazowieki a few days earlier. Traveling to southern Poland from his home in the Baltic city of Gdansk, the Solidarity leader told crowds at several stops that after battling to end Communist rule, he was ready to help build a capitalist future. ``As I was able to overcome communism together with you, now I am inviting you to help with building,'' Walesa told about 20,000 cheering supporters in the market square. Mazowiecki and Walesa were allies in Solidarity, the movement that drove the Communists from power. But Walesa began to complain shortly after Mazowiecki became prime minister in 1989 that he wasn't moving fast enough. Walesa decided to run for president, and after Communist President Wojciech Jaruzelski agreed to step down this fall, Mazowiecki announced he would run against Walesa. The election is Nov. 25. In his stop Wednesday, Walesa gave crowds in the medieval city what they wanted to hear: he would clean up grimy historic monuments to try to restore the beautiful stonework and sculptures. Speaking at the Sendzimir Steel Mill in Nowa Huta - formerly the Lenin Steel Mill - he told workers their inefficient, polluting plant might have to close. But alternative jobs must be found, he said. ``Everyone must stop and think, because 28,000 people are employed here,'' said Walesa. ``Those 28,000 people must have jobs. Let's sit down and find something. I don't believe there is no solution.'' Mazowiecki edited the Krakow-based monthly Wiez for decades and is linked to the progressive Catholic Znak publishing house in Krakow. But Walesa, arriving in the city three days after Mazowiecki kicked off his campaign here, appeared to receive at least one crowd that was much larger than the one that sent off Mazowiecki. At his hour-long market-square rally, Walesa was applauded after virtually every answer offered to the questions shouted from the crowd. Walesa also held a 30-minute meeting with Krakow intellectuals at the National Museum, and appealed for their support. Leading Polish intellectuals have largely deserted his worker-based union and rallied around Mazowiecki. ``Passing through the city, I felt the strength of workers and here I want to feel the strength of your minds. I want to be wise with your wisdom and strong with your strength,'' he said. Earlier, Walesa was feted at the town hall, where banners announed ``I prefer Lech,'' and was made an honorary citizen of the city. Krakow was Poland's capital until the end of the 16th century. Spared by World War II's devastation, its medieval monuments include the Wawel castle and cathedral with the tombs of kings, queens and national heroes. But pollution from the industrial Silesia region and the Nowa Huta mill - built by the Communists in the 1950s as part of a crash industrialization program - have corroded and begrimed the old monuments. Walesa also lay flowers at a simple monument in Nowa Huta for Bogdan Wlosik, a teen-age protester allegedly beated to death by police in 1982, when Poland's Communist government had imposed martial law.

DOC.HEAD: Havel Forces Czechoslovakia's Defense Minister to Quit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with CTK quote on civilian needed for defense post, Vacek's TV comments, details. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: President Vaclav Havel relieved Defense Minister Miroslav Vacek of his duties on Wednesday and temporarily entrusted the defense portfolio to the prime minister, the state CTK news agency said. Vacek, 55, a career soldier and longtime Communist Party member, had served as deputy defense minister under former Communist Premier Ladislav Adamec. Wednesday's terse report gave no details or reasons for Havel's decision, but it quoted Parliament deputy Michael Kocab as saying the president realized it was ``high time'' for a civilian to head the Defense Ministry. Havel's office declined comment. Interim defense duties were transferred to Premier Marian Calfa. Vacek later said on national television: ``I fully agree that it is suitable that I resign.'' But he added that ``the reservations some people had toward my person do not contribute to the peace and atmosphere necessary for carrying out complex changes, above all in the economic sphere.'' After thanking Havel for supporting him through his nearly 11-month tenure, Vacek urged Czechoslovaks to change their attitude toward the army. ``If you cannot love it, then as a start, at least abandon the grudge,'' he said. Vacek played a major role in forming the coalition ``government of national understanding'' under Calfa after Czechoslovakia's peaceful revolution last November. It was the first government here in 41 years not dominated by Communists. Vacek was appointed defense minister on Dec. 3, 1989, and left the Communist Party three months later. ``The president voiced his appreciation that army Gen. Miroslav Vacek did not permit the abuse of the army against the people by anyone,'' CTK said, referring to the November revolution. But according to the agency, Kocab said Havel's decision was based on findings of a presidential commission set up on Sept. 10 to investigate military activities during the November revolution. The commission is expected to submit its report Thursday. Unconfirmed reports say the army was to have been used against the people who overthrew the Communist leadership through peaceful street demonstrations. CTK said Havel also expressed his appreciation that Vacek ``loyally fulfilled all orders and initiated the process of fundamental restructuring of the Czechoslovak army.'' Some politicians blasted Vacek's appointment as defense chief in the new coalition government in June, seeing him as an unnecessary holdover of Communist influence. A petition, signed by prominent student leaders, was circulated in Prague in recent weeks. It demanded Vacek's resignation and that of Calfa, also a former Communist party member. CTK quoted the petition as saying, ``There is no way to ignore the halfhearted nature of events over the last 10 months. . . . We demand that all state bodies be cleansed of those who lack the moral and professional qualities needed for executing their functions.'' Finance Minister Vaclav Klaus meanwhile urged cooperation from trade unions on his sweeping economic reforms, which begin on Jan. 1, CTK reported. Klaus, who plans a radical free-market reform of the ailing economy, warned workers and business against pursuing private interests at the cost of the general welfare of the community, the agency said. Czechoslovkia's economy, one of Europe's most developed between the wars, has been devastated by four decades of Communist central planning.

DOC.HEAD: No Deceit in Customer Switches from AT&T, MCI Tells Congress
DOC.NOTE: EDS: INSERTS grafs 5-6: ``But Merrill,'' with AT&T testimony
DOC.TEXT: An MCI official Wednesday denied that his company was deceiving consumers into switching their long-distance service from AT&T, saying AT&T was exaggerating consumer complaints. At a House hearing that featured continual verbal sniping between representatives of the two bitter rivals, MCI Communications Corp. Executive Vice President Eugene Eidenberg said MCI wouldn't risk its integrity for the sake of a few fraudulently gained customers. Eidenberg shrugged off claims by AT&T that 90,000 of its customers had been switched to another long-distance service against their will in the past six months. ``Much more common than the intentional switching by an inter-exchange (long-distance) carrier is a simple, honest mistake,'' Eidenberg told the House Government Operation subcommittee on government information, justice and agriculture. But Merrill Tutton, AT&T vice president of consumer services, cited an 86-year-old Connecticut woman who was asked to switch to MCI. Even though she said she told the telemarketing caller that her daughter handled her affairs, she was switched anyway, without her approval, Tutton said. ``Time and time again consumers are being switched without their authorization or consent,'' Tutton said. State and federal authorities and local phone companies have received tens thousands of complaints about unauthorized switching, particularly in the wake of recent advertising wars between MCI, AT&T and US Sprint. But Eidenberg said one family member may agree to a switch without the knowledge of another, or clerical errors may occur at local phone companies that process huge volumes of new phone orders and service changes each month. Customers sometimes switch and then change their minds. Eidenberg said AT&T was ``grossly exaggerating'' the problem, in which telephone marketing services call customers and ask them to authorize switching long-distance companies. He said unauthorized switching was a very small percentage of legitimate service changes. ``Do not be taken in by AT&T's self-interest in preserving its market share,'' Eidenberg told the subcommittee. But Rep. Bob Wise, D-W.Va., said the number of complaints probably was just the tip of the iceberg and that the problem, known as ``slamming,'' won't go away until state and federal regulators act. Federal rules now require only that the new long-distance companies be able to present, on demand from a local phone company, written authorization from a customer seeking a changeover. If a customer complains and a written notice cannot be produced, the company must pay to have the customer switched back to the original carrier. But Richard Firestone, the Federal Communications Commission's chief telephone regulator, testified that companies frequently switch customers back to the original carrier without even attempting to produce a written authorization. AT&T has asked the FCC to require written authorization in advance of any switch - a rule the FCC had in 1985 until long-distance companies, including AT&T, complained. MCI says customers won't switch if they have to sign something in advance and it is urging the FCC to establish standards and monitoring procedures for the telephone marketing companies, and for easy return to the original carrier. The National Association of Regulatory Utility Commissioners also said advance authorization would favor the incumbent.

DOC.HEAD: Former KGB Official Says Soviets Shot Wallenberg in 1947
DOC.TEXT: A former KGB official says he saw records indicating that Raoul Wallenberg, the Swedish diplomat who saved thousands of Jews during World War II, was executed at least 33 years ago, The Times of London said Wednesday. Oleg Gordievsky, whose new book is being serialized in The Times, said he saw the Wallenberg file in the archives of the Soviet security agency. Soviet officials tried to recruit Wallenberg shortly after the Red Army moved into Budapest in 1945, Gordievsky reportedly wrote in the book. When Wallenberg refused, he was taken to the Soviet Union and shot, ``not later than 1947,'' The Times reported. The Times has been serializing Gordievsky's book, ``KGB: The Inside Story of Its Foreign Operations from Lenin to Gorbachev,'' which was coauthored by Christopher Andrew. Gordievsky's account of Wallenberg's death was not included in the excerpts but reported in a short news story in Wednesday's editions. Soviet authorities said in 1957 that Wallenberg died in 1947 in Moscow's Lubyanka Prison. However, Wallenberg's relatives and other members of the Wallenberg Commission have pressed for investigations of reports that the diplomat was still alive. He would be 77 today if still alive. Members of the commission including Wallenberg's half-brother, Guy von Dardel, went to Helsinki, Finland, last month in the hope of pressing President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to discuss the case at their summit meeting. Swedish authorities have relayed reports to Soviet authorities that Wallenberg was seen in the 1950s and '60s, with less reliable reports of sightings continuing into the 1980s. The commission said last month Soviet authorities never looked into the prison's records, although in 1957 the Soviets said they had examined the records.

DOC.HEAD: New Study Says Racism Common Part of High School Student Life
DOC.TEXT: Many U.S. high school students experience racism in their schools and communities, and four of every 10 questioned for a survey released Wednesday admitted they harbor racial or religious prejudices. ``The survey shows that our children have learned how to hate,'' said Dr. Richard Lapchick, director of the Center for the Study of Sport in Society at Northeastern University. The national survey, conducted by Louis Harris and Associates, found 57 percent of 1,865 high school students questioned had witnessed or heard about a racial incident. Students in grades 10 through 12 in public, private and parochial schools responded to questionnaires between August 31 and September 18. Acts considered racially motivated included taunts, graffiti and violent acts against people of a particular religion or race, said Louis Harris, chairman of the polling company. The survey was conducted for Reebok International, Ltd., a Stoughton-based sports apparel ``This is something that is indigenous to most of the country,'' Harris said. The survey found 61 percent of the students surveyed in the South had knowledge of a racial act, compared with 58 percent in the West, 50 percent in the Midwest and 57 percent in the East. The highest occurrences of racism occurred in suburban areas at 60 percent, while inner cities averaged 57 percent. The study didn't provide statistics per city. It had a margin of error of plus or minus 3 percent. Harris said 25 percent of the students reported having been the target of racial confrontations with violent overtones, though not necessarily with actual violence. Blacks had the highest frequency at 70 percent, followed by Hispanics at 67 percent. Forty-seven percent said when confronted with a racial incident they would either join attackers or side against the group being attacked. But, ``one out of every two high school students say they're prepared to do everything they possibly can do to stop such incidents from developing, and to cut them off once they start,'' Harris said. Four in 10 students admitted harboring prejudices against other races or religious groups. ``The high numbers indicate that this is a crisis by any measure indeed,'' Harris said. ``It's a crisis that cries out for some constructive programs to attempt to ease tensions, and develop more tolerance and understanding among these young people themselves.''

DOC.HEAD: Wisconsin Prison Fugitive Captured in Canada
DOC.TEXT: Lawrencia Bembenek, who went from waiting tables at a Playboy Club to police work, to jail for killing her then-husband's ex-wife, was caught Wednesday in Canada three months after she fled prison here. The 31-year-old Ms. Bembenek didn't resist when she was arrested along with her fiance, Dominick Gugliatto, 34, in Thunder Bay, Ontario, said Constable Andrew Rozdolsky of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police. Police arrested the pair in a basement apartment following tips from callers who had seen the Bembenek case depicted on a television show, ``America's Most Wanted,'' Rozdolsky said. Ms. Bembenek was serving a life sentence for murder in the 1981 killing of Christine Shultz, the former wife of Ms. Bembenek's husband, Elfred Schultz, a Milwaukee police detective. They have since divorced. Popularly known as ``Bambi,'' Ms. Bambenek allegedly escaped July 15 from the Taycheedah Correctional Institute. She apparently made her getaway by crawling through the window of a basement laundry room and jumping a 7-foot barbed wire fence, authorities said. The former model from Milwaukee has lot of sympathy in her hometown. Many people believe she is innocent of the killing. Her flight from prison inspired a Milwaukee mini-industry of ``Run Bambi Run'' T-shirts, bumper stickers and cutouts of the former model. Rallies were held wishing her well as a fugitive. Once a waitress at the now-defunct Playboy club in Lake Geneva, Wis., Ms. Bembenek joined the Milwaukee police force in the late 1970s. She was fired from the department in 1980 for lying about a friend's marijuana arrest. A year later she was arrested for killing Mrs. Schultz. It was Christine Schultz's two young sons who found her in her bed, bound, gagged and shot in the back. A jury convicted Ms. Bembenek of murder despite testimony from one of the victim's sons that the person seen in the house the night of the killing was not Ms. Bembenek. Ms. Bembenek has failed so far in attempts to get a new trial. Ms. Bembenek and Gugliatto, who worked in a lawn-mower factory, were being held in a Thunder Bay jail on charges of illegal immigration and set to appear in court Thursday. Fond du Lac County Sheriff James Gilmore said a Thunder Bay police detective interviewed Ms. Bembenek earlier Wednesday at the restaurant. Her only identification, a birth certificate, didn't check out, so police went to her apartment. They found Gugliatto outside with a car packed and the couple apparently ready to leave, Gilmore said. ``She obviously made a call - `pack up let's go.' The car was packed. They think it was probably five minutes'' before they would have fled, the sheriff added. Gilmore, the sheriff, said Wisconsin authorities didn't expect the couple to be returned to the state at least until next week and would let Canadian authorities complete deportation procedures first. Ms. Bembenek faces an escape charge that would tack on five years to the life sentence she was serving. At the time of her escape, she would have been eligible for parole in 1993. Prison officials had called her a model prisoner. Louis Kebezes operated the restaurant where Ms. Bembenek worked in Thunder Bay. ``She was an excellent waitress, an excellent person, very polite with the public,'' he told WITI-TV in Milwaukee. Schultz, who retired from the Milwaukee police force and is a homebuilder in Florida, said he was relieved to learn of his ex-wife's arrest. He has said he has feared for his safety since the escape. ``My family here in Florida is all very glad that she is is custody,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Bombs, Strikes Show Public Discontent with Austerity Measures
DOC.TEXT: President Carlos Menem signed a decree restricting strikes Wednesday and three small bombs exploded in an apparent protest against his harsh economic reform program. The decree, which penalizes unions staging wildcat strikes and allows workers to be fired without severance pay under certain conditions, came on the 45th anniversary of the foundation of the labor-based Peronist movement. Menem's opponents took the opportunity to note how far he had strayed from the populist Peronist program that got him elected. Socialist national deputy Simon Lazara called the decree ``terrible.'' ``Legally, it's an abuse. Politically, it's an illegitimite act. And the date which the decree is announced is an act of provocation,'' he said. The bombs caused no injuries and only minor damage to a Citibank branch, an office of the conservative Union of the Democratic Center, and a garbage truck that picked up a package at a government office. Police deactivated a bomb planted outside the office of Perez Compac, a shipping and banking company. No one claimed responsibility for the bombs. Citibank and Perez Companc are preparing to buy the state phone company as part of the government's privatization program. The union representing the company's 47,000 employees opposes the buyout, fearing it will lead to layoffs and cutbacks in wages and benefits. The Union of the Democratic Center, which finished third in the May 1989 voting that elected Menem, has strongly supported privatization. In defiance of other Peronist leader, Menem appointed several Democratic Center members to high office. To balance the budget and bring down inflation that topped 1,800 percent the past 12 months, Menem has fired public employees, severely restricted wages and put dozens of state companies up for sale. Many Peronists say his policies have betrayed the legacy of party founder Juan Peron, who created or nationalized many state companies during his 1946-55 presidencies. On Oct. 17, 1945, Peron was freed from prison after hundreds of thousands of workers protested on his behalf. The next year, he was elected president. Workers' right to strike is authorized in the constitution. But Menem decreed that ``essential services'' - such as water, electricity, hospitals, gas, phones, schools - may not be shut down by strikes. Union leaders said the decree is unconstitutional. ``The restriction of the right to strike and the economic program are like a person and its shadow because they support each other,'' said legislator Jesus Rodriguez of the Civic Radical Union, Argentina's second largest party. Saul Ubaldini, a strong opponent of Menem, was re-elected Wednesday to head a confederation of workers representing more than 1 million teachers, state workers and metalworkers. Ubaldini led the powerful, 3 million-member General Labor Confederation from 1980 until the federation split last October. Ubaldini led 13 general strikes against the 1983-89 government of Menem's predecessor Raul Alfonsin of the Radical Civic Union. Menem claims to be unconcerned about the growing opposition to his administration. ``Ubaldini ... can stage one or 1,000 strikes ... but the government won't change its path,'' Menem said before departing Wednesday on a 10-day trip to Italy, Poland and the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: British Wives Plan to Visit Husbands in Iraq
With AM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: British women who approach the Iraqi embassy for news of their husbands trapped in Iraq are being offered visas to travel there, Joanna Copley, a member of the Gulf Support Group, said Wednesday. She said she knew of two women who took up the offer of visas, ``although they may not actually go to Iraq.'' Some news reports said up to 15 British wives plan on going. The Foreign Office said Wednesday it advised British women not to go to Iraq. ``We believe this is simply a cynical propaganda ploy,'' a spokesman said, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``It is also very dangerous.'' Western men have been kept from leaving Iraq and occupied Kuwait since the Aug. 2 invasion, but hundreds of women and children have been allowed to go home. Ms. Copley said the Gulf Support Group, set up to help families of those trapped in the Persian Gulf, was also advising women not to go to Iraq because they may not be allowed to leave again, and also because ``the Iraqis are bound to make propaganda out of it.'' She said if wives took money into Iraq they would be breaking United Nations sanctions imposed to protest the invasion. A man who answered the telephone at the Iraqi embassy would not comment on the visa offer.

DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS graf 4, ALCOHOL section, to clear garbles
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Budget-Taxes
DOC.TEXT: Here is a comparison of some provisions in the deficit-reduction bill passed by the House and a version being debated by the Senate: GASOLINE: No change in the House bill. The Senate would raise the 9-cent gasoline tax to 18{ cents per gallon by 1992 and the 15-cent diesel tax to 24{ cents. Neither bill would affect heating oil. INDEXING: The House would forgo for one year the annual adjustments to income tax brackets and personal exemptions, which are designed to protect against inflation-caused bracket creep. That would mean higher taxes each year in the future for all except the wealthiest people. The Senate has no such provision. ALCOHOL: House: Raise the $12.50-a-gallon tax on 100-proof liquor by $1, or 20 cents a fifth; double the beer tax to 32 cents a six-pack; raise taxes on most wines, including, for example, table wine, which would go from 3 cents a 750-milliliter bottle to 25 cents. Senate: Raise liquor $1.20; double beer; raise table wine to 21 cents. TOBACCO: Both would raise the 16-cent cigarette tax by 4 cents in 1991 an another 4 cents in 1993. Snuff, cigars and other tobacco would face 25 percent tax increases each year. FLYING: Both would raise the 8 percent tax on airline tickets to 10 percent, eliminating the drop to 4 percent that was scheduled to occur at the end of the year. TELEPHONES: The Senate would make permanent the 3 percent tax on local and long-distance phone service, which is due to expire Dec. 31. Not in the House bill. LUXURIES: Both would impose a 10 percent tax on the portion of the price of cars above $30,000; boats above $100,000; jewelry above $5,000; furs above $10,000 (House) or $5,000 (Senate), and private planes $100,000 (House) or $250,000 (Senate). TAX RATES: The House bill would raise the top rate paid by the wealthiest people, now 28 percent, to 33 percent. It would impose a 10 percent surtax on those with taxable incomes over $1 million. The Senate bill would do neither. The House, but not the Senate, would raise to 25 percent the 21 percent alternative minimum tax paid by some high-income people with large amounts of deductions that otherwise would reduce their tax liability to near zero. ITEMIZED DEDUCTIONS: The Senate would limit itemized deductions (except those for medical expense, casualty losses and investment interest) of people with adjusted gross income over $100,000. Only 95 percent of deductions would be allowed against the portion of income above $100,000. CAPITAL GAINS: The House bill would allow a person to avoid tax on half of up to $200,000 of capital gains earned in a lifetime; the gains could come from most investments but not from stocks. A person with annual income under $100,000 could avoid tax on another $1,000 a year of gains, including those on the sale of stock. No capital gain would be taxed at a rate above 28 percent. The Senate bill has no capital-gains provisions. LOW-INCOME: Both bills would increase the earned-income tax credit, which benefits low-income families with children, as a way of offsetting some of the increased excise taxes. The Senate plan also includes a major expansion of child-care benefits. MEDICARE TAXES: House would increase from $51,300 to $100,000 the maximum annual wage to which the 1.45 percent Medicare tax applies. The tax is withheld as part of the Social Security tax. The Senate would raise the limit to $89,000. The Senate would require all state and local government workers and their employers to pay the tax; the House would continue exempting workers hired before April 1, 1986. MEDICARE PREMIUMS: House would raise the $28.60 monthly premium for Medicare Part B insurance to $29.90 next year and $46.20 by 1995. Senate: $29.90 next year and $47.00 by 1995. MEDICARE DEDUCTIBLE: House would raise to $100 through 1995 the present $75 deductible which beneficiaries must pay before Medicare starts paying for doctor bills. Senate: $150 each year. SOCIAL SECURITY: Both would require all state and local government workers who are not covered by a public retirement plan to pay Social Security taxes. ENERGY INITIATIVES: The Senate bill earmarks $3.5 billion worth of incentives for increasing U.S. oil and gas exploration and production. The House does not. EXPIRING PROVISIONS: The Senate, but not the House, would extend through 1991 at a five-year cost of $5.5 billion 11 targeted tax breaks that are expiring. Principal beneficiaries include workers who receive tuition aid or group legal services from employers; businesses that hire the poor; investors in low-income rental housing; self-employed who buy their own health insurance; businesses that increase spending for research; and low-income people trying to buy a first home. CONTRIBUTIONS: The Senate, but not the House, would permit upper-income people subject to the alternative minimum tax to deduct the current value of an artwork donated to a museum. Present law allows them to write off only for the purchase price. BUSINESS: Both bills would raise taxes on life insurance companies by $8 billion. They would extend for five years an expiring 0.2 percent surtax that employers pay for unemployment insurance. Senate, but not House, would prohibit corporations from deducting interest paid on overdue taxes. MEDICAL DEDUCTIONS: The Senate, but not the House, would deny a medical expense deduction for cosmetic surgery unless prescribed to repair damage from an accident or a birth defect.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Envoy Says Iraq Could Show Flexibility
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's special envoy on the Persian Gulf crisis said Wednesday he remained optimistic that Iraq might show some flexibility to avert war. The envoy, Yevgeny Primakov, commented after a 45-inute meeting with President Francois Mitterrand. Primakov conferred Tuesday with Italian Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti in Rome and is to fly Thursdaty to Washington to meet President Bush and other American officials. ``I remain a prudent optimist,'' Primakov said after his talks with Mitterrand. ``I think the Iraqi position could still become more flexible.'' Primakov visited Baghdad earlier this month and met with leading Iraqi officials including President Saddam Hussein. In another development Wednesday, Defense Minister Jean-Pierre Chevenement informed the Cabinet that France's forces in the gulf were being reinforced, particularly its anti-tank capabilities. The Defense Ministry declined to give details of the reinforcements, but said the French force in Saudi Arabia now totaled about 5,000 men, up from the previously announced figure of 4,000.

DOC.HEAD: Paraguayan Legislator Seeks U.N. Poll Watchers
DOC.TEXT: A Paraguayan opposition leader asked Wednesday for the United Nations to send pollwatchers to May municipal elections to verify that the country has entered the path toward genuine democracy. Paraguay's U.N. mission said the government has not yet decided if it wants independent election monitors from the United Nations, Organization of American States, or other agencies. The May voting will be the first democratic mayoral election in the country's history, and could provide the opposition with the chance to strengthen its local organizations prior to the 1993 national elections. The Paraguayan military overthrew Gen. Alfredo Stroessner in February 1989 and promised a return to democracy. Stroessner had ruled since 1956. The vice president of Paraguay's Chamber of Deputies, Juan Manuel Benitez Florentin, met Wednesday with one of the U.N.'s chief officials for Central American affairs, Francesc Vendrell, to ask for the election observers.
