Benitez said Vendrell told him the Paraguayan government would have to make the request for observers, and make it forcefully enough to persuade other nations to fund the request and send poll watchers. Benitez said he stressed that it is essential there be ``cleanness and transparency'' in the local elections, or the public might become disenchanted with the political process. ``Our entire political structure is no different than it was under Stroessner,'' said Benitez, who is also president of the Authentic Radical Liberal Party, a leading opposition party. Stroessner was ousted by his second-in-command, Gen. Andres Rodriguez, who won a presidential election held only three months later. Rodriguez has pledged to turn over the government to an elected successor in 1993, but many are skeptical that the powerful army and the official Colorado Party will relinquish power.

DOC.HEAD: Yugoslav Defense Minister Denies Military Planning Coup
DOC.TEXT: A critical meeting of Yugoslavia's federal Parliament was postponed Wednesday and the defense minister denied a military coup was planned if the legislature remained split along ethnic lines. The postponment of the session until Friday, following a full day of procedural wrangling, was seen by most observers as a clear victory for the reform-minded republics of Croatia and Slovenia. The session was meeting to discuss whether Yugoslavia would remain a federation, which Serbia advocates, or a loose confederation, which Croatia and Slovenia back. The latest ethnic standoff had threatened to block the parliamentary session, sparking a constitutional crisis and deepening the political chaos menacing the country. The Parliament also voted 125 to 40 Wednesday to confirm Stipe Mesic as Croatia's new representative on the federal presidency. Serbian deputies earlier threatened to refused to seat Mesic, seen by many Serbs as a Croatian nationalist, as Croatia's member in the eight-member presidency. Croatian deputies reacted by warning they would walk out of Parliament. The Serbs were finally outvoted by a block of Slovenian, Croatian, Bosnian and Macedonian representatives. Rising tensions betwen Serbs and Croats before Wednesday's session sparked widespread rumors the army might seize power if Parliament couldn't agree on the future relationship of the six Yugoslav republics. Defense Minister Veljko Kadijevic described the rumors as ``nonsense.'' ``They are nothing but vulgar provocations,'' Kadijevic told The Associated Press after Wednesday's session. The respected weekly Danas in Zagreb on Monday quoted unidentified sources as saying a coup was one option that already had been discussed by top military officials. The army is multi-ethnic, but two-thirds of all officers are Serbs, and more than 90 percent are or were members of the federal Communist party. Vjesnik, the main daily in the republic of Croatia, called the Parliament session ``the last poker game'' in the lengthy power struggle over Yugoslavia's political future. Rising ethnic tensions already have resulted in clashes between Croatian police and Serbs in Croatia. A confederation plan advocated by Croatia and Slovenia, where center-right parties have ousted Communist governments in free elections, is vehemently opposed by communist-ruled Serbia. Borisav Jovic, the Serb who currently holds Yugoslavia's rotating presidency, is pushing a federal option that would keep power centralized in Belgrade. The presidency deadlocked over the issue last week and held stormy sessions Monday and Tuesday to try and forge a compromise. Janez Drnovsek, Slovenia's representative on the collective presidency, walked out of the meeting Tuesday to protest the stance of President Borisav Jovic, a Serb who holds the annually rotating chairmanship of the supreme body. The state news agency Tanjug on Wednesday published what it said was a plan for the future from the presidency, but the scheme seemed likely to draw support only from Serbia and the tiny republic of Montenegro. According to Tanjug, the plan foresees a bicameral Parliament, with one chamber elected on the principle of ``one man, one vote.'' Opponents say this would give Serbs, the largest ethnic group in Yugoslavia with about 9 million people, a dominant say in national affairs. The plan also foresees Yugoslavia remaining a federation and accords member states the right to decide the fate or existence of any provinces. That would give Serbia the right to abolish the province of Kosovo, an ancient Serbian region now dominated by ethnic Albanians.

DOC.HEAD: 35 Arrested as Peruvian Miners to Discuss National Strike
DOC.TEXT: About 35 miners were arrested Wednesday in Morococha in central Peru on the third day of a strike by Centromin workers. Miners decide this month whether to extend the strike throughout Peru, union leaders said. Two union leaders were among those arrested, said Jorge Quesada, chief of the National Federation of Miners and Metalworkers. The state-owned Centromin company said about 57 percent of its 12,000 blue-collar workers are striking. Most of the rest are set to walk out Thursday. The workers want a 250 percent raise in their $3.50 daily wages, the federation said. Union leaders said they will meet Oct. 25-27 to discuss whether to call a national strike. Besides raises, strikers would demand that mining companies recognize the federation as the miners' sole representative in collective bargaining. Centromin produces most of Peru's silver and is the country's second-top producer of copper. State railway workers stayed off the job for a third day Wednesday. The railway handles 96 percent of Centromin's mineral shipments.

DOC.HEAD: Fort D to Symms. FYI debate continues and timing of votes is uncertain
DOC.TEXT: Senate leaders Wednesday night scrambled for support for a $250 billion deficit-reduction plan that would double gasoline taxes, cut Medicare benefits and mildly boost income taxes on the wealthy. The measure includes a broader-based tax increase than the soak-the-rich House version that President Bush has said he will veto. Democratic and Republican leaders spent much of the day trying to line up enough votes to defeat what they called a killer amendment that would strip the gasoline tax boost from the measure. The amendment by Sen. Steve Symms, R-Idaho, would cost nearly $43 billion in revenues over five years. ``We're either going to come out of this exercise with a $500 billion deficit-reduction package, or with nothing,'' warned Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine. As debate began, Democratic Budget Committee Chairman James Sasser, D-Tenn., said, ``We tell the American people that there will be some sacrifice in this package. But we tell them at the same time that it will be fair.'' And the White House said the Senate version could form the basis for ending the government's long budget stalemate. ``The White House is ready to receive the bipartisan package similar to the Senate package,'' said Bush's chief of staff, John Sununu. ``Get it to the president's desk and he'll sign it.'' The administration also saiil now, the president has tried to keep the pressure on by threatening to shut the government down unless Congress sends him a full budget he can accept. Without emergency legislation, federal authority to spend money expires at 12:01 a.m. Saturday. Acting one day after the Democrats pushed a bill much tougher on the rich through the House, Senate leaders chose to face Election Day just three weeks off with a proposal bearing all the marks of a political compromise. There would be limits on deductions for people with incomes exceeding $100,000, but no boost in tax rates for the rich as the House approved. The 9-cent-a-gallon gasoline tax would be doubled, but the earned-income tax credit for the poor would increase, too. The package would shave about $250 billion from the federal deficit over the next five years by raising $142 billion in new taxes and paring Medicare, farm support and other benefit programs. Savings in other bills - mainly defense cuts - would bring total deficit-reduction to about $500 billion, including $40 billion in the budget year that started Oct. 1. Bush had threatened to veto the House bill because of its increase in the upper bracket income tax rate. Though administration officials objected to some provisions in the Senate version, Sununu said in an interview on NBC-TV the president liked the compromise. Despite the plan's powerful supporters, the Senate's Democratic and Republican leaders spent the day defending their plan from lawmakers unhappy for regional or philosophical reasons. Western senators complained that the higher gasoline tax would be a severe blow to states such as theirs, where people routinely drive long distances. Others insisted that the bill's overall tax package was unnecessary, that spending should have been cut more deeply instead. ``Grab your wallets and run for cover because Congress is getting up a head of steam to raise your taxes,'' said Symms. Party leaders replied that with the economy teetering, everyone had to pull together. ``I believe the deficit of the United States is so serious that it isn't a Democratic issue or a Republican issue or the president's issue,'' said Sen. Pete Domenici of New Mexico, the budget panel's ranking Republican. ``The people want us to do something.'' The starkest contrast between the Senate and House bills was in how their pain would be distributed. The Senate measure would increase taxes on people earning more than $200,000 by 3.7 percent, exactly half the burden the House would impose. Those with incomes between $20,000 and $50,000 would see their tax bills jump by nearly 3 percent under the Senate plan but only about 1 percent with the House version. The Senate omitted the income tax increase from 28 percent to 33 percent that the House would impose on the wealthiest people. It also excluded the moderate break in capital gains taxes that the House would grant to middle-income people. Like the House-passed bill, the Senate version would increase taxes on alcohol, tobacco, fancy cars, private airplanes and boats, furs and jewelry. The Senate bill would gradually hoist the monthly premium Medicare recipients pay for doctors' coverage from $28.60 this year to $47 by 1995 - 80 cents higher than the House. The Senate would increase the annual deductible beneficiaries pay, now $75, to $150 next year, compared to the House's $100. The Senate would also raise the wage cap from which the 1.45 percent Medicare tax is deducted from all paychecks from $51,300 to $89,000. The House would push the cap to $100,000. Both bills would also reduce Medicare payments to doctors and hospitals, the Senate's cuts totaling $34 billion. And both would reduce support payments for farmers, student loans, and veterans' benefits. They would increase the 8 percent airline ticket tax by 25 percent. Lawmakers would also raise fees for federal services ranging from emissions testing of cars to bank insurance.

DOC.HEAD: Environmentalists Arrested After Smokestack Protest
DOC.TEXT: Five environmentalists who spent the night atop a pair of smokestacks climbed down and were arrested Wednesday, ending a protest staged to warn of mercury contamination from trash burning. ``We've made our point - we've made people aware,'' Greenpeace spokeswoman Jeanne Whalen said. The group blames the giant incinerators ringing the Everglades for high levels of mercury found in fish and wildlife. The three men and two women sneaked into the Pinellas County compound early Tuesday, scaled the 160-foot towers and unfurled banners reading ``Don't Burn Florida'' and ``Mercury is Rising.'' Sheriff's deputies arrested them on suspicion of trespassing and released them on bond. If convicted, each faces a maximum $1,000 fine ad up to a year in jail, said sheriff's spokeswoman Marianne Pasha. Plant manager Robert Stitz said the mercury emissions are within safe levels. The ininerator burns 3,000 tons of garbage daily and generates electricity.

DOC.HEAD: Briton Denies He was `Fifth Man' in Soviet Spy Ring
DOC.TEXT: A Briton accused of being the ``fifth man'' in a Soviet spy ring has characterized the allegations as false and a publicity stunt, a newspaper reported Wednesday. Le Monde, a leading French daily, said one of its reporters spoke by telephone with the accused spy, John Cairncross, at his home in southern France. Cairncross, 77, said excerpts from a book by a KGB defector accusing him of espionage were full of errors, Le Monde reported. Excerpts from the unreleased book were published this week in the Times of London ``It's nothing but a publicity campaign,'' Cairncross was quoted as saying. The book, ``KGB: The Inside Story of Its Foreign Operations From Lenin to Gorbachev'' by Christopher Andrew and Oleg Gordievsky, a former KGB official now living in Britain, says Cairncross worked for Moscow at the same time as spies Kim Philby, Guy Burgess, Donald Maclean and Anthony Blunt. The book says Burgess recruited Cairncross at Cambridge University. It alleges that Cairncross, while employed at the British Foreign Office, and at the electronic eavesdropping center, provided valuable information to Soviet intelligence. Cairncross was quoted by Le Monde as saying he knew Philby, Burgess, Maclean and Blunt because they were contemporaries of his at Cambridge University, but he did not know of their spying activities until after it was revealed in the press. The book also said Cairncross, after he was interrogated by the MI5 British counterintelligence service, confessed to passing documents to the Soviets. It was not clear from the Le Monde article whether Cairncross denied all espionage activity.

DOC.HEAD: Arab Ministers Confer on Jerusalem Killings
DOC.TEXT: The 21-member Arab League convened an emergency meeting Wednesday night at the request of the PLO to discuss responses to the killings of 19 Palestinians last week in Jerusalem. According to some sources, the PLO was asking Arab nations to raise $40 million to finance a general strike by Arab workers in Israel. The league includes the PLO and 20 Arab nations, seven of which sent their foreign ministers to the meeting. The others were represented by the their Tunis-based ambassadors to the league. The PLO has denounced Israel for refusing to allow a U.N. delegation to investigate the killings at Jerusalem's Temple Mount on Oct. 8. Police opened fire after Palestinians threw stones at Jews at the nearby Western Wall, or Wailing Wall.

DOC.HEAD: City Impoverished But Proposed Budget Would Double Mayor's Salary
DOC.TEXT: The mayor of this impoverished city has proposed 1991 and 1992 budgets that would more than double his salary and those of other elected municipal officials. But Mayor Carl E. Officer said the proposals shouldn't be taken too seriously because they will be revised extensively. ``I don't want anyone to take the figures we submitted overly serious. It needs a lot of work,'' he said. Alderman Percy McKinney was one of those who didn't take it very seriously. ``Sometimes you have to take a reality break,'' he said. ``This is totally outlandish. We simply cannot afford that.'' East St. Louis faces a debt estimated at $47 million. The city has had trouble meeting its employee payroll and maintaining municipal services. A judge recently gave away City Hall to pay a court award to a man who sued the city. The man sold the property, and the city has appealed the judge's original ruling. A $34 million bailout bill passed this summer by the Illinois General Assembly created a state panel to oversee the city's finances. Under the Distressed Cities Act, municipal officials had to submit the budgets to the East St. Louis Financial Advisory Authority by Monday. Officer met the deadline when he submitted the two plans. ``The plans were not detailed. All I was simply trying to do was comply with the statute,'' Officer said. Officer's salary under the 1991 budget would increase 107 percent, increasing from $30,000 to $62,366. It would go up to $65,484 the following year. Treasurer Charlotte Moore's salary would jump from $25,000 to $51,900 in 1991. The salary for that office would then increase to $54,500 in 1992. City Clerk Alzada Carr would get a $24,200 raise in 1991; her salary would increase from $22,500 to $46,700. A public hearing on the proposals is scheduled for Oct. 30.

DOC.HEAD: Refugees Say Car Bombs Used by Kuwaiti Resistance
DOC.TEXT: Kuwaiti refugees arriving at this border crossing Wednesday said two car bombs exploded a day earlier at a Kuwait City traffic circle traversed by Iraqi soldiers and their families. The refugees, most of them families who left their country in large, late-model cars, were arriving at this border post in a steady trickle, about one car every 10 to 15 minutes. They repeated accounts from earlier refugees of Iraqi soldiers invading Kuwaiti homes in the middle of the night, taking away family members for questioning and stripping entire neighborhoods of everything they could carry. ``They are Ali Baba and the 40 thieves,'' said Abdul Karim, a consulting engineer who crossed the border Wednesday with a colleague. ``I have never seen a ragtag army like this one,'' he said, speaking in English. ``The Iraqi soldiers are looting, the Iraqi civilians are looting, and then looters are looting the looters.'' Karim and his colleague, engineer Abdul Aziz, said they reached the scene of a booby-trap car bomb explosion Tuesday, just minutes after it happened at a traffic circle heavily traveled by Iraqis going to and from Iraq. They said three cars were destroyed and they were told there had been casualties, although they did not see any. The two men said the explosion was the second they heard during the day, but they had no details on the other blast. Some refugees have described continuing armed resistance by the Kuwaiti underground, although the government-in-exile has said it was scaling down the resistance to avoid reprisals by the Iraqis against the remaining population. After invading Kuwait on Aug. 2, Iraqi President Saddam Hussein declared it Iraq's 19th province and began attempting to colonize the country with Iraqis, according to accounts form the country. The estimated 430,000 Iraqi soldiers and civilians in Kuwait are said to outnumber native Kuwaitis.

DOC.HEAD: Pakistan Government Hits Benazir Bhutto with Two More Charges
DOC.TEXT: The caretaker government that succeeded ousted Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto filed two additional cases of corruption against her on Wednesday, one week before national parliamentary elections. Some legal experts expressed doubt that any of the six cases against her, her husband and major members of her former government will be completed before the Oct. 24 voting. Special one-judge tribunals would hear the cases. A hearing was set for Oct. 20 by Justice Mohammad Amir Malik to determine whether the 37-year-old Ms. Bhutto should stand trial. There was concern in Pakistan that the United States and other Western countries would cut off millions of dollars in economic and military aid if Ms. Bhutto is disqualified from running. But U.S. influence here has become an election issue, and many fear she will be disqualified as a snub to Washington. President Ghulam Ishaq Khan dismissed her 20-month-old government on Aug. 6 as being so corrupt and incompetent it could not effectively govern this Moslem nation of 110 million people. Ms. Bhutto is challenging his decision in court. The new charges filed by the army-backed government accuse Ms. Bhutto of using hundreds of millions of dollars in secret service funds to buy political favors and of using government and military aircraft to carry supporters in Parliament during a no-confidence vote last year. Ms. Bhutto has denied any wrongdoing. If found guilty, one result could be her banishment from politics for seven years. At least seven former Bhutto Cabinet ministers have been charged with corruption before tribunals and more than 100 supporters in her Pakistan People's Party have been arrested. Ms. Bhutto's husband, Asif Ali Zardari, 38, is also accused in the abduction of a Pakistani-born British man last April and is in prison. His wife was allowed to visit him for two hours Wednesday, their first visit since he was arrested a week ago.

DOC.HEAD: Iranian Dissident Group Says Many Killed in Tehran Clashes
DOC.TEXT: An Iranian dissident group said Wednesday that moderates and radicals fought gunbattles last week in Tehran and there were a number of casualties. The Iraq-based Mujahedeen Khalq, or People's Holy Warriors, said in a statement telexed from its Paris office that members of an internal security committee fought with Revolutionary Guards, Iran's main military force, last Thursday, leaving ``many casualties on both sides.'' The statement, quoting sources in Tehran, said the shootings occurred in the capital's eastern Tehran-Pars district. It did not provide a death toll, but said there were no civilians among the dead. The statement added that in a similar clash last Wednesday, in northern Tehran, ``a number'' of fighters on both sides were wounded. The reports could not be independently confirmed. The statement from the Mujahedeen, Iran's largest opposition group, said the confrontations were between supporters of President Hashemi Rafsanjani, and his more radical opponents. The radicals, led by former Interior Minister Ali Akbar Mohtashemi, and Ahmad Khomeini, the son of Iran's late spiritual leader, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, are angered by their exclusion from elections to a key constitutional body this month. Sources in Tehran reported fistfights in the parliament, or Majlis, before the Oct. 8 elections, which hard-liners claim were rigged. The Revolutionary Guards are loyal to Rafsanjani, while the internal security committees back the radicals. Rafsanjani has been seeking to reestablish ties with the West and attract investment and technology to revive Iran's sluggish economy. The radicals believe Rafsanjani is straying from the ideals of Iran's Islamic revolution, which rejected ties with the West.

DOC.HEAD: Tribe Chairman, Son, Convicted in Bribery Trial
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 6-7 pvs bgng, `The younger...,' with 7 grafs to ADD potential penalty for younger MacDonald, UPDATE with reax from MacDonalds, ADD detail. Pick up 8th graf pvs: `The prosecution ....
DOC.TEXT: Suspended Navajo Chairman Peter MacDonald was convicted Wednesday of 41 counts of bribery and other crimes for taking money and favors from business people operating on the reservation. The same six-member tribal District Court jury convicted Peter ``Rocky'' MacDonald Jr., MacDonald's son and codefendant, of 23 similar counts. The prosecution contended MacDonald illegally asked for and accepted cash payments, loans, airplane rides and use of an automobile from businessmen seeking to curry favor. The defense argued during closing arguments Friday that MacDonald got the gifts through friendship, that he hadn't threatened the business people nor promised them anything in return. The elder MacDonald was convicted of 41 of 42 counts of bribery, conspiracy and ethics violations. Three counts against the 61-year-old former aerospace engineer were dismissed Friday. The younger MacDonald, an unemployed lawyer who lives in San Jose, Calif., was convicted of 23 counts of bribery, theft by extortion, ethics violation and conspiracy. Judge Robert Yazzie has said he would consolidates the counts. If he does, MacDonald would face a maximum of 10 years in prison. The elder MacDonald faces a maximum sentence of 21{ years in prison and a $21,500 fine. The conviction bars him from holding tribal office for four years. He is on the Nov. 6 ballot for tribe president, a post that replaced the chairmanship. Sentencings were set for Oct. 22. MacDonald's attorney said his client would appeal. Rocky MacDonald's lawyer said he probably would as well. Rocky MacDonald said he had no comment. But his father said the verdict was no surprise. ``All along I've said the prosecutor is snowjobbing the jury,'' MacDonald said. And as he left the courtroom, he said: ``I am the chairman of the Navajo Nation.'' About 180,000 Navajos live on the 21,100-square-mile reservation, which covers parts of Arizona, Utah and New Mexico. The prosecution called 23 witnesses before resting its case Friday. But defense attorney Val Jolley decided against calling any witnesses, arguing that the prosecution failed to prove its case. ``Their case is in a shambles. We don't have anything we have to defend,'' Jolley said Friday. ``The only time you have to present a defense is when a case is proven beyond a reasonable doubt.'' The trial is the first of three scheduled for the elder MacDonald in tribal court. MacDonald was placed on administrative leave in 1989 by the Tribal Council after allegations of corruption surfaced midway through his fourth four-year term. The father and son's second trial is scheduled to begin Oct. 23. It is on conspiracy charges stemming from the tribe's purchase of a ranch for $33.4 million from a company which paid $26.2 million for the property only five minutes earlier. The third trial, in which MacDonald faces 93 fraud counts stemming from the tribe's 1986 primary and general elections, is scheduled to begin Dec. 4. Suspended Vice Chairman Johnny R. Thompson is a co-defendant.

DOC.HEAD: Mitterrand Commemorates Liberation of Nazi Concentration Camps
DOC.TEXT: President Francois Mitterrand told 200 survivors of Nazi concentration camps on Wednesday they could find satisfaction in witnessing ``a truly new Europe'' where hope is replacing hate. The survivors came to the Elysee Palace from about 20 countries for a ceremony commemorating the 45th anniversary of the liberation of concentration camps by allied forces. ``Your reward is to be present for the birth of a truly new Europe ... without the domination of some over others,'' Mitterrand said. ``One can say, with precaution, that the time of hope is taking the place of the time of hate, even if there remains much to do to prevent new forms of exclusion, less spectacular but insidious, from developing.''

DOC.HEAD: Ethics Committee Hears Riegle
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 7th graf: ``In a,'' with committee statement
DOC.TEXT: Senate Banking Committee Chairman Donald Riegle attended a closed-door meeting Wednesday of the Senate Ethics Committee to discuss his relationship with indicted thrift owner Charles H. Keating Jr. Riegle, D-Mich., is one of five senators under scrutiny for their ties to Keating and his Lincoln Savings and Loan, which government regulators seized last year. The bailout, expected to cost taxpayers at least $2 billion, represents one of the costliest failures in U.S. banking history. The Michigan senator spent more than four hours in the committee room and returned to the Senate floor without seeing reporters. He issued a written statement saying, ``I welcomed the opportunity to meet directly with the Ethics Committee and review with them all the facts in this matter. I know my conduct was proper and I will await the judgment of the committee.'' The Ethics Committee chairman, Sen. Howell Heflin, D-Ala., declined to comment. The vice chairman, Sen. Warren Rudman, R-N.H., said only, ``We're through with the senators,'' indicating the committee planned no more interviews of the five senators. Earlier, committee member Sen. Trent Lott, R-Miss., told reporters the panel should be ready to vote this week on whether to continue investigating some or all of the five. In a statement issued later Wednesday night, the committee said it would begin ``a series of deliberative meetings'' on the matter Thursday. The committee said no statement would be issued ``until a decision has been made.'' The Ethics Committee has met separately with each of the senators. Riegle is the last. The three-term Democrat from Flint has asserted repeatedly he did nothing wrong. The public interest group Common Cause has accused Riegle and the four other senators - Aan Cranston, D-Calif., Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz., John Glenn, D-Ohio, and John McCain, R-Ariz. - of improper behavior in interceding with federal regulators on Keating's behalf. Keating and his associates contributed $1.3 million to the senators' campaigns and causes. The Ethics Committee is trying to determine whether the donations motivated the senators to help Keating. The senators say their actions were routine efforts to help a constituent settle a dispute with the bureaucracy. Keating's failed thrift was based in Irvine, Calif., and its parent company was in Arizona. But he had purchased and renovated the Pontchartrain Hotel in downtown Detroit. In a letter to the Ethics Committee on Oct. 18, 1989, Riegle said he had hoped Keating would make further investments in the area. Keating hosted a fund-raiser for Riegle's 1988 re-election campaign at the Pontchartrain in March 1987. A year later, Riegle returned the $78,250 he received from Keating and associates, saying he wanted to avoid an appearance of conflict of interest. The five senators met with several California regulators who were investigating Lincoln Savings and Loan on April 9, 1987. Riegle did not attend a meeting a week earlier between the other four senators and Edwin Gray, former head of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board. The Ethics Committee launched its investigation last December. Sources have said Robert S. Bennett, its outside counsel, has recommended dropping Glenn and McCain from the probe. But the sources say Bennett believes there is enough evidence to continue investigating Riegle, Cranston and DeConcini. The recommendation on Riegle apparently was based largely on the fact that his meeting with the regulators occurred less than three weeks after the Detroit fund-raiser, sources have said. Riegle's chief aide says the fund-raiser was scheduled months before the April 9 meeting. Riegle has portrayed himself as having only minor involvement in the Lincoln affair. In his letter to the Ethics Committee, he said he attended the meeting at the request of DeConcini and McCain because of his knowledge of the banking industry. ``At no time did I seek any meeting with regulators in Lincoln's behalf or suggest any course of regulatory action with respect to Lincoln,'' he said in a statement last October. But Riegle later acknowledged discussing the Lincoln situation with Gray in March 1987. Gray has said that conversation led to the two meetings between senators and federal regulators that are a focal point of the controversy.

DOC.HEAD: Forensic Experts Helping Identify Remains from Mass Grave
DOC.TEXT: An American and two Argentine pathologists arrived here Wednesday to help identify the remains of some of the 1,500 people secretly buried in a mass grave. Authorities uncovered the grave, in an unmarked section of a cemetery outside Sao Paulo, while searching Sept. 4 for the bodies of unidentified paupers who died in the early 1970s. By law, such remains must be dug up and put in repositories. Most of the skeletons packed in blue plastic bags at the Perus cemetery were those of indigents, but at least 50 were the remains of political foes, dumped there by security forces during Brazil's military dictatorship, authorities said. Military officials were given amnesty from prosecution for human rights violations after they left power in 1985, and the identifications will be used purely to help relatives confirm the deaths of missing people. ``Our objective is to offer advice to our Brazilian colleagues and some of the benefit of our experience obtained in Argentina, where an equally tragic experience occurred,'' said forensic anthropologist Clyde Snow, of Oklahoma City. Snowhas been working since 1984 with the Argentine Forensic Anthropology Team to identify the remains of suspected subversives who disappeared during the ``dirty war'' waged by Argentina's rightist military from 1976-83. At least 9,000 suspected leftists vanished and are presumed dead. Snow also was part of the international forensic team that in 1985 identified the remains of Nazi war criminal Josef Mengele in a cemetery near Sao Paulo. Snow was accompanied by Luis Fondebrider and Alejandro Inchaurregui of the Argentine team. A temporary forensic lab was set up at the Perus cemetery to determine the age, sex and height of the skeletons.More detailed examinations were to be carried out at the University of Campinas, about 58 miles from Sao Paulo.

DOC.HEAD: Syrians Leaving Beirut's Christian Enclave; Aoun's Accounts Frozen
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with how presidential palace was damaged, details. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Syrian troops began withdrawing from the Christian enclave of defeated Gen. Michel Aoun on Wednesday, and the government froze the rebel officer's bank accounts. Witnesses said they saw a Syrian armored brigade withdrawing from Aoun's former territory in the Metn mountains northeast of Beirut. Police said government and Syrian troops also were leaving the Christian heartland northeast of the capital. ``The combat is over. The forces that carried out the attack were ordered to start gathering at key road intersections and strategic locations,'' said a police spokesman, who could not be identified under standing rules. The Christian general's 11-month mutiny against the government of President Elias Hrawi was crushed Saturday by Syrian and Lebanese troops. Aoun took sanctuary in the French embassy, and the newspaper An-Nahar said it might take weeks or months for France and Lebanon to reach agreement on his departure. The Lebanese Central Bank said it had carried out the government-ordered freeze on Aoun's local accounts and was arranging to block his access to deposits abroad. Banking sources quoted by the communist-run Voice of the People radio station estimated the frozen assets at $100 million. The figure could not be verified independently. Hrawi's government has said it wants Aoun tried on charges including the alleged theft of about $75 million from the state treasury. The unidentified sources quotedbby the radio said some of the frozen funds were in the names of Aoun's two aides, Maj. Gen. Edgar Maalouf and Brig. Gen. Issam Abu-Jamra. Also Wednesday, Hrawi sent his director of presidential affairs, Mahmoud Othman, and six presidential guards to assume control of the presidential palace in the Christian suburb of Baabda. The 55-year-old Aoun used the palace as his headquarters. The presidential palace was damaged in fighting between Aoun and Syrian forces last year and in shelling duels with rival Christian militia fighters of Samir Geagea this year. Repair work is expected to begin soon to enable Hrawi to occupy the palace, traditional seat of the presidency. In Aoun's former enclave, an 80-square-mile area northeast of Beirut that is home to 15,000 Maronites, bakeries and groceries reopened Wednesday and residents began repairing damage caused by the fighting. ``Life is gradually returning to normal. Civilians, who have generally remained indoors since Saturday, started going out,'' the police spokesman said. ``Winter is coming. I can't leave holes in the roof and glass windows shattered,'' said Elie Sayegh, who lives in the Christian suburb of Hadath east of Beirut. ``A tank shell demolished my car. It can't be repaired,'' said Sayegh. Businessman Elie Yazbek was trying to rent a crane to get his damaged car to a mechanic. ``It is badly damaged, but can be repaired,'' said Yazbek, 43. ``The car will have to be ready by next week. I'll have to drive my children to school.'' Hrawi plans to form a reconciliation government to reunify the capital and implement a peace accord giving Moslems and Christians equal power in Lebanon. The accord is aimed at ending the 15-year-old civil war. Aoun rejected the peace accord, largely because it did not set a timetable for withdrawing Syrian forces. Syria, the main powerbroker in Lebanon, has had troops in the country since 1976. The Syrians are considered an army of occupation by many Christians.

DOC.HEAD: German Official Arrested for Spying for Iraq
DOC.TEXT: A government official arrested earlier this month for allegedly spying for Iraq supplied that nation with secret U.S. documents on the Persian Gulf crisis, a newspaper reported on Wednesday. On Oct. 2, the Federal Prosecutor's Office said a Foreign Ministry official identified only as Juergen M.G. had been arrested on suspicion of delivering confidential documents to Iraqi military intelligence. Bild Zeitung reported the ministry official had informed Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein of ``every step of the U.S.A. and its allies'' after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. The official had ``access to the most secret sealed documents,'' Bild said, including information from NATO's headquarters in Brussels and from the U.S. Ambassador to NATO, William Taft. The German official also delivered ``situation analyses'' drawn up by NATO intelligence agencies, Bild reported, and informed Iraq of cables sent to Bonn from German embassies in Israel, Jordan and Baghdad, the newspaper said. Bild said the secrets were relayed via the Iraqi embassy in Bonn. According to Bild, the alleged spy may have previously worked for the former East German secret police. Bild said the official was unmasked after a tip by a former East German intelligence agent in Egypt. Asked to comment on the Bild report, Hans-Juergen Foerster, a spokesman for the prosecutor's office, said it is still not known exactly what the man had delivered to Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Turns Down Mercy Flight for Kuwait
With AM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Iraq refused permission for a mercy flight to carry medicine into Kuwait to help Kuwaitis and foreigners stranded there, U.N. officials said Wednesday. Kuwait's government-in-exile offered Friday to send a medical flight to Kuwait, and asked Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar to make arrangements with Iraq for it to land. Iraq's U.N. Mission refused the request Tuesday, said U.N. spokesman Francois Giuliani. He did not elaborate on Iraq's refusal, but said Baghdad's position was well-known. Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, and subsequently announced it had annexed the emirate and made it into the 19th province of Iraq. Other attempts by the United Nations to send missions into Kuwait have been stymied by Baghdad's insistence that the mission be understood as a visit to an Iraqi province, rathr than to an occupied country. The United Nations has denounced the invasion in a series of eight resolutions.

DOC.HEAD: Ethiopian Jews Ask Israel, United States to Appease Ethiopia
DOC.TEXT: Ethiopian Jewish leaders asked Israel and the United States on Wednesday to come to terms with the Addis Ababa government to save thousands of Jews stranded there. ``We are appealing to the American administration: for the sake of human lives, forget the anger over the Ethiopians, talk to them and convince them to release the Jews,'' Rachamim Elazar, secretary of the Union of Ethiopian Immigrants, said on Israel radio. Ethiopian Jewish leaders in Israel say the African country's Marxist government is blocking Jewish emigration to win military, political and economic assistance from Israel. Ethiopia is torn by civil war and famine. Ethiopian Jews have sought to escape to a better life in Israel, where 17,000 Ethiopian immigrants have made their home. About 15,000 to 18,000 Jews remain in Ethiopia. About 8,000 were airlifted to Israel in 1984 through Sudan. According to U.S. congressmen, Ethiopia is trying to force Israel to sell it advanced weapons for use against the rebels in the civil war. Ethiopia also is seen as wanting closer ties with the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Inmate Accused of Credit Fraud from Prison Cell Faces Sentencing
DOC.TEXT: Federal authorities are struggling to estimate the size and reach of an elaborate credit card fraud scheme masterminded by a murder convict from his prison cell. Daniel Neal Faries has admitted he used a telephone and computer smuggled into his prison cell in Florida to purchase hundreds of thousand of dollars worth of merchandise on other people's credit cards. Later, he even built his own phone within the federal prison in Chicago to continue running the massive credit card fraud ring while he awaited charges of being a leader in the ring. In newspaper interviews and statements quoted in court records, Faries claims he bribed two dozen prison guards with expensive gifts, sent flowers and jewelry to his wife and even bought a se of diamond-studded false teeth for a fellow inmate's mother. He is scheduled for sentencing Thursday in U.S. District Court in Milwaukee. He faces five years on the fraud charge and has asked the judge to give him the maximum so he can quickly return to prison and start a new scheme. So far, authorities have tracked down $500,000 worth of merchandise stolen through his credit card scam. But investigators said Faries and a ring of up to 125 people could have illegally charged millions of dollars more in merchandise to other people's credit cards. The investigation could stretch on for years because of the widespread activities of the ring and the difficulty in proving that those who received gifts from Faries knew about his scam, said Cliff Deckard, special agent in charge of the Secret Service in Milwaukee. Nevertheless, the investigator said he hopes to indict 50 people by next month. The identities of suspects have not been released. The case is being handled in Milwaukee because some of the fradulently merchandise was purchased there. Faries has admitted he began using other people's credit card information about four years ago while he awaited trial on a murder charge in a federal prison in Miami. Faries was later convicted and sentenced to life in prison. Over the past four years, Faries has confessed to sending cases of wine, limousine service, gold coins, food baskets and jewelry to friends and relatives while he was behind bars. He also said he bought Rolex watches and snakeskin boots for 24 guards at the Dade County Jail in Miami in exchange for access to a computer. Faries said a guard smuggled in a laptop computer and telephone in a laundry bag for him to obtain credit card information and make his illegal charges to other people's accounts. After Faries was sentenced on May 1 to life in prison on the murder charge, he was moved to Chicago's Metropolitan Correctional Center to await trial on the massive fraud scheme he operated while in the Miami jail. The switch to Chicago, however, didn't stop him from running his credit card crime, he said. Prison officials in Illinois recently caught him with a rudimentary phone he built by tapping into the prison phone wires behind a metal plate in a jail room. He dialed out of the prison to a satellite dish by using his electronic watch, he said. The tones of the watch, similar to those of a telephone, connected him with a worldwide satellite communication system, Faries said. From there, he said, ``I'm away. I can call anywhere in the world - for free.'' Faries brags he is a smart thief who reads books and magazines while in jail to further his life of crime. ``I get all the rags,'' Faries said in a weekend interview with the Chicago Sun Times. ``In Miami, I subscribed to everything up to and including `Working Mother.' I liked the ads (for mail order purchases) in there.'' Secret Service officials on the case say they hope Faries' sentencing on the credit-related charge bars him from phone or computer use because he'll already spend his life in prison on the murder charge. ``I'm not sure what effect a (jail) sentence will have on him. That has been the problem to begin with,'' Deckard said. A sentencing in Milwaukee should not have been necessary, Faries lawyer, Dean Strang, said. ``If he did what they say he did, it seems to me the most practical way to handle this problem would be to take away the telephone,'' Strang said. Prison officials in Illinois and Florida have refused to discuss Faries case.

DOC.HEAD: American Extradited from Israel Over Britain's Biggest Robbery
DOC.TEXT: An American allegedly involved in Britain's largest robbery, the 1987 London safety vault heist, was extradited to London from Israel on Wednesday, police said. Eric Rubin, 51, flew to Heathrow airport Wednesday from Tel Aviv, accompanied by two British detectives, police said. Six men were jailed last year for the July 12, 1987, theft of $59 million in cash, jewelry, works of art and other valuables from the vault in the Knightsbridge area of London. Included in the haul was a 40-carat diamond, since recovered, belonging to the wife of West German industrialist Gerd Rudolph Flick. Italian Valerio Viccei was sentenced to 22 years in prison for that and five previous robberies. Five others received sentences of 10 to 18 years. Rubin has been in custody in Israel since 1988, awaiting the completion of extradition proceedings. Police also want to question Rubin about a 1987 robbery at a London branch of the exclusive Coutts Bank, a spokesman said.

DOC.HEAD: Country Duo Judds to Break Up at End of Current Tour
DOC.TEXT: The Judds, an award-winning mother-daughter country music duo, will call it quits at the end of their current concert tour, they announced Wednesday. Naomi, 44, will retire from performing due to hepatitis, which was diagnosed 10 months ago. Wynonna, 26, will start a solo career with an album tentatively slated for a spring 1992 release. ``I have always told Wy and our fans the only thing that could stop me from this career that I so desperately love would be my health,'' Naomi said. ``Unfortunately, that has happened.'' Their current tour is booked through Nov. 4 at Philadelphia, but RCA spokesman Greg McCarn said additional dates were certain to be set. ``I will miss touring and the daily interplay with our fans,'' said Naomi, who said she will continue writing songs. The mother and daughter announced their decision in a tearful news conference at an empty Music Row building that formerly housed RCA Records and where the duo auditioned seven years ago. The Judds were voted duo of the year for the third straight year Oct. 8 by the Country Music Association. In their acceptance remarks, both fought back tears as they credited each other. Their hit records over their six-year career include ``Grandpa,'' ``Mama He's Crazy,'' ``Why Not Me,'' ``Rockin' With the Rhythm'' and their current ``Born to Be Blue.'' Four of their eight albums have sold 1 million copies: ``Why Not Me,'' ``Rockin' With the Rhythm,'' ``Heartland'' and ``The Judds' Greatest Hits.'' Wynonna said her first solo recording sessions would be after the current tour winds up. ``The decision to begin a solo career has all happened so fast because of Mom's health that I have not put a lot of thought into it,'' she said. ``My main concern right now is Mom's welfare. However, I have the complete support of my manager, my mother and others around me. I certainly will give it my best shot.'' Hepatitis is an inflammation of the liver. Symptoms include weakness, loss of appetite, nausea, vomiting and jaundice. Wynonna announced in July that she is engaged to songwriter Tony King of Nashville. Naomi, a former nurse, married gospel music singer Larry Strickland in May 1989. She was divorced in 1977 from her first husband.

DOC.HEAD: Mormon Church Leader Discharged From Hospital
DOC.TEXT: Mormon Church President Ezra Taft Benson was discharged from the hospital Wednesday, nearly a month after he was admitted for treatment of blood clots on the brain, a church spokesman said. Benson, 91, underwent two operations at LDS hospital for the blood clots and later was treated for unrelated gastrointestinal bleeding. Benson's daily schedule had been somewhat curtailed for the past few years because of his age. However, he attended weekly meetings of the Council of the Twelve and First Presidency in the Salt Lake Temple before he was hospitalized. Church spokesman Don LeFevre said doctors hadn't yet decided what activities Benson would be able to resume. Benson was hospitalized Sept. 18 after complaining of severe headaches and difficulty swallowing. He has been president of the 7.5 million-member Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints since 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Rappaport Ahead in Spending on Senate Race
DOC.TEXT: Republican challenger James Rappaport has poured personal loans into his campaign and is spending more than Sen. John Kerry, finance reports show. Kerry, D-Mass., has spent $2.3 million this year on the campaign, according to documents on file at the Senate clerk's office and made public Wednesday. Rappaport has spent $2.4 million. Virtually all of Kerry's money comes from individual contributions. Kerry refuses to accept money from political action committees. Rappaport, as of Sept. 30, had loaned his campaign $2.25 million, or nearly 92 percent of the total he has spent this year. ``We're in the same ballpark with John Kerry,'' said Rappaport spokesman Gary McMillan. ``He's collected more than $5 million over the life of his Senate term plus $2 million worth of free franked mail.'' Any financial advantages of incumbency were offset by Rappaport's ability to write his own campaign checks for millions, said Kerry consultant Ron Rosenblith. The most recent polling conducted just after the Sept. 18 primary showed Rappaport trailing Kerry by just 4 percentage points, making the race statistically even. The two candidates have aired television ads attacking their opponent. Rappaport issued a widely noted ad showing a photograph of the unpopular Massachusetts Gov. Michael S. Dukakis fading into a picture of Kerry. Kerry immediately shot back with an ad raising questions about Rappaport's business dealings in Vermont and Hawaii.

DOC.HEAD: San Francisco Bay Area Remembers the Earthquake
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 23 grafs to UPDATE with memorials taking place. Picks up 21st graf pvs, `But nothing...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto SCZ3, LaserPhotos staffing.
DOC.TEXT: People fell silent, church bells rang and mourners heaped white carnations near the spot where a freeway collapsed as Californians marked the first anniversary Wednesday of Bay area earthquake. In West Oakland, grief mixed with celebration as about 200 residents of the drug-torn neighborhood gathered near the Cypress Freeway, which collapsed and killed 42 people. Standing with rescuers, city officials and politicians, many felt renewed pride as they recalled the efforts of neighbors who scaled the rubble of the double-decked freeway to rescue trapped drivers. ``A year ago today, we heard the loudest noise ever heard in Oakland,'' said Paul Cobb, head of the Citizens Emergency Relief Team, a volunteer neighborhood group. ``We saw neighbors grabbing ladders out of their basements. Those who stood on corners with nothing to do all of the sudden rose to the occasion.'' The Oct. 17 quake, which measured at 7.1 on the Richter scale, struck at 5:04 p.m. It killed 67 people. People across the nation knew something was wrong when the television signal from the World Series was lost. The quake halted the third game of the series between the Oakland Athletics and the San Francisco Giants. The A's were again in the series - in Cincinnati - and many spoke with quiet pride of the way Californians helped the injured and rushed to rebuild. ``Those were some of California's most terrifying few seconds,'' Gov. George Deukmejian said at an earthquake conference in San Francisco, that was also attended by Marilyn Quayle, the vice president's wife. ``But they were followed by some of the finest hours of our society.'' Observances were held throughout the San Francisco Bay area. At 5:04 p.m., church bells tolled in the city and in Santa Cruz and Watsonville. In those two two cities south of San Francisco, where quake damage is still evident, mourners observed a moment of silence. They fell silent, too, by the freeway in West Oakland. Richard Von Riddle, 34, of San Leandro, hopes a memorial will be built to honor quake victims. ``There's 42 spirits floating down this strip right here,'' said Richard Von Riddle, as he stood by the freeway. He hoped a memorial would be built to those crushed. ``People lost their whole families,'' Von Riddle said. ``Every time I go by, I start shaking and my heart breaks.'' The remaining roadway that bisects the drug-infested neighborhood of Oakland was renamed Mandela Parkway. ``There's been a very demonstrable renewal of hope in West Oakland,'' said event organizer Jack Atkin. ``The earthquake was staggering in its destructive power. God knows, there's enough problems in West Oakland with or without an earthquake. But people pulling together will get them solved much quicker.'' At the Ferry Building in San Francisco, 1,000 people cheered as the flag was raised for the first time since the quake. The building's flagpole remained tilted long after the quake, and had become for some a symbol of how far the recovery had to go. In Watsonville, where one person died, scores of residents took to the streets to commemorate the quake. One group gathered for the blessing of a new home, the latest to be rebuilt since the quake. Calls flooded into the AfterQuake Project in San Francisco, a mental health hot line for people traumatized by the quake, after a television station broadcast the number early Wednesday. ``A lot of people are feeling some anxiety about crossing the bridge. They are looking at the weather,'' said counselor Alexandra Charusofsky. The mid-day temperature Wednesday was 80 degrees, about 10 degrees above normal. The day of the earthquake, the high reached 83. At Candlestick Park, where the quake shook fans awaiting the third game of the 1989 World Series, Mayor Art Agnos said the quake ``tested our preparedness, it tested our strength, and most of all, it tested our character as a city and a people. We survived that earthquake.'' A French restaurant, L'Entrecote de Paris, organized a ``A Celebration of Survival'' to recreate last year's impromptu after-quake soiree that started when regulars begged the restaurant not to close like others on the block. ``Some were frightened, some were laughing,'' said owner Alexander Mortazavi. ``They were singing songs together. This whole place became a party.'' In seaside Santa Cruz, where blocks of downtown still show the quake's destruction, residents were given the option of partying into the night to the outdoor sounds of rock bands and ``earthquake comedy,'' a free show by a group of San Francisco comics. ``The earthquake made you an instant native,'' said Bratton, a member of the Downtown Association, one of the event organizers. ``The people who stayed are like veterans of a war, veterans of a tragedy.'' But nothing was scheduled Wednesday in the streets of another hard-hit area. In San Francisco's Marina District, where the earthquake sparked fires and destroyed homes, the tragedy still haunts residents. The Marina's anniversary events were scheduled before and after the actual date to avoid a media onslaught. ``People here are trying to get through the day,'' said Maggie McCall, publisher of the Marina Times, a neighborhood newspaper. ``We don't like to be inhospitable, but we don't like people staring at us all the time. It's hard for a lot of people.''

DOC.HEAD: House Approves Trade Tie
DOC.TEXT: The House voted Wednesday night to normalize trade relations with Czechsolovakia for the first time since World War II and dramatically reduce tariffs on its exports to the United States. By a voice vote, the House approved a trade agreement signed last April by the Bush administration and the newly elected Prague government granting each other most-favored-nation trade status. Such a status qualifies the exporting country for the lowest tariffs in effect on the goods it ships to the buying country. The agreement now goes to the Senate, where approval also is needed before barriers to trade with the formerly communist ruled Czechs can come down. Although the agreement was signed in April, President Bush did not send the agreement to Capitol Hill for the required congressional approval until last month. The accord will effectively reduce by 90 percent the tariffs paid on some $82 million in Czech exports to the United States last year and open the way for increased business ties between the two countries. The effect will be to give Czechoslovakia a much broader U.S. market for its exports by cutting their prices to wholesalers, retailers and ultimately American consumers by as much as up to 40 percent. It also will open the Czech economy to more U.S. exports while also protecting American companies' patents and copyrights. The agreement is the first U.S. bilateral trade accord with a former Eastern Bloc country since the Warsaw Pact began collapsing more than a year ago.

DOC.HEAD: Candidate: My Report Led To Sadat Peace Initiative
DOC.TEXT: Republican gubernatorial candidate Pierre Rinfret claims his report of a 1977 trip to the Middle East prompted Egyptian President Anwar Sadat's historic peace mission to Israel. Cyrus Vance, U.S. Secretary of State at the time, on Wednesday called Rinfret's claim ``rubbish.'' Rinfret is challenging Democratic Gov. Mario Cuomo's bid for a third four-year term. A recent independent poll found Cuomo had a 45-point lead. Rinfret's August 1977 report, titled ``The Geopolitics of Israel and Surrounding Arab States,'' discussed Israel's military preparedness in case of war The report said Israel would try to destroy the economic base of each enemy country and would target the Suez Canal, electric power stations, factories and dams. Rinfret, an international economic consultant, said Israeli secret service officials told him that the disclosure of Israel's military intent convinced Sadat to visit Israel, according to campaign spokesman Ted Kavanau. Sadat's surprise visit to Israeli Prime Minister Menachem Begin in November 1977 led to the historic Camp David peace accord between Egypt and Israel two years later. ``The Israeli secret service took the report and gave it to Sadat,'' Kavanau said. ``When he got it - this is Pierre Rinfret talking - he made the decision instantly to go to Israel. ``The Israelis were using Rinfret to deliver a message to the Egyptians that they would fight,'' Kavanau said. Vance said Sadat decided to visit Israel on his own. ``I was in very close touch with Sadat all along and Rinfret was never mentioned,'' said Vance, a New York City attorney who served during the Carter administration. Sadat and Begin shared the Nobel Peace Prize in 1978. Sadat was assassinated by Moslem extremists in 1981. Begin, 77, resigned as Israeli prime minister in 1983.

DOC.HEAD: ANOTHER LOOK: Clean-Coal Research May Not Be in Time to Save Industry
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhotos, LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Five years ago, Ohio voters approved a bond issue to find ways to clean the state's high-sulfur coal and - in the process - save the jobs of miners like Jerry Back. Some $85 million later, Back is anything but reassured. ``I've got 15 years here, and I'd hate to see it go down the drain,'' Back said as he prepared for the start of the second shift at the Meigs No. 2 mine. ``I think in five years, we may be working. But I don't think we'll be working after five years.'' Ohio's high-sulfur coal, once burned in many of the region's electrical power plants, fell into disfavor in the 1980s amid rising concern about acid rain pollution. State officials, seeing the market diminish, asked voters in 1985 to approve a $100 million bond issue to back research projects aimed at finding a way to remove some of the sulfur. While officials say the research is promising, the solutions may not gain widespread commercial acceptance in time to save many Ohio mines and the jobs of 6,700 miners. ``I'm a coal miner, but I'm a person, too,'' said miner Bill Oiler. ``If there is a problem out there, we do need to find a solution. But the solution is not to just do away with jobs. We need to find technology to alleviate the problem.'' Ohio Coal Development Office chief Jacqueline Bird said her office has disbursed about 85 percent of the money raised through the 1985 bond issue. Some of the projects will soon enter large-scale testing, while others remain on the drawing board. ``If there were a quick, easy solution, God knows we would have done it by now,'' Ms. Bird said. ``We're trying to find the permanent solution. If there were a short-term answer, we would have landed on it.'' Ohio coal is abundant - the OCDO estimates a 200-year reserve - but it is loaded with sulfur, which combines with oxygen during burning to form sulfur dioxide. Sulfur dioxide combines with hydrogen and oxygen in the atmosphere to form sulfuric acid. Typical Ohio coal has a sulfur content of about 3.5 percent; most utilities need coal with sulfur content below 0.7 percent. The federal government has steadily tightened sulfur dioxide and nitrogen oxide emission limits, and even more stringent limits are pending in Congress. As the limits have shrunk, so have Ohio coal sales and mining jobs. Even Ohio's own utilities and mills burn more coal from out of state than in-state mines. Last year, less than 46 percent of the coal burned in Ohio came from within the state, U.S. Department of Energy figures show. But it takes as long as 25 years for a technology to move from concept to commercial acceptance, Ms. Bird said. Each stage must be tested and the next step revised on the basis of earlier findings. And even when the technology is proven, it takes time for the industry to trust it and invest millions of dollars in plant renovations, she said. Ohio doesn't lack ideas. At Lorain, it is testing a process that burns limestone along with coal to absorb sulfur dioxide. At a plant in Brilliant which was shut down in the 1970s because of the cost of complying with clean air laws, they're turning water to steam by burning a mix of coal and sorbent, which reacts with and captures sulfur. The steam drives a turbine and creates electricity. But the gases from the burning are cleaned of sulfur and then used to create electricity in a second turbine. Remaining hot gas is used to heat fresh water headed into the boiler. But Jack Segall, U.S. Department of Energy deputy assistant secretary for coal technology, said there are no rewards for taking risks in new technology. ``If the cost of producing electricity as a result of this new technology goes down, it's the ratepayer who gets the benefit,'' he said. ``If the technology does not work, it's the utility that gets penalized.'' President Bush's clean air plan includes incentives to encourage use of clean coal technologies, Segall said. But it's still not clear what choice utilities will make, he said. And in the meantime, ``we hold our breath and hope we can make it,'' Ms. Bird said. ``In Ohio, if the Clean Air Act amendments don't change substantially from where they are now, the large (mining) companies will be able to make it, and so will some of the medium-sized companies,'' she said. ``You'll probably see more mergers between medium- and small-sized companies - and some companies will go under, unfortunately.'' The best hope is to accelerate the pace of clean coal technology development, Ms. Bird said. ``The problem now is people are saying, `Well, you've been in existence in five years, why isn't it solved?' It's the perception that if you throw enough money at it quickly, that'll do it,'' Ms. Bird said. ``But you can't push science and technology along that fast. You can accelerate it, but you can't make it meet false deadlines.''

DOC.HEAD: New West Historians Color the Past in Realistic Hues
DOC.TEXT: John Wayne rode into America's heart as a white-hatted tamer of the West. But some historians say if the truth had found its way into those old Westerns, Wayne would have worn a black hat. ``There's really kind of an insult to Indian people in that notion of white person stands at Mississippi River and looks into the horizon and says, `It's open. It's free. It's mine,''' said University of Colorado history professor Patricia Limerick. ``Certainly, historically people did that. But I don't see any reason why the historians should echo the point of view of one of the participants. To have your vanity, your self-image or your pride rest on an untruth is not good for individual mental health, national mental health.'' Limerick, 39, is a New West historian - a breed of Western historians who see the pioneers as exploitive conquerors who damaged the environment with their unrestrained hunting, trapping and mining. The ranks of the New West historians include Limerick, Howard Lamar of Yale, Donald Worster of the University of Kansas and others. They say traditional Western history omitted the tragedies and the contributions made by Indians, Hispanics, French trappers, Chinese, blacks and women. ``When the dust settled, the invaders had more power and the natives had less,'' said Limerick, whose book, ``The Legacy of Conquest: The Unbroken Past of the American West,'' is written from the New West viewpoint. Not everyone agrees with the revisionists. A.B. Guthrie, author of ``The Big Sky,'' and University of Wisconsin history professor Alan Bogue believe the they tend to overemphasize the negative side of the West's settlement. ``Life is hard everywhere. Inequalities are forever,'' Guthrie wrote recently in Nieman Reports. ``The revisionists' wide-eyed discovery of them in the West strikes me as a bit naive. It is the blind cruelties of life on this planet that have led man to invent heaven.'' Most Americans learned about the settlement of the West from the writings of Frederick Jackson Turner, a Univesity of Wisconsin history professor who influenced historians for more than a century. In the late 1800s, Turner made the Anglo-American settler the focus of his account of the West's settlement. These settlers were depicted as having given up comfortable homes to start new lives in an unforgiving wilderness, free to anyone brave enough to tame it. Turner also is credited with formulating the ``frontier thesis,'' which said the frontier that set Americans apart from the rest of the world closed in 1890. U.S. Census data was cited. His premise laid the groundwork for the belief in a uniquely American pioneer spirit that authors and presidents have invoked to inspire a nation. Limerick said a recent poll of teachers of Western history showed 87 percent used Turner's theses as the basis for their courses. ``Turner and his students and his generation tended to see the Western experience as something that was extremely impressive: People marched across the continent and turned it into homes and industries in a relatively short time,'' said Bogue. ``There were always underlying stories that were something we couldn't be nearly as proud of perhaps ... Turner's version of the West was what he and his generation saw in it.'' The New West historians believe Western history should be written as a continuous story, not with a division between the 19th and 20th centuries. Without such an arbitrary dividing line, the California Gold Rush of 1848, for example, could be tied into 20th century mining booms in which the same land, water and environmental issues recurred. Because the two centuries usually are treated as two separate eras, textbooks that may address California economics and demographics usually fail to show how they relate to the state's history, said Clyde A. Milner II, a Utah State University professor who is editor of the Western Historical Quarterly. New West history is ``a developing trend over the past 30 years that now is reaching a critical mass,'' Milner said. Critics argue that New West historians find too much fault in Turner's work, which was well-accepted at the time. ``They are overemphasizing the unfortunate results of the Western movement ... It gave millions of people the opportunity to provide for new lives,'' said Bogue. ``One I don't think can be criticized too harshly for saying, `Hey look, it really does look as if an era is ending.' People of that time thought so.'' Limerick blamed the stagnation of U.S. historical theory during the post-Turner era on historians trapped by his definitions of the frontier. They drove ``themselves into a cul-de-sac and then became stymied,'' she said. As the historians debate, the new ideas are gaining acceptance in a wide arena, with a growing emphasis on specialized history whose focus ranges from the environment to cultural diversity. In addition, the more realistic views are gaining a foothold in literature, from the popular Southwestern Indian mystery novels of author Tony Hillerman to a $12 million ABC-TV mini-series about George Armstrong Custer, based on author Evan S. Connell's ``Son of the Morning Star.'' But the New West historians face an uphill journey to conquer all the myths, as witnessed by the popularity of Larry McMurtry's novel, ``Lonesome Dove'' and the subsequent TV mini-series, she said. There is a place for the romantic tales of the Old West that made John Wayne famous, ``as long as we let it have as much power as we think it should have ... we ought to be aware of where the (movie) screen is and where we are.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Tues PMs, Oct 23

DOC.TEXT: Leaders of the nation's two biggest religious bodies, the Roman Catholic and Southern Baptist churches, are protesting proposals to cut tax deductions for charitable contributions. Scores of other voluntary agencies also are opposing the move. Monsignor Robert N. Lynch, general secretary of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops, said, ``Weakening the incentives for contributions would not only be counter-productive but contradict the repeated calls by President Bush for increased involvement by the non-profit private sector in addressing needs of the less fortunate in our society.'' Kay S. Dowhower, director of the governmental affairs office for the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America, noted individuals contributed $96 billion in 1989 to various causes serving public purpose. ``In fact, the charitable contribution tax deduction may indeed be one of the biggest bargains in the federal budget,'' she said, adding: ``Do not bite the hand that feeds so many.'' --- GENEVA (AP) - Hailing the re-unification of Germany, the Rev. Emilio Castro, general secretary of the World Council of Churches, urged German churches - West and East - to learn from each other, pray and work together and ``be witnesses together to Jesus Christ at a period when your country needs you most.'' --- MEXICO CITY (AP) - A Canadian television news anchor says journalists should broaden the definition of news beyond disasters and conflicts to ``embrace inspiring news that promotes dignity.'' Kevin Evans, an anchor for the CBC in Vancouver, British Columia, said at a Lutheran-sponsored international conference on communication that unpleasant news and conflict should be reported not as entertainment ``but to provoke thought, to challenge.'' --- ANCHORAGE, Alaska (AP) - For the second time in a year, an American Indian has been elected an Episcopal bishop. The Rev. Steven Charleston, 41, an Oklahoma-born Choctaw, was elected bishop of Alaska. Another American Indian, Bishop Steven Plummer, was elected a year ago as bishop of Navajoland, a mission diocese based in Farmington, N.M., covering Navajo reservations in Arizona, New Mexico and Utah. --- NEW YORK (AP) - American Orthodox rabbis have designated Saturday ``a Sabbath of Protest'' against what they called the ``unjust and immoral'' United Nations condemnation of Israel for the violence in Jerusalem in which 19 Palestinians were killed. ``This hypocrisy of the U.N. is not unusual,'' but the United States joining in the condemnation vote is ``alarming,'' declared Rabbi Marc D. Angel, president of the Rabbinical Council of America. ``The U.S. has betrayed Israel.'' The Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations said the ``blatant provocation and premeditated act of violence'' in which Palestinians hurled rocks at Jewish worshippers was instigated by PLO leaders to divert attention from the Persian Gulf crisis and divide Arab states. --- HORSLEY'S GREEN, England (AP) - Representatives of various agencies involved in Bible distribution say the world has ``a greater openness and hunger for the word of God than ever before in history.'' Saying that use and familiarity with Scriptures had dimished in industrial countries, the Bible organizations urged churches to ``make the Scriptures central to their worship and ministry.'' The 12 Bible organizations, holding their first joint meeting Oct. 2-5, said in a statement: ``Christian missions often carry out their evangelistic task without using the distribution of Scripture as an integral part of their outreach, thereby neglecting to provide their personnel with the tool most crucial to their ministry.'' The agencies include the United Bible Societies, Wycliffe Bible Translators, International Bible Society, Bibles for the World, Bible League, Institute for Bible Translation and Pioneer Bible Translators.

DOC.HEAD: Actress Sees Women Gaining Ground in Hollywood
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Mimi Rogers sees a gleam of hope that women may one day achieve equal status in today's macho movie world. ``It's an unfortunate fact that there are many more roles for men than there are for women. A favorable sign is the success of films like `Pretty Woman' and `Ghosts' - much more successful than big, male-dominated action films,'' she said. ``With these two films, in which women are on more of an equal level, being so successful, maybe the trend will start to shift in the direction of having men and women really co-starring.'' Upcoming movies seem promising: Cher and Winona Ryder co-star in Orion's ``Mermaids,'' a sweet relationship movie; Michelle Pfeifer co-stars with Sean Connery in ``The Russia House,'' based on the John le Carre thriller; Julia Roberts stars in next spring's ``Sleeping With the Enemy''; and Academy Award-winner Jody Foster is eagerly awaited as the star of ``Silence of the Lambs,'' a taut thriller based on the best seller by Thomas Harris. If not equal, Rogers has a vital role in ``Desperate Hours,'' with Mickey Rourke and Anthony Hopkins. It's Dino De Laurentiis' update of the 1955 movie, with Rogers in the part originated by Martha Scott. Rourke plays the Humphrey Bogart role of a criminal psycho who takes a suburban family hostage. Hopkins has the part of the husband, originally played by Fredric March. The director of the MGM release is Michael Cimino. Yes, the same Michael Cimino who won an Academy Award for ``The Deer Hunter'' in 1978, and made the financial bomb ``Heaven's Gate'' in 1980. Rogers remarked that during the ``Desperate Hours'' filming Cimino ``was very relaxed, very much at ease and enjoying the whole process. There was an awareness on his part that he wanted to bring it in on time and on budget. I think we actually finished a week early and under budget. ``He knows that he knows how to make movies. There's no question the guy has made some brilliant movies. It's more a matter of reaffirming that he can do it, that he can follow a schedule and a budget, that it's no problem and boom - there's the movie. That's what he did.'' Rogers has three new films: ``Desperate Hours''; ``The Doors,'' Oliver Stone's biography of rocker Jim Morrison; and ``The Rapture,'' an apocalyptic drama. Last January, she and Tom Cruise ended their three-year marriage, during which she seemed to be subordinating her own career as his zoomed skyward. She corrected that impression: ``I actually worked quite a bit. Unfortunately, two of the films that I did haven't been released in this country. ``I did a picture for Vestron called `Hider in the House' (with Gary Busey) that got caught up in the company's bankruptcy. Then I did a film with James Belushi called `To Forget Palermo.' We spent 14 weeks shooting that. It was an Italian-financed film - an English (language) film with an Italian director. That's always a bit of an experiment,'' she said. ``I don't know what happened to it. Maybe American distributors looked at it and thought it wasn't going to make money. Both of those films, I think, have been released internationally but not here. So there's an apparent void that didn't really exist.'' Like her former husband, Mimi (short for Miriam) Rogers had a traveling childhood. Both their fathers were engineers who took jobs all over. Rogers was born in Coral Gables, Fla., but she moved to Virginia, Arizona, Michigan, England and finally Los Angeles. A good student, she graduated from high school at 14, and started acting in her 20s. Her first film was ``Blue Skies Again'' with Harry Hamlin. Her other co-stars include Michael Keaton (``Gung Ho''), Christopher Reeve (``Street Smart''), Tom Berenger (``Some to Watch Over Me'') and Denzel Washington (``The Mighty Quinn''). She usually plays ``the love interest.'' But she hopes that will change as movies take a feminine tilt.
