DOC.HEAD: Jewish Refugees Play Extras in Film About Escape From Denmark
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: For three of the Danish film extras playing Jewish refugees waiting to be shipped to safety in Sweden, the scene gave them an eerie feeling of deja vu. Oskar Kaznelson and his wife, Bella, and Hans Goldstein were among 7,200 Jews smuggled out of German-occupied Denmark in small boats to neutral Sweden under the noses of the Gestapo during the autumn of 1943. Another 464 members of the community were not so fortunate. They ended up in a German concentration camp. Forty-seven years after their dramatic night escape, the Kaznelsons and Goldstein once again were being bundled into fishing boats, standing by to make the risky 10-mile dash across the Oeresund strait to the Swedish coast. But this time they were only playing a scene in a movie, and the gun-wielding youths hustling them below decks were actors playing Danish resistance fighters. ``A Day in October'' began filming at the end of September and is to be finished in November. The script was largely inspired by Leo Goldberger's book, ``The Rescue of the Danish Jews - Moral Courage Under Stress,'' and is being done in English. For the Kaznelsons, their roles brought back memories of their own flight from Denmark in September 1943 when they were smuggled out of Copenhagen. Oskar and Bella Kaznelson were engaged to be married when on August 28-29 1943 there was growing civil unrest in Copenhagen and the Germans took over. The couple fled Denmark on Sept. 12, paying the equivalent of about $1,000 each to be smuggled to the Swedish port of Malmoe. ``When we got to the Swedish side, the first thing that happened was that we were thrown in jail,'' said the 71-year-old Kaznelson. It wasn't until Oct. 1, 1943 that Sweden began accepting Jewish refugees from abroad. After they became legitimate refugees, Oskar joined the Danish Brigade, a group of refugee Danish military officers, policemen and resistence fighters. Bella went to her parents in Gothenburg. They returned to Denmark on liberation day May 1, 1945. Bella is now a dental assistant, and Oskar is sells equipment for the building industry. Goldstein, now a public accountant, came to Denmark from Vienna in 1938. His mother died in Auschwitz, his father survived one of the camps and went to the United States. Goldstein escaped to Sweden by boat, spent two weeks in a refugee camp there and returned in June 1945. He had intended to go to Palestine, but was prevented at the time because of the political situation in the area. So he married a Danish woman and settled down in this country. ``The movie is basically the story of a young Danish resistance fighter who falls in love with a Jewish girl who is being pursued by the Gestapo,'' said Damian Slattery, the American screenwriter. The fictional plot is set against the authentic historical backdrop of occupied Denmark, he said. Goldberger's book contains contributions by American and Danish historians and witnesses of the events in Denmark in 1943. He is the Danish-born son of the former cantor of the main synagogue in Copenhagen, and escaped with his family during the October boat lift. ``The Danes made a fantastic effort. They stood together, they were deeply offended by the deportations and they were able t say what they thought about the Germans,'' Goldberger said. D.B. Sweeney (``Gardens of Stone,'' ``Eight Men Out'') plays the Danish underground leader, and actress Kelly Wolf portrays Sara Kublitz, the hunted girl. Wolf co-starred in ``Triumph of the Spirit,'' about the plight of Jews in war-torn Europe. Daniel Benzali and Tovah Feldshuh play her parents. The movie is directed by Kenneth Madsen, a Dane who has won a Clio Award for his commercials and is making his feature film debut. It is produced by Just Betzer, who made the Academy Award-winning ``Babette's Feast,'' and French videomaker Philippe Rivier.

DOC.HEAD: Term Limits: More Popular as a Concept than a Practice
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: As political punishment, the drive to limit lawmakers' terms and tenure can send them a message without getting personal. And even disenchanted voters seem to prefer it that way. The upstart issue of this campaign, term limits are gaining endorsements from some candidates who see them as hostile to the establishment and to incumbents, few of whom are likely to be ousted by the voters. Term limits offer a way out for voters who tend to favor their own representatives, while complaining about what is happening at the State House or the Capitol. ``People say, `I like my legislator, but not the legislature,''' said John Keast, who tracks referendum issues for the conservative Free Congress Foundation. ``Term limits are a concept rather than a candidate. It's much easier for people to handle.'' A Washington Post-ABC News poll conducted Oct. 14 makes the point in numbers: 63 percent of those surveyed said they disapproved of the way Congress is doing its job - and 64 percent said they approved the performance of their own House member. Despite the voter dissatisfaction reflected in polls, neither party expects major changes in Congress in the Nov. 6 elections. Only two states, California and Colorado, will be deciding in this election whether to restrict terms in office. Oklahoma already has imposed a 12-year limit for state legislators, effective Jan. 1. That measure was approved by two-thirds of the voters in a Sept. 18 primary election. Polls reflect majority support for the other two state measures, but there is an intensive, well-financed campaign against the California limits. It would take a broadened movement with staying power to apply term limits in a way that would force real changes from a system in which incumbency, and the seniority that comes with it, usually rule. Vice President Dan Quayle sees that coming. ``The voters are channeling their discontent into real and lasting reform,'' said Quayle, who is pushing term limits as he campaigns for Republican candidates. ``The people are restless,'' Quayle said. ``This new wave of cynicism has been building for a long time. It should not be discounted. Clearly, term limitation is an idea whose time has come.'' President Bush says he's for term limits, noting that the Republican platform advocates them. While Bush hasn't stressed it as an issue, GOP gubernatorial candidates have in states like Texas, Florida, California and Georgia. For example, as he campaigned with Bush in Dallas on Monday, Clayton Williams said that if he is elected governor, he will push a constitutional amendment for term limits. ``The people in Texas are fed up with the politicians in Austin,'' Williams said. Opponents of term limits argue that career bureaucrats and special interests would become stronger than they already are if legislatures were stripped of their veteran lawmakers. They complain that term limits are an anti-democratic measure because they restrict the choices available to the voters. Advocates concede that point, but say it's a price worth paying for change. While there is some Democratic support for term limit measures, it makes more sense for Republicans. The GOP would benefit from turnover, especially in the House, which has been run by Democratic majorities for 36 years. A constitutional amendment proposed in the Senate early this year would impose a 12-year ceiling on senators and House members, but it is not going anywhere in Congress. So supporters are trying to build pressure in the states. Resolutions advocating congressional term limits have been proposed in at least 29 state legislatures, adopted in only two. Colorado's state measure also would impose a 12-year limit on service in Congress, a provision that certainly would face constitutional challenge in the courts. But measures that apply only to state legislatures could eventually turn up the pressure for action to limit congressional tenure too. ``People rightfully feel that entrenched legislators are only interested in getting re-elected, and I do not think the movement to limit terms will stop at the state level,'' Quayle said in Louisville, Ky., last week. He said it should be extended to cover the House and Senate, where he served 12 years. His first speech as a congressman from Indiana in 1977 was a call for federal term limits. It had been one of his campaign themes in 1976, when he upset a veteran Democrat. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Walter R. Mears, vice president and columnist for The Associated Press, has reported on Washington and national politics for more than 25 years.

DOC.HEAD: Uncertain Project Blooms Into Common-Lanuage Bibles for Russians
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Saturday in 7th graf is Oct. 20.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: When Dale Randolph's organization decided nine years ago to translate the Bible into modern Russian, he had no idea how it could be useful to the Russian people since their country then barred importing Bibles. But that project of uncertain ends has turned out to meet a surprising and newly expanding purpose. ``When we started, I didn't have the slightest idea what we could do,'' he said. ``In those days, it was illegal even to walk around the streets of Moscow with a Bible.'' Despite the uncertainty, the translation work went ahead simply ``in faith,'' without any known, feasible usefulness, he said. But by the time the seven-year job was finished in 1988, he said, ``the doors had swung wide open'' to an immense, pent-up Russian yen for Bibles, a yearning now being served by Randolph's group and other American organizations. Like others, ``I didn't have any idea the situation was going to change,'' he said in an interview. ``The only explanation is that someone other than us was watching over this. Our ministry has been blessed over and over in incredible ways.'' Randolph, president of the World Bible Translation Center in Fort Worth, Texas, said a printing of 100,000 of its New Testaments was scheduled for completion in Moscow on Saturday and would be sold through Soviet bookstores. Printing of an additional 300,000 copies was contracted with a Grand Rapids, Mich., plant as the first part of a goal of 1 million copies to be given free to Russians by year's end. Plans call for handing out a million complete Bibles next year. They will be distributed partly through a branch ``Bible Center'' opened in Moscow this fall as part of the Kuntsevo Cultural Center. ``The demand for Bibles is just incredible,'' said Randolph, who has made five trips to the Soviet Union this year arranging the project. ``When freedom came, it was like a dam had been broken, and the desire came gushing forth. ``The people have been totally starved for the Bible. They've been starved for information about God. Everyone in that country is wanting to know what Christianity is about, from government on down. ``They want to look at what it says about family life, about alcoholism and other problems, to see its answers to life. There is a tremendous hunger for it. The opportunities over there are just benumbing.'' Other agencies also are swelling the flow of Bibles to the Soviet Union, including the American Bible Society in which most denominations participate and the Evangelical Publishers Association in a special ``Moscow Project.'' Those Bibles, however, are in the 17th century Russian ``synodal'' translation, as traditionally used by the Russian Orthodox Church and other Russian-language churches. ``We're the only group providing a modern Russian translation,'' Randolph said. ``We're shooting at the masses. It's not so necessary to reach church people as to reach the man in the street.'' Randolph's organization, which also produces modern translations in other major languages and a simple-English version for the deaf, said two key principles are followed - that the rendering be true to the original Hebrew and Greek and ``be easily understood in the target language.'' Started in 1972, the center is associated with the Churches of Christ, for which Randolph formerly was a missionary in Greece. The staff of about a dozen includes three scholars in Greek and Hebrew, who oversee adherence of the modern-language translations to the original meanings. Shortly after the center completed its Russian New Testament, Randolph got a first-hand sampling of the Russian appetite for Bibles at a Moscow book fair in September 1989. His booth's supply of 10,000 copies was exhausted in one morning, and for the next day and a half, names and addresses were taken of 17,000 other Muscovites wanting Bibles. These later were sent. The center since has completed the entire Bible in modern Russian. Randolph said much of the change in the Soviet Union ``has its roots in religious desires, in a hungering of citizens in that country and most of Eastern Europe to know more about God.'' ``Everthing points to a surge forward of Christianity in that country,'' he said. He said that with the Soviet Union moving toward capitalism, the people may seek to find their answers to life in Western materialism. But there also is a powerful religious base despite 70 years of Communist efforts to eradicate it, he said. ``The Russian Orthodox Church is at a high point of its existence,'' he said, adding: ``The Soviet Union very well may provide a major thrust to Christianity in the years ahead.''

DOC.HEAD: Chevrolet Caprice: Size and Comfort in a New Design
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto, Graphic
DOC.TEXT: Look out, here comes the boat - no, the 1991 Chevrolet Caprice. Look at how it floats across those bumps in the road. Look how those six adults pile in easily on the cloth bench seats front and rear. Look at how the golf clubs, the suitcases, the carts full of groceries all disappear into the massive trunk. It's like looking at a part of Americana. There just aren't many big autos like this left. Big Chevrolets have been part of the General Motors Corp. fleet for decades. Since the 1950s, sales of the middle-America, bread-and-butter cars have totaled more than 38 million. For 1991, GM has redesigned its Caprice and looks for sales of about 200,000 units compared with 150,087 in 1989. Already this calendar year, the new Caprice, which debuted in April, is helping boost sales more than 8 percent above last year's pace. The design and engineering changes include a 5-liter V-8 engine as standard, teamed with a four-speed automatic transmission. The package delivers 170 horsepower and provides for a maximum 5,000 pounds of towing capacity, up 1,000 from the 1990 Caprice. The previous model's 4.3-liter V-6 engine has been dropped. The V-8 performed well in the test drive, though I could feel the shift points during demanding acceleration. Chevrolet reports the Caprice can go from 0 to 60 miles per hour in 10.5 seconds - a respectable showing for a car this size. So was fuel economy at 17 miles per gallon, city; 26 on the highway. GM also boosted safety features in the redesign, installing a driver-side air bag and four-wheel antilock brakes as standard equipment. Suspension provided by four-wheel coil springs was on the mushy side during the test drive, giving a floating feeling as the car hit potholes and bumps on the streets. Outside, the Caprice is rounded, both front and rear. The rear wheel fenders are skirted, adding to the sloping, aerodynamic look. The styling helps take the edge off the largeness of the car, but once you're inside and driving, you're reminded that it's a big automobile: I nearly backed into another vehicle the first time in reverse, being unused to having so much car back there. Inside, there's ample room for six adults. Chevrolet added 3 more inches of shoulder room and 2 more inches of hip room. Because the car retains its rear-drive configuration, the middle person in back must contend with the mid-floor hump. But even with the front seat all the way back and reclined a bit, I could stretch out my legs. The rear shelf below the back window also was one of the largest I've seen. The trunk, with 20.4 cubic feet of cargo space, is so monstrous that a small person might have to climb inside to reach the spare tire. Chevrolet wisely designed the lid so that items do not have to be lifed up and over the body, just over the bumper. Exterior fit and finish was good, though on the test car some of the trunk lining was not attached on one side. Caprice buyers typically have ``a fond place in their hearts for a full-size Chevy,'' said company spokesman David Hudgens. Target buyers for the 1991 model will be younger than previous buyers, who averaged about 62 years of age, Hudgens said. Many past buyers have been retirees, and they used their Caprices for social and recreational trips. ``They're in their middle years and they have time to travel,'' Hudgens said. ``They want comfort and space.'' Today, the company hopes to get more buyers who are in their 40s and 50s, who will use the car for commuting to work, too. Base price for the test car was $16,515. Competitors include the Ford Crown Victoria, which starts at more than $16,600; and the Chrysler New Yorker, which starts at more than $19,000. Consumer Reports magazine lists 1983-85 Caprice models as average in owner reports of trouble. The 1986 model was ranked worse than average and the 1987-88 models were listed as much worse than average. Hudgens said Chevrolet is always trying to improve quality and that production plants are working to get reliability and durability to a world-class level.

DOC.HEAD: New Group Offers Hope for Lima Street Kids
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: The street kids of Lima are called ``piranhas,'' for the Amazon fish that can strip a swimmer of flesh in minutes. They swarm over victims in packs, snatching wallets, purses and jewelry. Freddy lives in University Park, downtown Lima. His clothes are torn and dirty. He has a long, deep, red cut on his right ear, but no open sores on his face like some of the others. He is 11 years old. Like the other kids, Freddy sniffs glue to get high or quiet his hunger. Hundreds of children roam the garbage-filled streets of Lima, willing even to sell their bodies for enough to buy some food and glue. Without help, most probably will die soon or end up in Peru's infamous prisons. ``Many of the kids have venereal disease, some have AIDS and all of them have some kind of skin infection,'' said Dwight Ordonez, head of a project called Ninos de La Calle (Street Kids) that is trying to help. Peru is in its worst economic crisis and thousands of children hustle a living on the streets of Lima, a city of 7 million. Children of 5 or 6 hawk cigarettes, shine shoes or wash cars. Most go home at night, even if home is only a shack. For the hundreds of ``piranhas'' there is no home. They live in parks, plazas, on the river bank behind the Government Palace. Packs of them roam La Parada, a huge food market frequented by drug dealers and prostitutes, and Kennedy Park in Miraflores, a district of nightclubs and luxury shops. The city operates five youth shelters, there are several orphanages and the police have two juvenile detention centers, but the number of children on the street indicates the old system doesn't work. Ninos de La Calle is part of the private, U.S.-financed Center of Information and Education for the Prevention of Drug Abuse. It takes a different approach because ``we are convinced the normal way of working with street kids fails,'' said Ordonez, 30, who has a master's degree in psychology. He said the traditional way is to confine the children, beat them and impose overly strict rules. Ordonez said Ninos de La Calle homes are like ponds next to a river, where the piranhas can swim in, stay awhile and swim out. House rules are fairly simple: No stealing, fighting, breaking things, drugs or sex. Ninos de La Calle has two homes and is building a third. About 55 boys have continuing contact with the group. The project was born in June 1989. Ordonez and other team members spent three months in the streets studying homeless children, and were horrified by what they saw. Lima's street kids, all boys and aged 10 to 16, run in loose-knit gangs of 30 to 50, Ordonez said. All sniff glue, he said, and about 10 percent smoke ``pasta basica,'' semi-processed coca leaf from Peru's Amazon jungle. Project workers won the confidence of the boys, who generally are aggressive and anti-social, by organizing soccer games. Once exposed to the homes set up by Ninos de La Calle, many decided to stay. They even chased away other piranhas who tried to lure them back onto the street with promises of drugs. The homes' biggest attraction seems to be a sense of belonging to a group where someone cares. Ordonez said most of the boys were from poor families, but divorce and abuse drove more of them into the streets than poverty. ``What they need more than anything else is to talk, but it's what they do least,'' said Eduardo Villanueva, 29, a psychologist who has been with the project since it began. One of Villanueva's boys at Miraflores house is Carlos, a lanky 16-year-old with a shy smile. When they first met, Villanueva said, Carlos was always high on glue and had trouble speaking. ``When I was sick, they helped me,'' Carlos said of Ninos de La Calle. ``When I wanted to leave, they invited me to stay.'' After two months at Miraflores, Carlos has begun attending a nearby public school, where he is about five years behind other boys of his age. He said he wants to learn accounting and work in a bank.

DOC.HEAD: Ortega: Revolution Still Possible Despite Collapse of Socialism
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Daniel Ortega, who won international respect by accepting an election defeat, says revolution in Latin America may survive the collapse of European communism, but not if its leaders cling to dogma. Nicaragua's former president said in an interview that injustice and poverty still are problems in the region, providing the fodder of revolution. At 46, with a decade of leadership behind him as head of the Sandinista National Liberation Front, Ortega has abandoned the olive fatigues and black-and-red bandanna of his guerrilla days and years in power. President Bush once compared the outfit to a Boy Scout uniform. Ortega cultivates a youthful image, dressing in jeans and colorful shirts, and remains politically active in Nicaragua and abroad. Young admirers pursue him for autographs when he appears in public. His acceptance of the February election loss to Violeta Chamorro, Nicaragua's new president, improved his image in the world. At home, Ortega has reined in the more radical elements of the Sandinista National Liberation Front. A combination of Ortega's influence and two crippling strikes led by the Sandinistas persuaded the new government to retain many Sandinista programs, including land distribution. ``The reality of Nicaragua is that no one can govern without the FSLN'' he said, using the initials of the Sandinista Front. ``I am sure that our talks with the government and our attempts to reach a consensus have angered some people inside the government, but we think common sense is prevailing.'' Elements of Mrs. Chamorro's fractious coalition accuse her of weakness for dealing with the Sandinistas, who are by far the largest party in Nicaragua and want to be consulted on important economic decisions. The Sandinistas oppose such austerity measures as currency devaluations, reductions in the public payroll and selling nationalized industries back to private investors. Ortega works for the party and travels abroad seeking foreign aid for Nicaragua. He said being out of office allows him more time with his eight children, but that they interfere with a book he is writing on the years in government. Wealthy nations are focusing on their own concerns at the expense of Latin America and other poor regions, Ortega said. ``We will now see an industrialized North, including the former Socialist countries, that will determine the dstribution of the world's technological resources,'' he predicted. ``The problems of the Third World will continue. The industrialized countries of the North have no time to consider our economies or problems in the South.'' U.S. economic assistance to Mrs. Chamorro's government has not met Nicaraguan expectations. About $65 million in cash has been provided since April and an additional $40 million is promised in credits for agricultural development. ``The collapse of the Eastern Socialist bloc gives the United States the hegemonic control that always was its objective in Latin America,'' Ortega said. ``The policies of assistance of the Socialist bloc . . . disappear and they are not compensated by the United States or other industrialized countries. ``This places Latin America at a disadvantage. It does not help our countries. The need for revolutionary change remains. ``We still have a revolutionary movement in El Salvador, and Brazil can explode, too. We have armed groups in Peru and Colombia. What happened in the East does not improve the living conditions of people in the South.'' Washington no longer can accuse all revolutionary movements of being communist, Ortega added, and ``at the same time, the revolutionary movement must rethink the kind of projects and programs they want. In the past there was a tendency to dogmatism.'' ``Our revolution was never subordinated to the Soviet Union,'' he said. ``They offered their support after the victory.'' ``The United States must show respect for Latin America if it wants a world of peace, and Latin America must increase its contacts with sectors of influence in the United States that . . . know the rich will sink if the needs of the poor are not satisfied,'' Ortega said. Of Nicaragua's future and the Sandinista role in it, he said: ``We realize this government came to power with the help of the United States. We accepted the challenge in the elections. ``But the Nicaraguan revolution's changes brought on by the Sandinista Front remain. ``Now the party must change, and adapt to the times. Neither the structure nor the programs of a party are immovable. We now need other forms, although the objectives of ending human exploitation and the principles of justice remain.'' ``We still have a lot to do to emerge from the crisis,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Networks To Share Election Night Exit Polls, Projections
DOC.TEXT: The television networks' race to announce who won on election night is over. And the winner is ... VRS! VRS? This year, for the first time, ABC, CBS, NBC and CNN have put together a single organization - Voter Research and surveys, or VRS - for exit polls and projections. This means two things: The networks will save money, and the main competitive aspect in TV election coverage is gone. ``Of course it's being changed; no question,'' said Warren Mitofsky, executive director of VRS. ``But now I think the networks have an opportunity to compete on a much better playing field. ``Instead of competing about who can come up with numbers first, they can compete on their news coverage. They have a good chance to do their analysis, their interpretation of what it means, and a good presentation.'' VRS will cost each member $3 million through the 1992 fall elections, said Mitofsky. The networks won't say how much they're saving with VRS, but they use the word ``substantial'' most often in their descriptions. ``In this age, nobody wants to lose a lot of money on news, and elections never paid their way,'' said Mitofsky, who led CBS's election unit for 20 years. ``The commercial revenue from election night maybe paid less than a third of the cost. This was a very expensive proposition without much return.'' For $3 million, each network gets exit polls and projections for all Senate, House and governor's races. And they get the same information on a selected few state and local races of national interest, like the Washington mayor's race and California's propositions. ``The numbers will be the same, but how we interpret that information, how we use it, will be different,'' said Mary Klett, NBC's director of elections and polling. VRS has about 55 people working on the 1990 elections, with a permanent staff of about half that, Mitofsky said. VRS absorbed many of its people from CBS' election unit and layoffs from other network election units. In hindsight, the broadcast networks' decision to form VRS seems almost inevitable, given that since 1985 all three have changed hands or leadership. At CBS under Laurence A. Tisch, at the merged Capital Cities-ABC Inc., and at NBC under General Electric, the mandate has been to cut costs. The new arrangment does nothing to prevent any or all of the networks from projecting the winner of a presidential election before polls close in the West; Mitofsky said the only long-term solution to that problem is a federal, uniform poll-closing law. Mitofsky said the old-style competition wasn't more accurate than VRS. All three tended toward more than 99 percent accuracy. With less pressure to be first, the process should be even more accurate, Mitofsky said. ``One of the criticisms of what we're doing is that there'll be no way to correct mistakes,'' said Mitofsky, who for two decades headed CBS' election unit. ``This is absolute nonsense.'' Projections derive from three statistical models. The first and fastest is the exit poll, interviews with voters who have cast their ballots. Then comes the key precinct model, precincts which historically have reflected larger voting trends. And finally there is the county model, where projections are based on actual raw vote totals. ``When you get all done with the three sources of projections, you then end up with the tabulation of the vote,'' Mitofsky said. ``This is a self-correcting process. I don't need to get a phone call from NBC to tell me when I've made a mistake.'' Creating VRS has not been painless. Negotiations began after the 1988 elections and concluded only in February of this year. The VRS questionnaires were designed by negotiation among the network election units. Above and beyond that basic service, VRS participants can buy ``unilateral'' polling and projections. CBS, with The New York Times, has done exactly that, arranging for an independent poll of voter attitudes. There is a precedent for VRS: the News Election Service, the vote-counting pool established by ABC, CBS, NBC, United Press International and The Associated Press in the late 1960s. ``VRS is a collection agency and provides only one projection,'' said Carolyn Smith, head of ABC's election unit. ``VRS provides no analysis. It is up to the individual network to make the proper conclusions and interpretations of the exit polls.'' ``The stuff each network puts out should be more interesting,'' she said, ``because we've been able to spend more time figuring out what we're going to do with this information, instead of being constantly pressured to be `firstest with the mostest.''' ``I assume that the other networks have their own resources and may very well come up with their own conclusions, even to the extent that we may be using a common pool of exit polling,'' said Marty Plisner, executive political director for CBS News and a VRS project overseer. ``The four different networks each have their own style, own people, own signature and, to a considerable degree, their own following,'' Plisner said. ``You'll know whether you're watching CBS or NBC,'' he said. ``Beyond that, there's a lot more to an election than who won and what time you know it.'' The most obvious change for viewers should be the way networks announce the projections. Mitofsky said he has asked the networks to credit VRS. ``I told them they should,'' he said. ``I'd like to think that they will.''

DOC.HEAD: Angry Voters Rebel at the Ballot Box
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: For Boston waitress Nancy Wilson, tables are empty, tips are smaller and taxes are higher. ``I'm an angry voter,'' she says. She is not alone; throughout the recession-struck Northeast, voters are rebelling against ballooning budgets and taxes as the Nov. 6 elections approach. Already, they have drummed out an old generation of political incumbents, some - like Democratic governors Michael Dukakis of Massachusetts, William A. O'Neill of Connecticut and Madeleine Kunin of Vermont - without even casting a ballot. All retired rather than face the wrath of the voters. ``The economic bowling ball has rolled through the Northeast and many political leaders have gone flying,'' says Lee Miringoff, director of the Marist College Institute for Public Opinion in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. What's more, voters in Massachusetts are so mad they are reviving the tax revolt that began in California in the 1970s and spread to Massachusetts in 1980. Voters then radically slashed property taxes levied by town governments and Propositions 13 and 2{ became household words. This time around it's known as ``Question 3,'' a referendum that would roll back increases in the state income tax and some fees imposed over the past two years and eliminate hundreds of new items and services added to the sales tax. ``The message nationally if (it) passes is that the tax revolt is still alive and well ... even in liberal Massachusetts,'' says William Schneider, a political analyst with the American Enterprise Institute in Washington and a visiting professor at Boston College. ``With the deficit crisis in Washington, politicians, even President Bush, assume you can pass new taxes and voters will understand,'' says Schneider. ``So what they're debating is who pays, the middle class, the rich, how the tax burden is distributed. The message will be, `not so fast.' The voters may not be reconciled to tax increases even in the midst of a fiscal crisis.'' The Northeast elections promise to be among the nation's most exciting because of the tax revolt, tough economic times, tight races and the emergence of a new generation of politicians who campaigned as ``outsiders.'' And the election could serve as an informal Democratic presidential referendum for Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York and U.S. Sen. Bill Bradley of New Jersey. Both are expected to be re-elected over weak challengers, but both must win by comfortable margins wo keep their political options open. Cuomo, seeking a third, four-year term, appeared most vulnerable this year. New York's credit rating dropped to the third worst in the nation, only a step above Massachusetts and Louisiana. Cuomo and the state Legislature approved a budget that included a record $1.8 billion tax increase. Still, ``As the bowling ball rolled through the Northeast, Mario Cuomo has remained standing very firmly,'' said Marist College's Miringoff. He said that although Cuomo is not as popular as he was four years ago, he is still within striking distance of his record 65 percent of the vote in 1986. His opponent, Pierre Rinfret, has run a bumbling, ill-financed campaign. This is not a good time for the Northeast. Unemployment rates exceed the national average. Bankruptcy filings and welfare applications have doubled and tripled. Banks have failed. The real estate market has collapsed. Problem loans and repossessed real estate have nearly doubled, to more than $36 billion. Sales tax and other collections fell short of projections, yielding large budget deficits, tax increases and more layoffs. Massachusetts alone had a record deficit of more than $1 billion in the last fiscal year. Three months into the new fiscal year, the budget is still running astray, forcing Dukakis to cut spending by another $500 million - all of this in stunning contrast to the ``Massachusetts Miracle'' that Dukakis boasted of in his failed quest for the presidency. ``It was a miracle that it lasted as long as it did because of a lack of real leadership,'' says Gary Arnold, the owner of Process Control Industries, Inc. in Taunton, a city 35 miles south of Boston whose economic decline was reversed during the boom years. Process Control Industries had 200 employees on its payroll 18 months ago. The work force has been cut in half and Arnold says the company is in a position to move almost at any good opportunity. ``The cost of staying in this state is a key issue,'' Arnold says. ``Obviously that's taxes. I sure hope the state gets managed a lot better. There's no attraction to stay here.'' In September's primary, Arnold and other voters ousted Democratic incumbents linked to the Dukakis administration. Instead, as an independent, he cast his ballot for the Republican gubernatorial candidate, William Weld, who beat his own party's endorsed candidate. Weld, a former assistant U.S. attorney general in the Reagan administration, is in a close race with the Democratic candidate, John Silber, who is on leave as president of Boston University. He, too, defeated the party's endorsed candidate, campaigning as an outsider. Weld supports the tax rollback. Silber opposes it. Supporters say the Dukakis administration increased state spending by 92 percent during the last seven years, almost three times the rate of inflation, and left Massachusetts with the sixth-highest tax burden in the nation. Opponents say the measure would devastate the economy, rolling back $1 billion already collected and spent and costing the state more than $2 billion in the next fiscal year. Domenic Bozzotto he broke ranks with the AFL-CIO and threw the support of his 5,000-member Local 26, Hotel Workers Union of Boston, behind the tax repeal referendum. Even more startling was the union's endorsement of a Republican candidate, Weld, for the first time in its 103-year-old history. ``We never endorsed a Republican candidate for anything, not even dog catcher,'' said Bozzotto, the president of the union. ``Our members and their spouses work two, three, four jobs. An average hotel worker probably makes somewhere around $17,000 to $20,000 a year. If they work one job, clearly they can't survive. If we don't grab these guys by the throat at the Statehouse and make them accountable, it will just be business as usual.'' That same sentiment is echoed in Vermont, where Kunin's predecessor, Republican Richard Snelling, is the favorite with a campaign pegged to the state's faltering economy. He blames Kunin. And in Connecticut, the Democratic Party's two-decade hold on the governor's office is in jeopardy because of the fallout from two years of tax hikes totaling more than $1 billion. The favorite is Lowell P. Wiecker Jr., the former Republican U.S. senator who is running as an independent. Voters in New Jersey have much outrage but little outlet for it. A $2.8 billion tax increase that has made Democrat Jim Florio one of the most unpopular governors in the nation. Florio does not come up for re-election for another three years, and the Democratic Legislature also has a free pass this year. The state constitution has no provision for referendum or recall of elected officials. Bradley's Republican opponent, Christine Whitman, has tried to direct some of the anger at Bradley, demanding that he take a stand on the state tax issue. But Bradley has refused.

DOC.HEAD: ^BOO! A Halloween Treat: TV So Bad It's ... HORRIBLE!!!
DOC.TEXT:
Happy Halloween, viewers. Our topic is bad television. Television that does not create a burden on the viewer's wit and intellect, but induces a vaccuum. This is TV so bad it's ... scary. ``Aaaggggghhhhhhhhh!!!!'' Please. Save your screams for the end. We're talking about TV that represents deformities in the national character; TV that speaks of profound Problems in the Republic. When future historians close the books on our era, they may forgive American culture for the aberrant values implicit in ``The Beverly Hillbillies.'' They'll probably call it ``classic television;'' the French will honor ``Gilligan's Island'' as a work of genius. It already is happening: ```Green Acres' isn't stupid, it's surreal!'' gushed cable's Nickelodeon channel in plugging its revival of the show. That's the strange thing about bad television. It is preserved in reruns until the dignity of age and nostalgia accrete to it. Mediocre TV sinks without a trace; bad TV becomes a ``cultural artifact,'' a precious relic of bygone days. Precious relics of the '70s and '80s? Here's a bottom 10 list, in ascending order of horror:
10. ``THREE'S COMPANY'' - From midseason in 1977 to 1984 this show epitomized the central values of the 1970s, much like disco and leisure suits. It was, and is, appalling. The premise, if that is what it can be called, was that two women and one man (Suzanne Somers, Joyce DeWitt and John Ritter) were capable of hilarious sexual tension and innuendo while chastely sharing an apartment. This menage was acceptable to the Ropers, their virtually impotent landlord and his sex-starved wife, who labored under the misapprehension that the male tenant was homosexual. A laff riot!!! The writing was as predictable as the tides, the conflicts were trivial, the humor sophomoric, and the acting ludicrously bad to non-existent. At a loss for comic ideas, the writers would have Somers sunbathe. When in doubt, jiggle. The show wrecked Somers' career after she made salary demands inconsistent with the producers' estimate of her worth. John Ritter may recover. Joyce DeWitt is a future trivia question. And, it is said, there is always an episode of ``Three's Company'' playing somewhere.
9. (tie) ``THE LOVE BOAT'' and ``FANTASY ISLAND'' - ``Mind candy'' was how these hour-long ABC anthology series were described by their fans. ``Love Boat'' followed a cruise ship and its crew members, with second-tier guest stars occupying three story lines about couples facing various impediments to the course of true love. This show made Barbi Benton a star. It is impossible to convey the unreality of ``Love Boat'' situations and characters, because they obeyed conventions of thought, behavior and dress that existed only on television - sometimes only on ``The Love Boat.'' ``Fantasy Island'' flouted those conventions. Ricardo Montalban played the mysterious host of a resort island where, by magic, his guests lived out their fantasies. It featured comic oddity Herve Villechaize, whose role consisted mainly of croaking, ``Da plane, boss! Da plane!'' ``Love Boat'' picked up fans in syndication after Lauren Tewes (``Hi, I'm Julie, your cruise director!'') was fired because of a raging, debilitating cocaine addiction that remains obvious to even the most casual viewer. It also produced a U.S. congressman, Harvard-educated Fred (``Gopher'') Grandy, R-Iowa.
7. ``HOLLYWOOD SQUARES'' - A panel of celebrities waiting in the interstices of a tic-tac-toe grid! Three in a row and you win! Celebrity quips! Celebrity innuendos! Coached panelists! Dreadful! Still, it was one of the few settings where Liberace seemed to be comfortable, relaxed and spontaneous.
6. ``THE DUKES OF HAZZARD'' - CBS' hugely successful kid program about two vaguely Appalachian, vaguely Southern good ol' boys (Tom Wopat and John Schneider) and their beloved car, the General Lee (440 Dodge Charger, 1969). The plot lines weren't tough to diagram: Conflict. Crisis. Car chase. End of car chase. End of conflict. The slapstick was bad, and the Duke boys' dialogue even worse. Wopat and Schneider complained about the poor quality of the scripts. Nobody cared. The actors claimed they were getting ripped off on merchandising and royalties. Warner Bros. denied it. Wopat and Schneider struck, sued; Warner Bros. countersued and hired replacement Dukes. The show's ratings plummeted, a settlement was reached and Wopat and Schneider returned to the show. The stars' careers have not flourished; Warner Bros. remains in the entertainment business to this day. This show also produced a U.S. congressman - Ben Jones, D-Ga., who played Cooter. Might abysmal television be a breeding ground for federal office? Could a grade-B movie star be elected president? Naaahhh.
5. ``MANIMAL'' - This show about a crimefighter who could change into animals lasted three months on NBC in 1983. (Sample dialogue: ``He's out catting around.'') Arf!
4. ``LOVE CONNECTION'' - Since 1983, the syndicated ``Love Connection'' with host Chuck Woolery has been introducing couples by videotape. This is the spiritual heir to ``The Dating Game,'' where a bachelor or ``bachelorette'' would ask vaguely suggestive questions to a trio of hidden singles. (``Bachelor No. 1, if you were a main dish, what would you be?'') ``Love Connection'' singles audit three videos, select a partner, go out on a date, and agree not to discuss the date until they reappear on national television to discuss it. Uh-huh. If the studio audience picked a different partner, the show offered to pay for a second date with the audience's choice and return again. ``To date,'' the ``Love Connection'' reported this year, ``the show has spawned 17 marriages and seven babies.''
3. ``THAT'S INCREDIBLE!'' - ABC's answer to NBC's 1979 genuinely innovative ``Real People,'' which featured various eccentrics, human interest stories and bits of Americana. ``That's Incredible!'' staged stunts that were incredible, including a daredevil who was severely burned when he ran through a tunnel of fire. Another featured guest, an inventor, later was indicted on federal fraud charges. An expose by TV Guide in 1982 revealed several of the show's stunts were faked, but it didn't leave the air until 1984. That's incredible.
2. ``SUPERTRAIN'' - One of the costliest flops in network history, NBC's 1979 ``Supertrain'' was a huge, nuclear-powered luxury train, a ``Love Boat'' on rails that had a steam room, pool, gym, disco and no discernible ideas. It was laughed off the air after a month, brought back a month later, and finally vanished into Nielsen Gulch.
1. ``TURN-ON'' - Developed in 1969 by ``Laugh-In'' and ``Real People'' creator George Schlatter, ``Turn-On'' was very much in the manner of ``Laugh-In.'' By all accounts, it was far too suggestive for its era, which puts it on the milder side of ``Married ... with Children.'' After one broadcast of ``Turn-On,'' 75 affiliates that had tuned in dropped out. ABC canceled it by the end of the week.
Is there a lesson for the '90s in all this bad television? Yes. We are what we have beheld. You may scream now.

DOC.HEAD: Joe Pantoliano Improves His Reading After Taking up Acting
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Joe Pantoliano of NBC's ``The Fanelli Boys'' says his career nearly ended before it started, when he almost missed out on a role in his high school senior play because of his third-grade reading level. The chance to act, and two dedicated teachers, gave him the motivation to improve his reading skills. ``When I was cast in `Up The Down Staircase,' it was a major victory,'' said Pantoliano, who launched a busy career in movies with that high school play in New Jersey. ``I didn't read well. I was really a bad student. ``When I auditioned for the play, I had a third-grade reading equivalency. I'd memorized the text and made it look like I was reading,'' he said. ``Acting was something I'd always wanted to do but had been afraid of because of the ridicule I'd get from my family and friends - which was soon forthcoming.'' Pantoliano's new comedy series, ``The Fanelli Boys,'' is about a boisterous Italian family of four grown brothers, whose misfortunes send them back to live with their strong-willed mother and to run the struggling family-owned funeral home. Pantoliano plays Dominic, a small-time hustler. ``With `The Fanelli Boys,' they sent me a script, I read it, talked to them, and they offered me the job,'' he said. ``If it was always that easy, I'd like this business. ``Dominic is an entrepreneur, a jack of all trades, a master of none. His role models are Cary Grant and John Gotti. He's the kind of man who would bend the law, but never break it. As we go along, I'm less and less involved in the extracurricular activities.'' Others in the cast are Ann Guilbert as the mother, and Christopher Meloni, Ned Eisenberg and Andy Hirsch as the other brothers. Richard Libertini plays the boys' uncle, a burned-out Catholic priest suffering a mid-life crisis. The setting of the show, which is on Wednesdays opposite ABC's ``Doogie Howser, M.D.'' and CBS' ``Jake and the Fat Man,'' echoes part of Pantoliano's upbringing. He grew up in Hoboken, N.J., where his father worked for 15 years for a funeral home. ``He drove a hearse, picked up bodies and acted as a pallbearer,'' Pantoliano said. A family with problem characters is nothing new for Pantoliano, who said his stepfather was a small-time gangster who served time in prison. ``His father had been a wiseguy, and he aspired to be like him,'' Pantoliano said at his home in the Venice area of Los Angeles. ``He hijacked the Hoboken Ferry once. He was after three liquor trucks on the ferry, but he couldn't get one of the trucks started. So he took the ferry all the way to Poughkeepsie. That made it interstate kidnapping. ``A year later, one of the gang members was busted. He didn't finger my stepfather, but he (the stepfather) still got seven years in prison. When he finally got out of prison, he was 50 and went straight. He warned me never to become a gangster.'' When Pantoliano left high school, he went across the Hudson River and entered acting school in New York City. He landed his first acting job at the age of 19. ``I got $10 a week, and it took $9 a week for food,'' he said. ``I lived over the theater in Compton, R.I. I got little bit parts in movies in New York. I finally moved to Los Angeles because I couldn't get arrested in New York.'' In Los Angeles, he was cast in a series called ``McNamara's Band.'' It folded after three episodes and he was out of work for eight months. Next came ``Free Country,'' which ran six episodes. Then he landed the part of Angelo Maggio in the 1979 miniseries ``From Here To Eternity,'' the role that won an Oscar for Frank Sinatra in 1953. NBC turned ``From Here to Eternity'' into a regular series and offered to revive the role of Maggio - who died in the original - but Pantoliano turned it down. ``They offered me a fortune, but I'd done the role,'' he said. ``I spent the next 12 months working as a waiter in an Italian restaurant. Once I waited on Fred Silverman, the man at NBC I'd said `no' to. I was broke, but even now I don't live extravagantly.'' Pantoliano's first role after that was in the theatrical movie ``The Idolmaker'' - and the first scene was filmed in the same restaurant where he had waited tables. He has worked steadily since, appearing in such movies as ``Risky Business,'' ``Goonies,'' ``Running Scared,'' ``La Bamba,'' ``Midnight Run,'' ``Empire of the Sun'' and ``The Mean Season.'' He's also in the upcoming ``Zandalee,'' with Nicholas Cage and Judge Reinhold, in which he plays a transvestite.

DOC.HEAD: Company Execs Helped Prep FBI Agent to Infiltrate Futures Market
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of Archer Daniels Midland Co. and other company executives helped an FBI agent infiltrate the futures market at the Chicago Board of Trade, the agent testified. Agent Richard Ostrom testified Tuesday in federal court that ADM chairman Dwayne Andreas, President James Randall, Chicago operations chief Thomas Frankel and several other officers of the Decatur-based agricultural giant knew he was an undercover investigator. The company trained Ostrom and gave him his first job among soybean traders now on trial on fraud and racketeering charges, Ostrom testified under cross-examination. In a hearing after jurors were dismissed Tuesday, defense attorney George Collins told U.S. District Judge George M. Marovich that ADM had been especially antagonistic toward the Board of Trade since being fined $25,000 in a dispute over alleged soybean price manipulation. Collins suggested that the opinions of ADM executives may have shaped Ostrom's investigation.

DOC.HEAD: Caterpillar Strikes Huge Deal with Romania
DOC.TEXT: Caterpillar Inc. is cashing in on the end of U.S. trade sanctions against Soviet bloc countries by selling 212 earth-moving machines to the Romanian government for use in coal mining. An analyst said Tuesday the deal could be worth $50 million for Caterpillar and may help the company reclaim Eastern Bloc markets lost to the Japanese during the Reagan administration embargo. ``It's a very significant deal for Caterpillar,'' said Frank Manfredi of Manfredi and Associates, a Buffalo Grove, Ill.-based analyst of the heavy machinery industry. Under a barter agreement announced Monday, Romania will receive 200 articulated dump trucks, 10 track-type tractors, a motor grader and a wheel-loader. The equipment will be delivered during the next nine months, said Jeff Hawkinson, spokesman for Caterpillar, the world's largest manufacturer of earth-moving equipment. ``This will boost Caterpillar's market share considerably,'' Manfredi said. ``It's a pretty big deal when you consider the world market for articulated trucks is about 3,000 units annually and they just sold 200, or about 7 percent of the world market in one deal. That's not bad.'' Caterpillar released few details about the deal. But Manfredi estimated its value at ``approximately $50 million'' based on a price range of $100,000 to $170,000 for articulated dump trucks, commonly used on projects with rough terrain and bad conditions. The huge off-road vehicles are built in two sections and bend in the middle for turning rather than using conventional steering in which the wheels turn from side-to-side. ``Normally, these trucks are not used in mining operations,'' Manfredi said. ``That must mean Romania's roads must be in pretty bad shape around their mining operations.'' Manfredi speculated the 10 tractors are likely large bulldozers worth upwards of $500,000 apiece. And the company usually sends a supply of spare parts in package deals, which would push the value even higher. The cash-poor country will pay for the equipment with unspecified Romanian goods and services. Thaddeus Kopinski, director of the office of Central and Eastern Europe for the U.S. Chamber of Commerce in Washington, said Romania may be paying Caterpillar with fork-lift trucks. ``Romania's chief export item is fork-lift trucks,'' Kopinski said. ``It's part of their material-handling sector and it fits into Caterpillar's profile.'' Manfredi said the barter agreement gives Caterpillar an advantage over competitors who are unable to accept such conditions for sales. ``Prior to the Reagan trade embargo, Caterpillar was the supplier of choice to the Soviet Union and Eastern Bloc countries for years,'' Manfredi said. Caterpillar Chairman Donald Fites told a group of visiting Soviet journalists last month that Caterpillar held 85 percent of the world market of imported mining equipment in the Soviet Union in 1981. Those customers were forfeited to Caterpillar's chief competitor, Komatsu, and other Japanese manufacturers during the embargo. Caterpillar has reclaimed about 50 percent of the lost business, Fites said. Manfrei said the numbers are the same for Eastern Bloc nations such as Romania. Hawkinson said the sale to Romania is the first in more than 10 years for Caterpillar. And he called it one of the company's biggest deals in Eastern Europe in a number of years. Hawkinson said Caterpillar sees Eastern Europe as a market with great potential because of the region's deteriorated infrastructure.

DOC.HEAD: Yeltsin Challenges Gorbachev's New Economic Plan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with Yeltsin comments. No pickup. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's plan for switching to a free-market economy backs away from a 500-day timetable, and Boris N. Yeltsin, leader of the Russian republic, said it was doomed to fail within six months. Gorbachev's 66-page blueprint, delivered to members of the national legislature Tuesday, is at least the fourth in a confusing and complicated series of plans for salvaging the failing economy. ``Another endeavor is thus being made to perpetuate the system hated by the people,'' Yeltsin said Tuesday. ``The new program is a catastrophe which will break out within the first few months.'' ``If the ... Parliament approves today's uncompromising program, it will take less than six months to realize that the chosen road is another blunder.'' A text of Yeltsin's remarks to the Russian Federation's legislature was published today in Sovietskaya Rossiya, the Russian Communist newspaper. Gorbachev's plan would give the 15 Soviet republics sweeping new powers to run the nation's economy, free many prices from government regulation and allow private ownership of businesses. It sets no timetable for the transition, but notes other nations have accomplished similar goals in 1{ to two years. Gorbachev is to present his plan to the Supreme Soviet national legislature on Friday, and the 542 members could vote on it as early as Saturday. Parliamentary committees began studying the proposals today. Yeltsin, president of the Russian republic, and the federation's other leaders have endorsed a radical plan for scrapping Communist central planning for a market-based economy in 500 days. Yeltsin said the Russian republic could go ahead with that program on Nov. 1, setting up its own currency, customs service and army. He acknowledged this would be difficult and costly, even for the biggest and wealthiest of the 15 Soviet republics, but said: ``If we show indecision in such a situation, we will lose the voters' trust and respect.'' ``If we procrastinate and put off (the reform) further, there will be nothing to reform because the economy will simply fall to pieces,'' he said. Yeltsin said Gorbachev's program, if adopted, would increase the national budget deficit to about $528 billion. ``The consumer market inevitably will be swamped by a shower of paper (money) and prices may grow dozens of times,'' he said. The plan Yeltsin has endorsed is named after its chief architect, economist Stanislav Shatalin. It differs from Gorbachev's plan in several key respects. The Shatalin plan suggests selling factories to private owners, breaking up collective farms and returning land to peasants, but the Gorbachev plan drops a clear commitment to private ownership of land. It says only that republic authorities will decide conditions for giving land to people for agriculture. The Shatalin plan would also gradually end all state control on prices. Under the Gorbachev plan, the government would still set prices in 1992 on bread, meat, dairy products and a few other staples. Yeltsin said the Gorbachev plan was an attempt ``to preserve the administrative-bureaucratic system.'' The proposal caps an intensive three-week effort by Gorbachev and top economists to resolve fundamental differences over how to change a system that fails to provide adequate food, shelter and services for the country's 285 million people. Differences among competing economic plans have touched on the very underpinnings of Soviet communism: socialist property, collective labor and state ownership of all land. ``People's lives are becoming more difficult, their interest in labor is falling, their faith in the future is crumbling,'' the Gorbachev plan says. It says the long lines in which Soviet shoppers must stand daily are a ``shame,'' and acknowledges rising food prices, overcrowded apartments and empty store shelves. But it hesitates to move ahead too quickly with reform, stating: ``The experience of applying stabilization programs in other countries ... shows that such a period can take about 1{ to two years.'' Gorbachev's compromise package, however, borrows heavily from the Shatalin plan in giving republics more economic power. Under Gorbachev's plan, republics would gain control of most of the resources on their territory. After delegating much economic power to republics, businesses and individuals, the central government would concentrate on defense, energy, highways, railroads, space exploration and communications. Gorbachev originally supported the Shatalin plan which was to have gone into effect Oct. 1, ``but the sinking union (national) government put pressure on the president, and he again changed his mind,'' Yeltsin said.

DOC.HEAD: OPEC Leader Criticizes Oil Consumers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subroto without first name is CQ.
DOC.TEXT: A top official of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries strongly criticized oil consuming countries on Wednesday for failing to release oil reserves to help curb rising oil prices. OPEC Secretary General Subroto said consumer countries have been reminded that it might be too late to keep oil prices within reasonable bounds if they waited until the fourth quarter of the year to release their strategic stocks. ``Unfortunately, these appeals proved fruitless. This is a great pity, and a clear indication that ... The concept of real cooperation between producers and consumers for oil market stability still seems to fall on the deaf ears of the majority,'' Subroto said. He said that OPEC has already acted to reduce the danger of an oil shortage by pumping out as much oil as it can. ``The ball is now in the consumers' court: it is now up to them to bolster the market's defense against an impending energy shortage by drawing down on their stocks,'' he told an international energy conference in Jakarta. Paul Vlaanderen, representative of the International Energy Agency, told the conference earlier that its analysis showed that world crude oil markets are still adequately supplied and no product shortfalls have been experienced by its members. Vlaanderen said the agency acknowledged that the oil markets are nervous in the wake of Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, but the situation still is manageable. He said prices are fluctuating based upon fears of war or hopes for peace in the Persian Gulf and the current strains on the oil system are unlikely to be remedied by a simple drawdown of IEA strategic stocks. ``It is a political phenomenon and not a supply-demand fundamental which drives the market. Physical shortages do not explain present price fluctuations,'' he said. Subroto told the conference that OPEC's total sustainable production capacity would increase from the current 28 million barrels to 34 million barrels a day in 1995. He said non-OPEC production would remain unchanged or fall slightly by the end of century and oil supply from the Communist countries would decline, largely because of lower Soviet production and higher consumption in China. Demand for OPEC oil increased from 15.45 million barrels a day in 1985 to 21.91 million barrels in 1989. This year, the figure is expected to reach 23 million barrels. Helga Steeg, executive director of the International Energy Agency, said member countries of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development would grow more dependent on imports due not only to rising oil demand but also to a decline in their oil production. Mrs. Steeg said in a prepared statement that OECD's dependence on imports could rise from 53 percent in 1988 to 70 percent by 2005. The OECD members include the United States, Germany, Japan and other industrial nations.

DOC.HEAD: From Blades To Shades, Forschner Group Expands Product Line
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto HF1 of Oct. 16
DOC.TEXT: The company that brought the all-purpose Swiss Army pocketknife to America is now offering products that do more than open wine bottles, strip wire or gut fish. Forschner Group Inc., the U.S. distributor of the multiblade red knives with silver crosses, has expanded into the sunglass and watch business with its new subsidiary, Swiss Army Brands Ltd. The company is banking on consumers' familiarity with the Swiss Army name to get these products off the ground. ``There is a high-quality imagery associated with the knife,'' said Forschner President James Kennedy. ``It has always been known as a useful, utilitarian product and we were able to transfer that to the watch's image.'' Sales of the Swiss Army Brand watch totaled around $4 million since its debut last fall, double the projections, said Kennedy. The simple watch with a large face, big numbers and black strap was designed in the United States and manufactured in Switzerland. It sells for $95 retail. The Swiss Army Brand aviator-style sunglasses were introduced in April and sell for around $115 retail. But sales have been disappointing thus far, totaling just $385,000 in the first nine months of this year. Kennedy said the glasses came out too late to be included in many retailers' summer catalogs. The new products are targeted at upscale, outdoorsy types who frequent camping and hunting stores. The company does minimal advertising and its products are sold by exclusive retailers such as Hoffritz for Cutlery, Eddie Bauer and Hammacher Schlemmer. The Swiss-based Victorinox Cutlery Co., founded in 1884 by Karl Elsener, developed the original Swiss Army knife in 1891. Its patent on the pocketknife expired in 1908, and since then, many imitations have surfaced. About half the soldiers in the Swiss Army carry Victorinox knives. The rest are manufactured by their rival, Wenger, which also sells Swiss Army knives in the United States through retailers like K Mart and L. L. Bean. Victorinox makes 295 different models of the knife, but Forschner sells only about 50 in the United States. The ``Scientist'' model features a magnifying glass, while the ``Tinker'' contains two can openers and a Phillips screwdriver. A saw, pliers, scissors and a file are part of the ``Craftsman.'' Forschner became a distributor for the pocketknives shortly after World War II. The company started out 135 years ago in New Britain selling only butcher scales. In the 1930s, it added Victorinox butcher knives to its line. The butcher knives, sold almost exclusively to slaughterhouses and restaurants, accounted for 27 percent of Forschner's business last year. Another 23 percent came from Swiss Army knives printed with corporate logos. The other half came from the pocketknives. When Kennedy came to work at the company in 1975, it decided to stop selling butcher scales and to halt sales of the pocketknives to its 40 wholesaers. Forschner began selling the pocketknives directly to specialty retail stores. Imitation knives have plagued Forschner for years, but when knockoffs of the watches started showing up in stores for $20-$25, the company took immediate action against some Asian manufacturers for violating trade laws. Since the knockoffs were not manufactured in Switzerland, the companies making them were not allowed to call them Swiss-style or Swiss-like and were prohibited from using the trademark Swiss Cross. Such restrictions also have limited Forschner's growth. ``We have to have all our products made in Switzerland, where the factories are small, inefficient and expensive,'' Kennedy said. He added that the strength of the Swiss franc has added to his purchase price. Nonetheless, in the past 16 years, Forschner's profits have grown 4,000 percent. Last year, Forschner sold $33 million worth of knives, up from less than $1 million in 1974.

DOC.HEAD: No Smoking Gun in Wickes Allegation; Government Moves On
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf pvs, `U.S. District. . . to CLARIFY judge's comments; PICKS UP 8th graf pvs, `Wood ordered. . .
DOC.TEXT: After failing to offer hard evidence that Michael Milken masterminded a 1986 stock manipulation, prosecutors will move to a second transaction they say paints the junk bond king as a rampant criminal. Milken, 44, has pleaded guilty to six felony counts related to illegal trading, but the government wants to demonstrate he deserves a long prison term for allegedly engaging in broader lawbreaking during his career. Testimony concluded Tuesday without a smoking gun that Milken ordered Wickes Cos. stock manipulated upward in April 1986 via large purchases by former speculator Ivan Boesky. Legal experts said the government's case so far was surprisingly weak even though there is a lower burden of proof in the hearing than a trial. Wickes was prosecutors' first choice for proving the extra wrongdoing by Milken. ``What really puzzles me is why the government didn't anticipate this was going to be a letdown and choose some other transactions and witnesses,'' said Alan Bromberg, a securities law professor at Southern Methodist University. ``It strikes me the government may be caught up in the web of its own conspiracy theory - that everything that happened was part of this grand conspiracy between Milken and Boesky,'' he said. U.S. District Judge Kimba Wood appeared skeptical of aspects of the government's case. ``Fairly ambiguous'' is how she described orders allegedly made by Milken to manipulate Wickes as described by a former Drexel trader. Wood ordered the pre-sentencing hearing to gain greater insight into Milken's character before she decides his punishment. He has agreed to pay $600 million in penalties and faces up to 28 years in prison. The proceeding marks the first test of the government's evidence against Milken after a four-year pursuit of the former Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. financier that included a 98-count racketeering and fraud indictment. At the end of testimony Monday, Milken lawyer Arthur Liman suggested calling off the rest of the hearing because it only was polarizing the case and not helping Wood fashion a sentence. Courtroom observers said Liman was satisfied with the defense on Wickes and may have been seeking an end before the second and third alleged illegal transactions against Milken are aired. But Judge Wood said: ``So far the hearings have been very helpful to the court. They are filling a certain type of void. Although I am questioning the government closely, at this point I haven't reached any conclusions.'' The government's case in Wickes hinged on the testimony of a former Drexel trader who claimed Milken was involved in manipulating Wickes. But the trader and two other government witnesses offered no direct connection between Milken with Boesky. Assistant U.S. Attorney John Carroll asserted that given the nature of Milken's other admitted schemes with Boesky he was linked to the Wickes manipulation. Wood dismissed that argument. The government's case now shifts to two other transactions from its 132-page pre-sentencing memorandum that portrays Milken as a greedy cheater. The defense claims his crimes involved isolated instances of going too far to help clients and they have requested no prison time. The hearing is to resume Thursday with testimony on allegations of misappropriations and bribery in securities of Storer Communications Inc. in 1985. The third transaction alleges insider trading in securities of Caesar's World Inc. in 1983. On Tuesday, the government implied but offered no proof that the prospect of multimillion-dollar fees may have motivated Milken and Drexel to break the law to help Wickes retire an expensive preferred security. Under questioning by Carroll, former Drexel corporate finance executive Joseph Harch said there ``were many positives'' to retiring the costly preferred stock issue. But Harch, testifying for the defense, said Wickes Chairman Sanford Sigoloff never asked Drexel to buy Wickes stock to push up its price and Milken never told him any such activity would occur. Harch said Drexel did not undertake any financing solely to preserve Wickes as a client. Former Drexel trader Peter Gardiner testified Monday that Milken asked traders to find buyers for Wickes and said to him, ``Peter, Wickes, 6[.'' Gardiner said he interpreted that as an order to close the stock at that level. Liman conceded Wickes was manipulated but said Milken played no role.

DOC.HEAD: Txas Instruments Lay Off 450
DOC.TEXT: Texas Instruments Inc. has laid off 450 defense employees as part of the company's yearlong plan to reduce costs. Texas Instruments officials announced in June they would fire 1,000 of the 22,000 workers at the Defense Systems & Electronics Group over the next 12 months. Company spokeswoman Terri West said Tuesday's layoffs bring the total to about 950 employees fired so far. ``They (layoffs) are in response to constraints on national defense spending,'' Ms. West said. Texas Instruments' defense division generates about $2 billion of the company's $6.5 billion annual revenue. Of the 450 workers notified Tuesday, 380 worked in Texas with 165 employed in Dallas. Other fired TI workers were employed mainly in either California or Colorado, Ms. West said. Those affected by the announcement will receive severance pay and insurance benefits for 60 days. All laid off workers will also receive help from the company's job placement office, Ms. West said. Dallas-based Texas Instruments, the second largest U.S. semiconductor manufacturer, employs about 73,000 workers worldwide.

DOC.HEAD: Businessman Reports Strong Response to Request for Highway Loan
DOC.TEXT: A Hong Kong businessman announced Wednesday he has received a strong response from bank lenders to a request for an $800 million loan to finance the construction of a superhighway in southern China. The loan would be one of the biggest since the June 4, 1989, military attack on pro-democracy demonstrators in Beijing, which resulted in a drastic decline in foreign lending for China-based business plans. Gordon Wu, managing director of Hopewell Holdings Ltd., said documents have been given to 20 local and foreign banks to solicit funds and initial responses had been ``overwhelming.'' ``We have no problem at all in getting the money. Now we have to persuade some banks to give us less,'' he said. Wu declined to identify the participating banks, but said half are Japanese. Nor would he disclose the pricing terms although it was believed that the loan's interest rate will be substantially above the London Interbank Offered Rate, the rate banks in London charge each other for dollar-denominated loans. Wu said the breakdown of the banks would be announced later this month. The 12-year syndicated loan is regarded as one of the barometers of foreign banks' confidence in China because of its size and long term commitment. Since June of last year, most major foreign banks have suspended medium to long term loans to China due to the uncertain political outlook in the mainland. Loans that have been given have been generally done in consortium, like Hopewell's loan, because bankers remain wary. Earlier this year, the the Mitsubishi Trust and Banking Co. arranged a $126 million loan. The 143-mile highway, linking the southern Chinese city of Canton and its neighboring boom towns of Zhuhai and Shenzhen, would take four years to complete and the first section between Canton and Shenzhen would be completed within a year, Wu said. With a total investment of $1.2 billion, he said the highway would help to ease already heavy traffic among the three cities, considered to be the richest in China. Wu said he has encountered no difficulty so far in the project apart from securing land for construction work. China's Bank of China and this British colony's Hongkong and Shanghai Corp. are responsible for the underwriting arrangements, and Wu said Japanese banks had so far indicated their readiness to provide more than half of the $800 million.

DOC.HEAD: Profit Rises 17.5 Percent in Third Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Union Pacific Corp. on Wednesday reported a 17.5 percent increase in its third-quarter profit, spurred by record carloadings on its railroad subsidiary. Net income was $161 million, or $1.61 per share, for the three months ended Sept. 30, up from $137 million, or $1.35 per share, a year earlier. Revenue rose 17.1 percent to $1.85 billion from $1.58 billion during the third quarter of 1989. Union Pacific Railroad's earnings rose 4 percent to a record $148 million, despite a $17 million increase in fuel prices. Overall freight traffic gained 7 percent to 1.08 million carloads, the highest for any quarter in the company's history. The railroad had 1.01 carloads during last year's third quarter. Coal loadings were up 10 percent; autos, 13 percent; food products, 14 percent; and containers and trailers, 8 percent. Forest products were down 3 percent, the only slippage among major commodities. Higher crude prices related to the Persian Gulf crisis helped boost earnings 11 percent for Union Pacific Resources, a natural resources subsidiary. For the year's first nine months, Union Pacific said profits totaled $442 million, or $4.41 a share, up 3.3 percent from $428 million, or $3.98 a share, in 1989. Revenue for the nine months rose 12.8 percent to $5.36 billion from $4.75 billion.
