DOC.HEAD: Former Stock Exchange Chairman Convicted on Corruption Charges
DOC.TEXT: Ronald Li, former chairman of the Hong Kong Stock Exchange, was convicted Wednesday in the High Court on corruption charges. A seven-member jury deliberated for more than 10 hours before convicting Li of accepting preferential offerings of shares in Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd. and Novel Enterprises Ltd. in 1986 and 1987 in exchange for helping to obtain listings on the market for the companies' shares. Li, 61, had pleaded innocent to the charges. The jury convicted Li by a margin of 5-2, sufficient in Hong Kong to find a defendant guilty. He faces a maximum penalty of seven years in prison and $64,000 in fines on each of two counts. Li was a powerful figure in this British colony's stockbroking community for two decades. In the trial, Michael Kalisher, the lead prosecutor, described Li as the patriarch of an exclusive society funded by friendly merchant bankers. ``It was a very cozy little club,'' he said in court. He alleged Li made more than $100,000 in profits by selling the shares he was awarded. In defense, Li compared himself to the owner of a restaurant who knows what the meals are but not how they are prepared. Li was instrumental in merging the colony's four exchanges into the Hong Kong Stock Exchange four years ago, turning the stock market of this British colony into one of the most dynamic in the world. His decision to close the exchange for four days during the world stock market crash in October of 1987 led to calls for his resignation. He stepped down as chairman of the exchange one month before he was arrested in January 1988. Between Li's arrest and his appearance in court, prosecutors dropped 13 charges lodged against him under the colony's Bribery Prevention Ordinance because of lack of evidence. Li faces other charges along with seven former members of the exchange scheduled to be tried in February.

DOC.HEAD: Senate, White House Agree on Child Care; House Balks
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS first three grafs to UPDATE with White House comments, picks up 3rd graf, bgng ``A second . . . Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The White House today urged the House to overcome its objections to Senate-passed legislation providing child care assistance to low income families, and to endorse the Senate version. The latest Senate version, unveiled by Democratic and Republican leaders Tuesday, is a five-year, $15 billion package. Most of the money would go for an expansion of earned income tax credits for low-income working families with children. ``This is a great step forward for parents, child care and education. We urge the House to pass it in its current form,'' said President Bush's press secretary, Marlin Fitzwater today. A second element is a new program of grants to the states, which would pass the money along to child-care centers or directly to families to offset part of their child care costs. Church-run centers would be eligible for the federal aid. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, and Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., described the package as a compromise that has President Bush's support, and said it would break a long deadlock over the child care bill. But House members were excluded from negotiations with the White House over the package, and the latest version fell short in scope and spending from a version passed earlier this year by the House. At least one key House sponsor said he would not go along with the Senate's deal. ``There are enormous differences,'' said Rep. Tom Downey, D-N.Y. Dole, in response, said the House would be to blame if child care fails to pass. ``Now it's time for the House to join the Senate and the White House so this priority legislation doesn't die before Congress adjourns,'' he said. Federal child care assistance was backed by both presidential candidates in 1988, but the issue has been stuck in conference committees since clearing the House and Senate. With Congress nearing adjournment and consumed by deficit-reduction battles, the outlook for a child-care bill had appeared to be worsening. Part of the new agreement is a strategy to bypas the deadlocked House and Senate conferees, who have been unable to resolve differences. Mitchell said the bill would be included in the Senate's budget deficit-reduction bill - adding child care to the tax-increase and spending-cut package that Congress is trying to pass before a midnight Friday deadline. Downey, however, said the House would resist that move. Under the new agreement, grants to the states for aid to families with child-care costs would amount to $2.5 billion over three years, compared with $6 billion over five years in earlier versions. Downey said the Senate's plan was inadequate and that twice as much was needed. The Senate bill also includes licensing, health and safety requirements for day-care centers - although they are weaker than those the House was seeking. The measure authorizes the grants to the states as a separate program requiring yearly appropriations. House backers - fearing child care would suffer in the yearly competition for money - had rejected that approach in favor of making it an entitlement program under the Social Security Act so it would be automatically included in the budget annually. Also excluded from the Senate-White House version is a section in the House bill providing money to help local governments establish or expand child-care programs based in the public schools. The new version would earmark a quarter of the grants to be used for early childhood education and before- and after-school child care services. The agreement has the support of the Children's Defense Fund, an advocacy group that has pushed for child care and which has battled the House leadership over the method. ``This is a start, a beginning of a federal child-care program that provides a strong base on which to build,'' said Helen Blank, lobbyist for the fund.

DOC.HEAD: DuPont Uses Endurance Tests To Develop Teamwork
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto WIL1 of Oct. 16
DOC.TEXT: Helmeted and harnessed, Du Pont Co. workers grunt, groan and sweat as they scale a 40-foot wall, climb a skinny 30-foot pole and zip down a 300-foot wire. They cheer each other on with shouts of ``You can do it!'' ``We're behind ya!'' ``How do you feel?'' With a break for a brown-bag lunch, they've finished the first half of the day-long ``Ropes Course'' - the introduction to Du Pont Fibers Department's ``Playing to Win'' seminars and empowered learning teams. The idea is to keep fibers competitive and increase productivity of employees who can work better with supervisors and each other, said Clifford E. Nix, fibers development director. The company is spending at least $23 million on the effort. It paid $1.3 million for the 45-acre campsite on the Elk River in northeastern Maryland. It leases resorts for fibers employees to take the same training at two sites in North Carolina, and one in Virginia and Tennessee. All of the sites are near Du Pont fibers plants. The seminars - four days for managers and two days for employees with their managers - are similar to the wilderness training courses that became popular among corporate executives in the 1980s. But Du Pont's program, which began about four months ago, is unique because it is in-house and is required for all 20,000 employees in the fibers department, which makes polyester, nylon, spandex and other materials. The company has contracted with Pecos River Learning Centers, of Santa Fe, N.M., to provide the training. ``What we want to create is (a work) environment where people's values can truly be expressed with the team, and having an environment where those values can be brought to the surface and having the freedom to express that,'' Nix said. That means changing management style. ``The key to the success of this whole effort is the willingness of the leadership to embrace change themselves. There's room for change, but the leadership has to let go and shift our behavior and our roles as leaders in the organization,'' Nix said. ``There have been a lot of companies experimenting with what we call employee involvement programs . . . It's based upon an established theory that if employees are involved in the decision-making process, morale and productivity will go up,'' said Douglas M. McCabe, a labor relations expert and professor at Georgetown University in Washington. James H. Wilbur, a securities analyst with Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co., said the timing is right because fibers earnings are likely to fall short of last year's. ``So if you can get the people to work together and be productive, it couldn't come at a better time than when things are tight.'' He said earnings in the fibers department - which represent nearly a quarter of Du Pont's total profits - have been hurt by a rise in foreign competition and raw materials costs. The division's first quarter profit fell to $168 million from $173 million last year. Second quarter earnings dropped to $157 million from $182 million. Miles Overholt, a management consultant and family therapist, said the program can be successful if Du Pont sustains enthusiasm among its employees. ``Any kind of program that's out on the market now, such as Pecos River, are great as a kick-off because the message is clear. It's direct, it's concise. The hard part is continuing it,'' said Overholt, president of Applied Organizational Development Inc., of Palmyra, N.J. McCabe, of Georgetown University, said the new approach can be sustained only if ``top management is totally dedicated to the proposition of employee involvement.'' ``Trust has to be a very strong value of the organization. Trusting each other in that work environment. Industry as a whole has got to embrace that value,'' Nix said. When the training began, employees were skeptical and it was difficult to get them to attend. Now, the courses are booked through June 1991. More than 3,000 employees have been trained at the sites since the first one opened in June in Virginia at Natural Bridge. ``Each week that goes by, my conviction grows. It's much different today than the way I felt in May or June. You wondered if people were going to get on the bus'' to go to the sites, Nix said. ``People who haven't gone through it generally don't know what to think of it. Those who have gone through it, there has been a good response,'' but there still appears to be a wait-and-see attitude, said Nancy Tidona, Du Pont spokeswoman. Nix said the teams will continue training with 10 four-hour seminars in the workplace spread over 18 months after visiting the wilderness site. When the entire department has completed all of the training, he said, he expects fibers to be in ``a more competitive position for the future. I expect more unity and more productivity.'' But the program hasn't been without its problems. George W. Martin, a 58-yera-old plant supervisor, died of a heart attack in September after completing one of Ropes Course activities. Nix said the only other accident has been a sprained ankle. Employees with medical problems are excused from the exercises, he said. After each activity, the teams are debriefed to discuss how the activity relates to their work. The concept behind three people hooked together to scale a 40-foot wall is to make a group decision on whether to make it to the top. There should be no hard feelings if a member does not want to go on, Tidona said. ``You can only go as far as your weakest team members,'' she said. ``I expect when it's all over I'll probably be a little more open with my peers and be more supportive of others,'' employee Richard Block said, on the first day of a recent four-day seminar.

DOC.HEAD: Coca-Cola Co. Earnings Up 9.1 Percent for Quarter
DOC.TEXT: The Coca-Cola Co. reported Wednesday its third-quarter earnings rose 9.1 percent as it chalked up sales gains around the world Coca-Cola said it earned $394.2 million, or 58 cents per share, up from $361.3 million, or 51 cents per share, in the same period a year earlier. Revenue totaled $2.8 billion, up from $2.2 billion. The company reported its soft drink sales rose in the United States and overseas. Coca-Cola Foods, which includes Minute Maid juice brands, reported a rebound in sales in the third quarter following a drop during the first half of 1990. Sales had fallen sharply due to the freeze that damaged the Florida citrus crop. For the first nine months of the year, Coca-Cola said its net income reached $1.09 billion, or $1.60 a share, up 12.5 percent from $966.6 million, or $1.36 per share, in the first three quarters of 1989. Nine-month revenue totaled $7.68 billion, up from $6.45 billion a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Former Vernon S&L Owner's Trial on Bank Fraud Begins
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 4 grafs to UPDATE with jury selection under way, tentative early timetable of trial, Dixon quote. Picks up 3rd graf pvs: `Prosecutors say ... Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Donald Ray Dixon, whose involvement in one of the biggest and most lurid thrift collapses in history has been overshadowed by the cases of Neil Bush and Charles Keating, is getting his day in court. Jury selection began today for the former owner of Vernon Savings and Loan Association, which went under in 1987 at a cost of $1.3 billion. He is charged with conspiracy, misapplication of funds and other crimes. Jurors should be picked within two days, and lawyers are expected to make opening statements Friday. Testimony is set to begin Monday and continue three to four weeks. ``Perhaps when my day in court comes, if they'll listen, they'll find out what really happened and the blame can be properly assessed and properly assigned,'' Dixon has said. Prosecutors say Dixon, 50, spent hundreds of thousands in thrift money on yachting and hunting trips, worldwide travel to gourmet restaurants, antique cars, a California beach house, prostitutes and contributions to politicians. Dixon has said the government is trying to make him a scapegoat for the nation's S&L scandal. Until the recent notoriety given Bush and Silverado Savings and Loan in Colorado, or Keating and Lincoln Savings and Loan in California, Dixon and Vernon were at or near the top of the list of alleged abuses cited in the industry. Regulators have accused President Bush's 35-year-old son and other Silverado directors of negligence. Keating faces criminal and civil charges from his involvement at Lincoln. If convicted on all counts, Dixon could get 190 years in prison and $9.5 million in fines. Twelve other Vernon executives and associates have been convicted; the verdicts against two of them have been set aside. Dixon lived lavishly, traveling the world for gourmet parties and acquiring along the way such playthings as a 17th Century castle door, Baccarat crystal, sculptures, a silved-studded saddle and a posh house near San Diego. The government says those luxuries, as well as payments to political campaigns and to prostitutes who allegedly entertained Vernon executives, were financed from the vaults at Vernon, which owned a yacht and five planes worth $6 million.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Approves Civil Rights Bill
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS one graf after 2nd graf, bgng ``I am,'' to UPDATE with Fitzwater reiterating veto threat; pick up 3rd graf, bgng ``The Senate . . . Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Civil rights leaders plan a fresh appeal to President Bush after a major bill to combat job discrimination cleared the Senate, but without the support needed to overcome his threatened veto. ``I am convinced this bill will have the effect of forcing businesses to adopt quotas in hiring and promotion,'' Bush said Tuesday. He said that if the measure reached his desk, he would ``be compelled to veto it.'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater reiterated that position today, saying the bill ``is neither sound nor practical'' and would have the effect of forcing businesses to adopt quotas in hiring and promotion. The Senate on Tuesday night approved the measure, 62-34, short of the two-thirds support that sponsors would need to override the threatened veto. Fifty-three Democrats and nine Republicans joined in supporting the measure, while 34 Republicans were opposed. Civil rights forces said they could count on the votes of three absent senators and thus needed only two more to reach the 67 required for an override. But the roll call revealed that despite many concessions they had gained no new support since July 18 when an earlier version cleared, 65-34. The House was due to vote today on the bill, which would effectively overturn six Supreme Court decisions handed down last year. It has been the civil rights movement's top piority on Capitol Hill in recent months. Provisions range from a ban on racial harassment in the workplace to punitive damages in extreme discrimination cases. The major controversy, though, is over proposed changes in complex court rules governing job discrimination lawsuits. The changes would make it easier for those filing suit to win and harder for employers to defend themselves. The administration and business critics of the bill say employers would adopt quotas as a ready-made defense in case they were taken to court. Sponsors of the bill scoff at this notion. Civil rights leaders who visited with Bush in May in an effort to reach a compromise plan to ask for another chance to make the pitch for the bill and head off a veto. ``This is going to be a defining issue for the Bush administration and civil rights,'' said Ralph Neas, executive director of the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights. He said a veto could resemble the ``Bob Jones University fiasco,'' in which a storm erupted the Reagan administration's move to grant tax-exempt status to that institution despite charges that it practiced discrimination. Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., said, ``I believe there is a good chance that President Bush will sign this bill. But if he vetoes it, I think there is a good chance Congress will override the veto.'' Sen. Arlen Specter, R-Pa., who voted for the bill, held out hope that even after months of disagreement the administration and sponsors could reach a compromise. He said talks were getting under way again. A summer of negotiations that were revived briefly in September have produced nothing. Some lawmakers believe Bush will opt to ``pocket veto'' the bill, allowing it to die for lack of a signature after Congress adjourns and leaves Washington for the campaign trail. Both sides in the debate have acknowledged that the sheer complexity of the measure has led to confusion. ``It is not ... a battle between David Duke and the rest of us for the soul of the Republican Party,'' Sen. John C. Danforth, R-Mo., said. ``It is a quibbling over words that lawyers have been involved in.'' Sen. Howard M. Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, was critical earlier of Republicans for opposing the bill. ``Is this the Republican Party of Abraham Lincoln?'' he said. ``Or is this the Republican Party of David Duke?'' GOP lawmakers winced at the mention of Duke, a former Ku Klux Klan leader and current Louisiana state legislator who counts himself as a Republican even though GOP officials have taken enormous pains to repudiate him. ``I think bringing in David Duke is hitting below the belt a bit,'' said Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah. Metzenbaum came back to the floor contritely later and said it had been ``inappropriate and improper'' to associate Republicans with Duke.

DOC.HEAD: Copper Hits Two-Year Low on Prospect of Oversupply
DOC.TEXT: The price of copper fell Wednesday to its lowest level in two years on worries about future oversupply. ``Adequate supplies and the belief that the United States and some of the other main copper-consumer countries are heading for recession are behind the setback,'' said Neil Buxton, a metals researcher at the investment house, Lehman Brothers. ``We are looking for the downturn to continue for the foreseeable future,'' he said. Metals traders Billiton-Enthoven also forecast a further drop because of a poor outlook for demand. Copper is used mainly in wires, cables and piping and brass fittings used by the plumbing and general engineering sectors. The London Metal Exchange price of copper, used by most of the world's producers as the basis for their sales contracts, was officially set on Wednesday at 1,299.50 pounds, or $2,560 per ton, for forward delivery. That was 50 pounds, or $98, below Tuesday's level and the lowest in 25 months, traders said. Copper consumption has already started to slow in line with the decline in economic growth in the main industrialized countries triggered by soaring oil prices, said London-based metals traders Rudolf Wolff. It expects demand to grow by just 1 percent this year to 8.66 million tons, compared with increases of 3 percent in 1988 and 4 percent in 1989. ``High interest rates have already affected the auto and construction industries in the United States, the United Kingdom and northern Europe,'' the firm said in a study released last week. Traders said that while growth in demand has slowed, production has risen this year - despite a series of problems that caused some shortages during the summer, including Peruvian miner strikes. Inventories in London Metal Exchange warehouses are just below 200,000 tons and are close to their highest level in five years, Buxton said.

DOC.HEAD: Bank Executive Resigns, Executives' Salaries Cut in Stock Scandal
DOC.TEXT: Sumitomo Bank, one of the world's largest banks, said Wednesday a vice president has resigned and it has cut pay for 24 other top executives after illegal loans were allegedly arranged by a branch manager. Sumitomo vice president Teizaburo Nishi resigned to take responsibility for not being aware of a former branch manager's illegal conduct, the bank said. It added that it is cutting the salaries of 24 top executives by as much as 50 percent for the six months starting Nov. 1. Meanwhile, the Japanese branch of Moody's Investors Service said it is considering lowering its rating for Sumitomo's securities because of concern over the bank's heavy concentration of real estate loans, said an analyst with Moody's Japan, speaking on condition of anonymity. Nishi's resignation followed that of Sumitomo chairman Ichiro Isoda, also in connection with the arrest 10 days ago of Akinori Yamashita, a former manager of Sumitomo's Yokohama branch. Yamashita was arrested on suspicion of having arranged 22.9 billion yen, or $182 million, in illegal loans to two groups allegedly involved in stock manipulation. Mitsuhiro Kotani, head of Koshin, one of the two groups that received illegal loans through Yamashita, has been indicted on charges of manipulating stocks in violation of the Securities and Exchange Law. Japan's Financing Law prohibits bank employees from engaging in loan transactions outside their normal bank operations. Those convicted face up to three years in prison and a fine of up to 3 million yen, or $23,800. This year, Moody's has lowered its ratings for six Japanese banks, including Sumitomo Trust Bank, Mitsubishi Trust Bank and Mitsui Bank, for their large number of real estate loans. It is now considering lowering those of four others, including Sumitomo, the analyst said. The stock scandal did not directly cause the review of Sumitomo's AAA rating, Moody's highest, he added. Sumitomo reported total assets of 62.8 trillion yen, or $499 billion, in March 1990, putting it behind the world's largest bank, Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank of Japan, which reported 66.6 trillion yen, or $529 billion, in assets.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares Close Lower

DOC.TEXT: Share prices on London's stock exchange closed lower Wednesday, but above the day's worst levels. A depressed stock index futures market dominated sentiment in the absence of news, traders said. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index closed down 15.6 points, or 0.7 percent, at 2,068.0. The Financial Times 30-share index closed down 12.5 points at 1,600.8. The Financial Times 500-share index fell 7.95 points to close at 1,103.51. Volume was 545.9 million shares, compared with 381.8 million shares Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Delta Agrees To $320 Million Expansion At Kentucky Airport
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS gate number in 5th graf, The project; CORRECTS Ronald to Donald and clarifies hub's relative size in 6th graf, Delta Chairman; picks up 7th graf, The airline.
DOC.TEXT: Delta Air Lines has agreed to spend $315 million to expand its operations and nearly double its workforce at the Greater Cincinnati International Airport, officials announced today. Gov. Wallace Wilkinson said the state has agreed to limit Delta's annual sales tax liability on jet fuel to $4 million. That would require an act of the General Assembly and Wilkinson said he expects it to pass. The governor said the state also will grant tax credits worth as much as $15 million on the airline's increase in payroll. The state is offering no incentive money up front for the expansion, which is expected to add 2,800 employees to the airline's workforce in northern Kentucky. The project will add 25 arrival and departure gates to the Delta hub already in place at the airport in Boone County. The number of gates for international departures will double to six. Delta Chairman Ronald W. Allen, who appeared with Wilkinson at an airport news conference, said the expansion would be the largest the airline has ever undertaken. Cincinnati is the airline's fourth-largest hub, behind Atlanta, Dallas-Fort Worth and Salt Lake City, and has been Delta's fastest-growing, Allen said. The airline is to begin construction immediately and is scheduled to complete the project by 1994. Wilkinson said $4 million, the amount of the proposed sales tax limit, is what Delta is expected to be paying at current prices in sales tax on aviation fuel within a year. The state receives $15 million from all airlines, officials said. It was not immediately possible to determine the full value of the credits and exemptions for Delta, but Allen said Delta projects the amount of jet fuel it purchases at the airport would roughly double. The sales tax limit and other elements of the incentive package will be placed on the agenda of a planned special session of the legislature in January, Wilkinson said. The tax limit would apply to any airline that invests $300 million in Kentucky and purchases at least 100 million gallons of fuel each year in the state.

DOC.HEAD: Spanish Truckers' Strike Prompts Closings at Renault Plants
DOC.TEXT: Renault said Wednesday it will close three of its automotive plants and temporarily lay off 22,000 workers as a result of a truck drivers' strike in Spain. A company spokesman said border blockades set up by the strikers had blocked supplies from Spain that were needed for production at the factories in Douai, Flins and Billancourt. He declined to elaborate. The spokesman said plants will be closed at least through Friday.

DOC.HEAD: MCI Loses $168 Million in Third Quarter
DOC.TEXT: MCI Communications Corp. on Wednesday reported a net loss of $168 million in the third quarter due to a one-time, $550 million charge to pay for modernizing its phone network. After subtracting preferred-stock dividends, MCI said its loss for the quarter ended Sept. 30 totaled $176 million, or 69 cents per common share. By comparison, the nation's No. 2 long-distance phone company earned $165 million, or 62 cents a share, in last year's third quarter. MCI reported revenue of $2 billion in the quarter, compared with $1.68 billion for the same period last year. The latest revenue figure reflects MCI's August acquisition of Telecom USA Inc., the nation's fourth-largest long distance company, for $1.25 billion. MCI also announced in August it was considering a writedown of $500 million to $550 million to cover the retirement of its analog phone network, which it is converting to modern digital lines. ``Without the writedown and other one-time events, MCI's profits would have been up 14 percent over the year-ago quarter,'' said Bert C. Roberts Jr., MCI's president and chief operating officer. ``Despite the challenge of smoothly integrating Telecom USA, the company increased its share of the large account, international and residential markets, and rolled out a new service for small to midsize businesses.'' In August, MCI moved up plans to have its phone network fully digital by the end of 1991 instead of the end of 1993. The accelerated schedule was made possible by the acquisition of Telecom USA, which had extensive digital lines, and by an agreement with Williams Cos. Inc. under which each company can use the other's phone network. Digital phone lines use computer language to transmit phone calls, providing vastly clearer reception than analog lines. For the year's first nine months, MCI earned $172 million, or 59 cents a share, vs. $450 million, or $1.69 a share, a year earlier. Revenue totaled $5.68 billion, vs. $4.76 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Also moved on general news wires
Dinner at McDonald's: Pizza and Celery?
DOC.TEXT: Stacy McIntire and her visitors wanted something with cheese and sauce, so they did the obvious thing at a not-so-obvious place. They went out for pizza - at McDonald's. ``We had company over and we fed four people on two pizzas for something like $12,'' she said. ``We went to the drive-through and didn't even have to get out of the car. We got it in five minutes.'' Pizza, in the land of all-beef patties, special sauce, lettuce, cheese, pickles, onions and sesame-seed buns? Is this a fast-food induced nightmare? Not at all. McDonald's, which for years counted its hamburger sales in the billions, may soon be counting pizza, pasta and other non-traditional offerings in an attempt to boost sluggish U.S. dinner sales. Owensboro's four Golden Arches and 10 others across the Ohio River in Evansville, Ind., are among 240 restaurants nationwide which are test-marketing tomato pies. The 12-inch pies also are being tested in Las Vegas; Hartford, Conn.; Fresno, Calif.; and suburbs of Chicago. Fresh carrots and celery sticks are being test marketed in Pennsylvania and California, and McDonald's also is experimenting with fresh fruit and soups. ``Our customers are interested in a little more variety and more choices,'' said Melissa Oakley, spokeswoman at McDonald's Corp.'s Oak Brook, Ill., headquarters. ``But we have to be very careful in what we choose. We're still committed to serving a limited menu.'' McDonald's, held up by many as a model American corporation, has long been committed to test marketing. Salads, the McDLT and Chicken McNuggets made the grade; the Hulaburger, two slices of cheese with a slice of grilled pineapple on a toasted bun, did not. Ms. Oakley noted that McDonald's tested salads for 10 years before introducing them in all of its 8,500 U.S. restaurants. But Michael Mueller, a Montgomery Securities Inc. analyst who specializes in restaurants, says McDonald's has reasons to press ahead with pizza now - investors' complaints about the company's recent U.S. sales growth. A pattern of progressively weaker domestic sales growth began in 1988 after peaking at 11.6 percent in 1987. A selloff of the company's stock followed release of second quarter results showing domestic sales of $6 billion for the first half of 1990, a 3.3-percent increase from the first half of 1989. ``From their standpoint they have to do something to boost dinner sales,'' Mueller said. ``This (pizza) is better than nothing.'' But is it better than Tony's, or Vito's, or Sal's? ``If you like pizza, it's just not right,'' said Elaine Lillpop of Rockport, Ind. ``It's a hurry-up job.'' She complained that the pepperoni pizza she bought in Owensboro tasted burned and didn't have enough cheese. Her 8-year-old daughter, Kari, said she didn't like it either. Gail Thompson of Owensboro said she won a free pizza and liked it, but wouldn't buy another. ``I love pizza but I don't particularly like eating it in this atmosphere,'' she said between bites of a burger. ``It's not fast food to me.'' That, says Mueller, is the problem. Pizza doesn't follow the rules that helped make McDonald's the world's largest restaurant chain. ``In the past they've been successful introducing products that are cheap, easy to eat, and come with quick service at the drive-through window,'' said the San Francisco-based analyst. ``Pizza is expensive, hard to eat in the car, and takes five minutes or more to get.'' Pizza also requires special ovens and is more difficult to make. And there are lots of competitors already established in the pizza market, Mueller said. Another restaurant analyst, Roy Burry of Kidder Peabody in New York, acknowledged the problems. But he expressed confidence that McDonald's would find a fast-food pizza that works. ``They've been on track for five or six years with this,'' he said. ``It takes a long time to get it right, which of course they will.'' Pizza was a logical choice, Burry said. The demand for more traditional fast food is not keeping pace with the number of new restaurants, he said. ``Pizza is the only fast food product that's growing,'' he said. ``It's a mammoth market. It offers major potential for them.'' Burry predicted the pizza might be ready for a national rollout within two years. The test likely will be expanded to more markets next year, he said. Ms. Oakley said McDonald's has not yet decided the product's fate. She said pizza is doing ``very well,'' although the company won't discuss sales figures. Pizza Hut, the largest pizza chain, maintains that McDonald's holds only 2 percent of sales in the Owensboro-Evansville market. Evansville workers said sales have been sporadic. A cheese pizza recently sold there for $4.99. The Deluxe, with cheese, sausage, pepperoni, green peppers, onion, tomato and mushrooms, sold for $7.99. Some restaurants sell pizza only after 4 p.m.; some offer quarter-pie slices for lunch. The Owensboro restaurants lure pizza buyers with glass windows that allow customer to watch sausage and pepperoni being spread by hand. But they don't see dough lovingly kneaded and tossed. McDonald's sacrificed fresh dough for frozen in its attempt to make pizza a fast food. Some customers say the dough will be the pizza's downfall. ``It tastes like cardboard,'' said 16-year-old Josh Hamburg of Owensboro.

DOC.HEAD: Nicaraguan Bank Workers Strike
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of bank workers struck Wednesday to demand pay raises, another sign of continuing unrest over government austerity policies. The strike by the 12,000-member Association of Bank Employees affected all of the country's 197 bank branches, including the Central Bank. The walkout capmaller job actions by bank workers, who are demanding job security, rule changes and increased bank capitalization in additions two weeks of s to higher pay. The bank union is part of the leftist Sandinista Front, which ruled Nicaragua for a decade until losing power in an election this year. The unions led massive nationwide strikes in May and July against government economic plans. Last week, it withdrew from talks with the government and businessmen aimed at reaching agreement on how to tackle the country's economic crisis, in which inflation has risen 4,000 percent this year. Sandinista work agreed to all the proposals I made and we agreed to the proposals that he has made,'' Vessey said with Thach standing at his side. Vessey said technical cooperation for joint investigations was agreed to, as well as ways to seek information and to return the remains of U.S. servicemen. He said the two sides ``agreed to new levels of cooperation to resolve the fates of the missing in action in Southeast Asia.'' A joint team will be formed to examine the specifics of the new forms of cooperation, Vessey said. Also participating in the discussions was Anne Mills Griffiths, head of a group of families of missing Americans. Thach is the first Hanoi official of his rank to visit Washington since Vietnam's independence 36 years ago. A State Department announcement had said the subject matter to be discussed was to be limited to the POW-MIA issue. In response to a question, Thach said there were no American war prisoners in government custody. Thach's ground-breaking visit is consistent with a pattern of improving relations that dates back to July when the Bush administration agreed to open discussions with Vietnam for the first time on resolving the conflict in neighboring Cambodia. Earlier, U.S.-Vietnamese contacts had been limited to humanitarian issues. The visit comes at a time of fading American bitterness toward Hanoi about the loss of more than 55,000 U.S. servicemen in the Vietnam conflict. A Time-CNN poll this past spring showed Americans support diplomatic relations by a 48-32 margin. Thach, 66, is a leading proponent of normal ties with the United States and has been promoting that goal recently in interviews with American reporters. As the participants in the discussion posed for photographers at the Army-Navy Club, about 20 Vietnamese demonstrators stood outside chanting slogans in support of democracy and a market economy for Vietnam. Thach also planned separate meetings this afternoon with members of the foreign relations committees of the Senate and the House. Secretary of State James A. Baker III met with Thach three weeks ago in New York and then agreed to facilitate Thach's visit to Washington by waiving the rule that limits Vietnamese diplomats to a 25-mile radius of New York City. The Baker-Thach meeting was the first high-level contact between the two countries in 17 years. The Bush administration has linked a normalization of relations with Vietnam to Hanoi's cooperation in obtaining an accounting of the missing Americans and in achieving a settlement of the Cambodian conflict. Ms. Griffiths said she believes Vietnam could do far more in helping account for American servicemen than it has. ``There's no question but that greater responsiveness would resolve hundreds of cases of Americans who are missing,'' she says. The United States has never recognized the communist government that assumed power in Hanoi in 1954 after the end of French colonial rule. Thach is well-known to U.S. diplomats as one of the principal negotiators of the agreement that led to the withdrawal of American forces from Vietnam in 1973. Any possibility of a U.S.-Vietnamese rapprochement in the aftermath were dashed when Hanoi's army conquered the U.S.-backed government in South Vietnam two years after the 1973 agreement. Subsequently, Vietnam was reunified under Hanoi's rule. Relations with Vietnam were further soured when Hanoi invaded Cambodia in late 1978. Successive U.S. administrations campaigned for years for a Vietnamese withdrawal from Cambodia. Vietnam said all of its forces were withdrawn a year ago but U.S. officials said some have since returned to Cambodia. Despite U.S. objections to Vietnam's role in Cambodia, both sides agree the Khmer Rouge, responsible for the deaths of over 1 million Cambodians in the 1970s, should not return to power.

DOC.HEAD: Bristol-Myers Squibb Net Up 20.7 Percent in Third Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Bristol-Myers Squibb Co. on Wednesday reported a 20.7 percent increase in net income for the third quarter, with strong sales in its pharmaceutical business and overseas. Richard L. Gelb, the company's chairman and chief executive officer, said favorable foreign exchange rates also helped net income increase to a record $495.9 million, or 94 cents a share, in the quarter ended Sept. 30. That compares with net earnings of $410.7 million or 78 cents a share in the third quarter of 1989. Sales rose 13 percent to a record $2.6 billion in the quarter, from $2.3 billion last year. Gelb said international sales rose 20 percent, while domestic sales increased 9 percent. Pharmaceutical sales rose 23 percent. For the first nine months of the year, net earnings rose 20.3 percent to $1.32 billion or $2.51 a share, from $1.099 billion or $2.10 a share. Sales rose 10.8 percent to $7.56 billion from $6.83 billion.

DOC.HEAD: 75-Year-Old Bakery Closes
DOC.TEXT: Van de Kamp's Holland Dutch Bakery, a regional baker with a 100-item line of goods, has closed and laid off nearly all its 500 workers, union officials and a lawyer for the company have announced. The 75-year-old bakery filed for protection from its creditors in August under federal bankruptcy law provisions. It listed $42.7 million in liabilities and $15 million in assets. David Gill,an attorney for the company, would not elaborate, and company officials did not return telephone calls for comment Wednesday. Andrea Zinder, research director for the United Food and Commercial Workers Union local 770, which represents some of Van de Kamp's sales staff, said Van de Kamp employees told her the bakery was shut for good. She and other union officials said the bakery dismissed most of its employees last week. ``From what I wGonzalez told Brady: ``This is a shocking interpretation of a Cabinet officer's responsibility. ``I know that you recognize that members of the committee have a right and responsibility to seek responses from the administration concerning the assumptions beneath the requested amount. ... ``As arduous as this may be for the administration, it is not a process from which the secretary can be exempted.'' The Senate Banking Committee last week endorsed spending $57 billion more for the bailout - $40 billion to cover S&L losses and $17 billion in reserve funds. It acted after receiving a fresh letter from Brady. Legislators in the House, however, are being less understanding. While there has been no talk of subpoenaing Brady, several committee members are threatening to vote against more S&L money unless Brady appears. ``There has been a very disturbing pattern of trying to circumvent any kind of congressional oversight'' of the savings and loan bailout, said Rep. Joseph Kennedy, D-Mass. ``If they (administration officials) run out of money because we want to be prudent as to how we provide it, then that's up to them. I'm not going to vote for any money for an organization where we have no idea of how the funds are flowing,'' he said. The Association of Community Organizations for Reform Now, ACORN, a consumer activist group, is urging the committee to block the second round of bailout financing unless it takes steps to reform the cleanup process. Gonzalez, meanwhile, is threatening to oppose more financing unless the cleanup agency, the Resolution Trust Corp., ceases its practice of protecting virtually all deposits, even uninsured deposits, when a thrift fails.

DOC.HEAD: Maker of Disposable Diapers Drops Environmental Pitch
DOC.TEXT: The maker of Bunnies Biodegradable Disposable Diapers has agreed to stop claiming that its product is good for the environment, New York Attorney General Robert Abrams announced Wednesday. The company had claimed that ``Bunnies and the plastic bag they are sold in will biodegrade before your child grows up.'' But Abrams asserted that Bunnies, ``like any organic waste, will take decades to degrade in our nation's landfills.'' Abrams, as lead attorney for 10 states, said Bunnies' maker, American Enviro Products Inc. of Placentia, Calif., also agreed to pay $50,000 to the states for costs and to change the design of the diaper so that it really does have less of an impact on the environment. ``This is a significant settlement because it is the first multistate agreement in the `green-marketing' area to actually reach a cash settlement and move a company in a positive direction,'' Abrams said. Bunnies has been on the market about a year and a half and nationally represents about 1 or 2 percent of the market, said the company's president, Robert Chickering. The action was joined by the attorneys general of California, Florida, Massachusetts, Minnesota, Missouri, Texas. Utah, Washington and Wisconsin.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed, Gold Rebounds
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell sharply against the Japanese yen Wednesday and finished mixed against other major currencies in busy trading. Gold prices inched higher after tumbling more than $25 an ounce earlier this week. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery fetched $366.70 a troy ounce, up $4.70 from Tuesday. Republic National Bank quoted a late bid for bullion of $366.10 an ounce, up $2.10. Much attention focused on the Japanese yen, which rose significantly against the dollar. Traders said Japanese portfolio managers are bringing their money home in an effort to support a weakening stock market and banks that have suffered declines in their capital ratios. ``People expect (Japan's) Ministry of Finance to keep yen interest rates fairly high,'' which attracts investors, said Bob Morrissey, senior trader at the Bank of Boston's office here. In addition, there is the belief that ``U.S. and Japanese officials have agreed to an orderly dollar decline, and they have been tolerating it,'' said Stephen Flanagan, a vice president at Manufacturers Hanover Trust Co. The dollar fell sharply in Tokyo, where the U.S. currency settled at 125.80 Japanese yen, down from 128.05 yen on Tuesday. Later in London, it fell further to 124.85 yen. In New York, the dollar closed off its lows at 125.43 yen but still was down from 126.79 yen on Tuesday. Traders said a government report showing a better-than-expected 0.2 percent rise in industrial production during September helped put a floor under the dollar even though a 7.5 percent spurt in automobile production masked overall weakness in manufacturing. The report hinted that there may be less room for the Federal Reserve to east interest rates. Higher interest rates tend to support the dollar by making dollar-denominated securities more attractive to investors. Some traders spent part of the session squaring up their positions ahead of another slew of economic data - the government will report Thursday on September's consumer prices and merchandise trade figures for August. In London, the British pound rose to $1.9650 from $1.9575 late Tuesday. In New York it cost $1.9615 to buy one pound, less expensive than Tuesday's $1.9655. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's rates included: 1.5125 German marks, up from 1.5115; 1.2720 Swiss francs, down from 1.2770; 5.0680 French francs, up from 5.0660; 1,132.50 Italian lire, down from 1,132.75, and 1.1683 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1564. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Tuesday's rates included: 1.5105 German marks, down from 1.5145; 1.2725 Swiss francs, down from 1.2780; 5.0588 French francs, down from 5.0732; 1.7015 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7070; 1,130.75 Italian lire, down from 1,134.25, and 1.1646 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1551. Gold rose in London to a late bid price of $366.50 a troy ounce from $364.25 bid late Tuesday. In Zurich, the metal rose to a closing bid of $366.20 from $362. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold fell 8.52 cents to close at a bd $367.81. Silver prices also rose. On New York's Comex, silver for current delivery settled at $4.198 a troy ounce, up from Tuesday's $4.142. In London the metal rose to a late bid price of $4.24 a troy ounce from $4.23.

DOC.HEAD: `Horizontal' Oil Well Could Spur Boom in Wyoming
DOC.TEXT: A ``super highway'' of oil has been tapped in southeastern Wyoming by a drilling technique that could spur an oil boom in the region, a petroleum expert said Wednesday. The find announced Wednesday by Union Pacific Resources Co., of Fort Worth, Texas, lies in the Niobrara Formation 18 miles northeast of Cheyenne. A 21-hour test of the well produced 1,462 barrels of crude, the greatest daily production of any Wyoming well, according to officials. The company, a subsidiary of Union Pacific Corp., achieved the results by boring into the formation horizontally instead of using traditional vertical techniques which would have produced as little as 50 barrels per day, according to Chuck Farmer, a petroleum engineer with the Wyoming Oil and Gas Commission. The find ``will result in a mini-boom,'' he said. Unlike vertical wells that bore straight down and miss pockets of oil on either side of the well, horizontal wells start vertically but the drill bit gradually is turned 90 degrees to traverse the rock formation. This enables the drill to encounter multiple fractures filled with oil that might be missed by a vertical drill. Farmer said horizontal drilling appears to be catching on in Wyoming.
