DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Fall on Supply Concerns, Technical Factors
DOC.TEXT: Crude oil prices tumbled more than $2 a barrel Wednesday as the energy futures market, though still sensitive to developments out of the Middle East, temporarily ran out of steam. Traders were preoccupied with supply-and-demand concerns. The November contract for light sweet crude oil slumped $2.17 to $36.72 a 42-gallon barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Later contract months also fell sharply. With no substantive developments from the Persian Gulf to influence trading, the market was swayed by reports that crude was going unsold in spot markets. The reports indicated low demand for oil from refineries, which are currently retooling to turn out more heating oil rather than gasoline for the winter months. Wednesday's drop was something of a surprise after the previous session, when crude prices rose nearly $1 on expectations that the American Petroleum Institute's weekly report on inventories - issued after the close of trading Tuesday - would indicate a decline in stockpiles. Tha is exactly what the API reported. The trade group said domestic crude inventories fell to 343.3 million barrels in the week ended Oct. 12 from 349.5 million a week earlier, with most of the decline coming from a major reduction in imports. The API report sent oil prices higher overseas, but when the U.S. market opened, prices fell. Technical factors also figured into Wednesday's session. As the price of crude fell through psychological points known as support levels, selling began to accelerate, analysts said. Analysts said the market has lost some of its frenzy since the November contract for crude was unable to break through the $41-a-barrel mark last week. But they were quick to caution that despite declines like Wednesday's, the market retains most of its bullishness and it is still hypersensitive to any negative developments in the Persian Gulf. ``It could rocket up if war breaks out,'' said Jim Fiedler, an analyst with E. D. & F. Man International Futures Inc. who called Wednesday's drop ``a correction to a bull market.'' Prices for refined products also fell sharply Wednesday. Home heating oil for November delivery plunged 5.75 cents to 98.25 cents a gallon despite the approaching winter weather. Later contract months also fell sharply. Wholesale unleaded gasoline for delivery in November skidded 4.48 cents to 93.40 cents a gallon, with subsequent months also dropping. In natural gas trading, the November contract closed at $1.900 per 1,000 cubic feet, down from $1.910 on Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: UTC Reports 22 Percent Rise in Third-quarter Earnings
DOC.TEXT: United Technologies Corp. on Wednesday reported a 22 percent increase in third-quarter earnings, citing a $46.5 million gain from unloading its majority interest in two Italian automotive companies. Net earnings for the third quarter totalled $239.8 million, or $1.90 per share, on revenues of $5.3 billion. That compares with earnings of $196.7 million, or $1.46 per share, on revenues of $4.8 billion for the same period last year. ``I am particularly pleased with the strength of our performance, especially in light of the poor economic environment and the weakness in the U.S. residential housing and automotive markets,'' said Robert F. Daniell, UTC's chairman and chief executive officer. The company reported a one-time pre-tax gain of $46.5 million from the sale of its 75 percent interest in Italian automotive firms Diavia and Aura. Without that gain, earnings would have increased 7.5 percent in the third quarter, the company said. UTC reported decreased earnings in its two largest segments in the quarter. Its power segment, which includes Pratt & Whitney, posted earnings of $242 million, a $39 million decrease from 1989. The decline reflected a slight cooling of last year's record jet engine sales and a one-time gain of more than $40 million when several of Pratt & Whitney's overseas partners increased their interest in joint projects, said UTC spokesman Peter Kowalchuk. Operating profits from the building systems segment, which includes its Carrier Air Conditioning and Otis Elevator subsidiaries, were down $15 million to $138 million, due in part to the nation's housing slump, the company said. The corporation saw improvements in its flight systems segment, which includes both Sikorsky Helicopter and Windsor Locks-based Hamilton Standard. Flight systems posted earnings of $50 million for the quarter, compared with a $34 million loss in the 1989 period. The industrial segment also gained, posting a net $65 million in earnings, up from $39 million. The figure was inflated, however, by the sale of UTC's interest in the Italian automotive firms. Profits for the first nine months rose 12 percent to $581.8 million, or $4.59 per share, compared with $517.7 million, or $3.91 a share during the same period in 1989. Revenues rose to $15.8 billion from $14.5 billion. UTC provides high-technology products and support services for the aerospace, building systems and automotive industries. Its products include Pratt & Whitney aircraft engines, Carrier heating and air-conditioning systems, Otis elevators and escalators, Sikorsky helicopters, Hamilton Standard aerospace systems and Norden defense systems.

DOC.HEAD: 2nd Eastern Employee Pleads Guilty in Maintenance Scheme
DOC.TEXT: A second Eastern Airlines foreman at Kennedy Airport has quietly pleaded guilty to falsifying aircraft safety and maintenance records and has agreed to cooperate with authorities, according to court records. Michael Hennessey, Eastern's general foreman at the airport, admitted to conspiring with other airline employees to falsify log books, work cards and computer records in a scheme that allegedly allowed unsafe aircraft to carry passengers. Hennessey, who faces a maximum sentence of five years in prison and a $250,000 fine, pleaded guilty at an Oct. 9 hearing before U.S. District Judge I. Leo Glasser of Brooklyn. An Eastern spokeswoman, Karen Ceremsak, said the airline had no comment on Hennessey's plea. ``A cooperation agreement was filed as part of his plea agreement,'' Hennessey's lawyer, Henry Putzel, said Wednesday. ``He has been and will continue to be fully cooperative with the government.'' Hennessey - who was not charged in a 60-count criminal indictment that was unsealed in July and accuses the airline and several top managers of routinely ignoring vital repairs - pleaded guilty and remains free on his own recognizance. Hennessey and the other defendants caused ``aircraft that were not properly maintained and repaired to fly and carry unsuspecting passengers,'' court documents alleged. According to court records, the scheme was directed by two top Eastern executives. Former Vice President Edward Upton and Thomas Lewis, who was the maintenance director of Eastern's Northern region airports, allegedly employed ``intimidation and coercion'' to force company workers ``to avoid and minimize flight delays and cancellations by falsifying aircraft maintenance records.'' Prosecutors allege that records were altered to make it appear scheduled maintenance and corrective repairs had been done when in fact they had not been. Hennessey also admitted to lying to Federal Aviation Administration authorities investigating the Eastern scheme, which allegedly took place from July 1985 to October 1989 at Kennedy and La Guardia airports in New York, Hartsfield International Airport in Atlanta and Eastern headquarters in Miami. The criminal indictment was unprecedented in the airline industry and came as Eastern was trying to rebuild its faltering service, regain passengers and reorganize in bankruptcy court after bitter labor disputes. The case is scheduled to go to trial at the federal courthouse in Brooklyn in January. In July, a former Eastern foreman named in the indictment pleaded guilty and agreed to testify. Elia Dragone of Jersey City, N.J., the first Eastern employee to plead guilty, said the scheme was orchestrated by his superiors at the airline. He admitted to conspiracy and obstructing an FAA investigation into the airline.

DOC.HEAD: Orange Juice Futures Skid Further After Brazilian Price Cuts
DOC.TEXT: Orange juice futures prices dropped to new four-year lows Wednesday amid speculation that Brazilian processers will dump more frozen concentrate onto the U.S. market in a shakeout stemming from a large Florida crop forecast. On other commodity markets, petroleum prices fell sharply; precious metals rose; grains and soybeans were higher; and livestock and meat futures were mixed. All contracts for future deliveries of frozen concentrated orange juice plunged the permitted daily limit of 5 cents a pound on the New York Cotton Exchange except the November contract, which has an expanded limit and fell 5.85 cents to $1.12 a pound. The November settlement was the lowest for a near-month orange juice contract since Oct. 16, 1986. Near-term orange juice has fallen by about 18 cents, or 14 percent, since last Thursday, when the Agriculture Department projected a 50 percent increase in Florida orange production this season compared with last year's frost-shriveled crop. ``The market continues to fall toward a dollar in the aftermath of the crop report,'' said Sandra Kaul, orange juice analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. Juice from Brazil made up for the U.S. shortfall last season, when the Florida freeze pushed prices to near record highs. But major Brazilian processers began cutting their prices soon after the report, including a 25 discount to U.S. customers on Monday, said analyst Celeste Georkakis of Cargill Investor Services Inc. She said the price cuts already are causing turbulence among smaller Brazilian processers. ``We understand that two have filed for bankruptcy and one has asked the government for financial help,'' Georkakis said. Oil futures tumbled on the New York Mercantile Exchange amid persistent perceptions that the Iraqi occupation of Kuwait might be resolved peacefully. ``You have seen a pretty hefty war premium put into this market. I think what you're seeing today is some of that war premium being eroded,'' said Stephen W. Platt, energy analyst Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Light sweet crude oil settled $1.26 to $2.17 lower with November at $36.72 a barrel; wholesale heating oil was 3 cents to 5.75 cents lower with November at 98.25 cents a gallon; wholesale unleaded gasoline was 3 cents to 4.48 cents lower with November at 93.40 cents a gallon. Gold futures rebounded moderately after three straight days of steep losses on New York's Commodity Exchange. Analysts said the rally was an overdue correction. Gold finished $4.60 to $4.70 higher with October at $366.70 a troy ounce; silver was 4.8 cents to 5.6 cents higher with October at $4.19 a troy ounce. Grain and soybean futures rose moderately on the Chicago Board of Trade, erasing the previous day's losses amid news that the Soviet Union bought 350,000 metric tons of U.S. corn and China is seeking to buy 300,000 metric tons of subsidized U.S. winter wheat. Corn and soybean futures also were supported by a threat of harvest delays and crop damage from a powerful storm system that was expected to bring high winds, rain and snow to the Midwest beginning Wednesday. Wheat futures settled 1} cents to 2} cents higher with December at $2.63{ a bushel; corn was 1} cents to 2\ cents higher with December at $2.28} a bushel; oats were 4\ cents higher across the board with December at $1.23\ a bushel; soybeans were { cent to 4\ cents higher with November at $6.14{ a bushel. Cattle futures ended mostly higher on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, boosted by firm cash markets. Hog futures were mixed but most pork belly contracts soared the permitted daily limit of 2 cents a pound on new indications of tight supplies. Live cattle futures settled .05 cent to .45 cent higher with October at 79.02 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .30 cent lower to .25 cent higher with October at 86.80 cents a pound; live hogs were .15 cent lower to .43 cent higher with October at 57.10 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.75 cents to 2 cents higher with February at 66.70 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Ames Reduces Corporate Staff
DOC.TEXT: Ames Department Stores Inc., the ailing discount chain that filed for bankruptcy protection earlier this year, said Wednesday it will lay off 250 corporate employees and close offices in West Hartford and Syracuse, N.Y. The Rocky Hill-based company said it already has eliminated 200 corporate positions through attrition over the past four months. The company has 1,600 corporate employees. Both moves are part of the company's plan to reduce costs as it struggles to recover under bankruptcy protection. The bulk of the layoffs - 160 - will be from Syracuse, N.Y. Ames said the West Hartford merchandising operations and Syracuse, N.Y., finance operation will be relocated in Rocky Hill next spring. Ames filed for protection from its creditors April 25. The filing under Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code allows the company to remain in business while it works out a plan to repay its creditors. Since filing for bankruptcy protection, the company has closed 219 stores and laid off about 18,000 employees.

DOC.HEAD: Prices End Little Changed in Nervous Market
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Micheal in 4th graf is cq
DOC.TEXT: Bond prices finished little changed Wednesday, influenced by mixed economic reports, more Middle East uncertainty, unresolved budget talks in Washington and plans for a record 2-year Treasury note auction. The Treasury's key 30-year issue rose about $1 per $1,000 in face amount. Its yield, which falls when the price rises, eased to 8.88 percent from 8.89 percent late Tuesday. Bond strategists said Commerce Department reports showing weakness in the housing industry but rising industrial production in September injected some confusion into the market because they signaled signs of recession and growth at the same time. ``That jerked it around a little bit,'' said Micheal Casey, a bond economist at Maria Ramirez Capital Consultants Inc., a New York investment concern. ``There were various conflicting stories out of the Mideast that knocked it around a little bit, too.'' All financial markets have been fixated on developments in the Persian Gulf since Iraq seized Kuwait more than two months ago, provoking a crisis that has nearly doubled the price of oil and raised fears of both recession and oil-shock inflation in the United States, which imports half its petroleum. On Tuesday, bond prices rose slightly on speculation that diplomacy might help resolve the Mideast crisis, but that thinking seemed to disappear Wednesday, partly on Secretary of State James A. Baker III's remarks that Iraq's Saddam Hussein ``must fail if peace is to succeed.'' Bond strategists said the persistent inability of Congress and the Bush administration to overcome differences in closing the federal budget gap also was creating uncertainty in the market. President Bush has threatened to shut the government down again Saturday unless Congress sends him a budget he can accept. Without emergency legislation, federal authority to spend money expires that day, and would prevent the Treasury from borrowing. ``The Treasury's like a junkie for money,'' Casey said. ``That's hanging over the market.'' William Veronda, a fixed-income strategist for Financial Programs Inc. in Denver, said additional bond market uncertainty stemmed from the Treasury's plan to auction a record $12 billion in 2-year notes later this month. That helped depress some short-term government bond prices, he said. In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, short-term and medium-term maturities were unchanged to 1-32 point lower, while long-term issues were up about 3-32 point, the Telerate Inc. financial information service reported. The movement of a point equals a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Shearson Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, rose 0.20 to 1,150.06. Yields on three-month Treasury bills rose to 7.40 percent as the discount rose 2 basis point to 7.18 percent. Yields on six-month bills remained unchanged at 7.57 percent as the discount remained at 7.20 percent. Yields on one-year bills rose to 7.59 percent as the discount rose 3 basis points to 7.11 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, paid at maturity. The federal funds rate, the interest on overnight loans between banks, traded at 6 percent, down from 7 15-16 percent late Tuesday. The drop was due to internal market factors and was not considered a sign of easing by the Federal Reserve. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds rose [ point. The average yield to maturity fell to 7.81 percent from 7.83 percent late Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: House Approves Civil Rights Bill But Veto Looms
DOC.NOTE: EDs: First 5 grafs new with Kennedy quote, partisan breakdown, one-vote gain, ``disappointed'' quote; picks up 4th graf: ``The Senate,'' Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The House on Wednesday approved a major civil rights bill designed to combat job discrimination and sent it to President Bush, who promised a veto on grounds that it would lead to hiring quotas. ``I hope that President Bush will reconsider the unwise and unjustified course he is on,'' Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., said following House approval of the bill, 273-154. The margin was 12 votes short of the two-thirds needed to override a veto and pass the bill over the president's objections. Thirty-four Republicans and 239 Democrats voted for the bill while 15 Democrats and 139 Republicans were opposed. Despite months of efforts for forge a compromise, civil rights forces succeeded in gaining just one vote beyond their total on Aug. 3 when the House passed an earlier version 272-154. ``We're somewhat disappointed because we had hoped that the additional compromises that were made since the vote last time would have picked up some votes,'' said William Taylor, a longtime Washington civil rights advocate. The Senate on Tuesday approved the bill but also fell short of the support needed to override a veto. Somber civil rights forces planned a final campaign to persuade Bush to relent and sign the bill. ``Give us these measly crumbs from the table,'' Rep. Craig Washington, D-Texas, said as the House debated the measure, which had been nine months in the making and softened repeatedly in efforts to woo Bush's support. The bill represents the civil rights movement's top priority on Capitol Hill this year. It would overturn six decisions on job discrimination that created a furor when the Supreme Court handed them down last year. Provisions range from a ban on racial harassment in the workplace to punitive damages in extreme discrimination cases. The greatest controversy, however, came over complex changes in rules on how job discrimination cases are decided. They would make it easier for minorities filing suit to win and harder for employers to defend themselves. President Bush said in a letter delivered to Capitol Hill on Tuesday that the changes would ``have the effect of forcing businesses to adopt quotas in hiring and promotion.'' He said that if the bill reached his desk, he would ``be compelled to veto it.'' White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said Wednesday morning that Bush planned to veto the measure and send it back to lawmakers with an alternative version attached. Civil rights leaders, however, have been saying the chances of passing an alternative this year are virtually nil. In recent months, they had been holding out hope that Bush would relent and sign the bill. After weighing Tuesday's missive from the president, however, civil rights leaders sharpened their rhetoric. ``His announced intention to veto the Civil Rights Act of 1990 shows that on issues of race and sex discrimination, George Bush is a Ronald Reagan in sheep's clothing,'' said Ralph Neas, executive director of the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights. ``While his style and rhetoric may differ, his substantive civil rights policies are just as deadly to those who are victims of job discrimination,'' Neas said. Indeed, with respect to key parts of the Civil Rights Act of 1990, President Bush's positions are even more extreme than Ronald Reagan's.'' ``Regrettably, President Bush has capitulated to the right wing,'' he said. There is nothing in the bill that would require employers to hire by quota. In fact, the measure contains a disclaimer specifically saying that it would not ``encourage'' the use of quotas. Business groups and Bush administration officials say, however, that the bill would make employers so vulnerable to discrimination suits that they would turn to quotas to provide themselves with a ready-made defense in case they were taken to court. Civil rights forces tried in vain for months to dispel this notion, saying the measure would do no more than restore the law to what it was before last year's decision in a case called Wards Cove versus Atonio, involving employment practices at a salmon cannery in Alaska. Supporters also said strong support for a civil rights bill was needed to show congressional disapproval of an upsurge in acts of bigotry by neo-Nazi groups and others. They cited a surprising showing in recent Louisiana primary voting for former Ku Klux Klan leader David Duke. ``David Duke was not a fluke,'' Rep. Patricia Schroeder, D-Colo., said.

DOC.HEAD: Profit Up at Pacific Telesis, Ameritech, Down at BellSouth
DOC.TEXT: Pacific Telesis Group and Ameritech said Wednesday their third-quarter profits rose, while earnings softened slightly at another regional telephone holding company, BellSouth Corp. Pacific Telesis, which owns the primary phone companies in California and Nevada, said its third-quarter profit rose 2.5 percent to $285 million, or 72 cents a share, compared with $278 million, or 68 cents a share, in last year's third quarter. Revenue totaled $2.47 billion, up from $2.37 billion in the same period of 1989. Pacific Telesis said gains in its cellular phone business and other services helped offset state-ordered rate cuts at Pacific Bell, a subsidiary. For the first nine months of the year, the San Francisco-based company reported a profit of $834 million, or $2.09 a share, down from $920 million, or $2.23 a share, a year earlier. Revenue totaled $7.28 billion, vs. $7.12 billion.

Chicago-based Ameritech, which owns five phone companies in the Midwest, said its profit rose 7.6 percent in the third quarter to $311.2 million, or $1.18 a share, from $289.1 million, or $1.06 a share, a year earlier. Revenue totaled $2.7 billion, up from $2.6 billion in the year-earlier period. For the first nine months, Ameritech earned $967 million, or $3.64 a share, up from $907 million, or $3.37 a share, a year earlier. Revenue totaled $7.97 billion, up from $7.61 billion.

Atlanta-based BellSouth said its third-quarter earnings totaled $402.9 million, or 84 cents a share, compared with $404.4 million, also 84 cents a share, for the same quarter of 1989. Revenue totaled $3.551 billion, up from $3.545 billion. ``Earnings continue to be dampened by rate reductions, but these reductions primarily reflect the costs of adopting incentive regulatory plans,'' said John L. Clendenin, BellSouth's chairman and chief executive officer. ``Such plans hold long-term benefits for customers and shareholders by providing economic motivation to accelerate the introduction of new services and improve operating efficiencies,'' he said. During the quarter, state regulatory commissions in Georgia and Tennessee agreed to adopt various forms of incentive-based plans. For the first nine months, BellSouth earned $1.271 billion, or $2.64 a share, down slightly from $1.272 billion, or $2.67 a share, last year.

DOC.HEAD: Language School To Open in Moscow
DOC.TEXT: Berlitz International Inc. said Wednesday it would open a language training school in the Soviet Union for the first time since the 1917 Bolshevik revolution. The Berlitz-Sovincentr Language School in Moscow will be a joint venture between Berlitz and the Soviet Chamber of Commerce. Berlitz said the school would be the first in a series in central and eastern Europe. Additional Berlitz schools are planned in the Soviet Union, Hungary, Czechoslovakia, Bulgaria, Romania and what was formerly East Germany. Berlitz schools in Moscow and Leningrad were closed down by the revolution that established a communist government, Berlitz said. Berlitz is a subsidiary of Maxwell Communications Corp.

DOC.HEAD: Earnings Dip in Third Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Georgia-Pacific Corp. on Wednesday reported a 46 percent drop in profit in the third quarter as its interest expense soared and its building products business weakend. The wood and paper company reported net income of $95 million, or $1.11 per share, on sales of $3.4 billion for the three months that ended Sept. 30. In the same period last year, profit was $178 million, or $5.58 per share, on sales of $2.6 billion. The buyout of Great Northern Nekoosa Corp. helped boost sales, but Georgia Pacific's interest expense rose from $65 million in the third quarter of 1989 to $163 million in the most recent quarter. Building products profits dropped in the quarter on lower prices, said T. Marshall Hahn Jr., chairman and chief executive officer. Plywood prices dropped 15 percent from the same period a year ago, he said. Pulp and paper profits improved, despite generally lower prices, he said. ``Demand and pricing for tissue and communication papers remains strong,'' Hahn said. For the nine-month period, net income was $303 million compared with $504 million for the same period in 1989. Earnings per share were $3.54 in 1990 compared to $5.58 a year ago.

DOC.HEAD: Venezuelan Computer Company Sues AT&T for Fraud
DOC.TEXT: A Venezuelan computer company has sued American Telephone & Telegraph Co. seeking $90 million in damages, claiming AT&T tried to put the company out of business and monopolize the phone and computer industries in Venezuela. The lawsuit was filed in federal court in Manhattan by C.A. Westel de Venezuela, a former distributor of AT&T products in the South American nation. According to a statement from Westel, the suit claims AT&T induced the company into buying obsolete or broken AT&T equipment at inflated prices, then slandered the company by telling its customers that it was at fault for problems with the equipment. The suit also alleges AT&T attempted to monopolize the telecommunications and computer industries in Venezuela ``through a pattern of racketeering activity'' and ``in furtherance of a scheme to defraud,'' according to the statement. In addition, the suit claims that AT&T stole telephone technology developed by Westel. ``We haven't seen the suit yet, but we have had differences with this company in recent times that led to the end of our relationswhip with them early this year,'' said AT&T spokesman Andy Myers, reading from a statement.

DOC.HEAD: Northrop Profit Rises 97 Percent on Strength in Electronics Area
DOC.TEXT: Northrop Corp. said Wednesday its third-quarter profit nearly doubled, largely because of a strong turnaround in its electronics division. During the quarter that ended Sept. 30, the B-2 bomber maker earned $42.4 million, or 90 cents per share, compared with $21.5 million, or 46 cents per share, during the third quarter of 1989. The electronics division, which lost $2 million during the same period of 1989, had an operating profit of $19.5 million this year. Northrop's sales rose by 2.5 percent, from $1.25 billion to $1.28 billion. Northrop said production on the first few B-2s increased slightly. The work volume also rose in the missile and unmanned vehicles systems and electronic countermeasures areas. It tailed off for MX missile guidance systems. Sales for the first nine months of 1990 rose 1.2 percent to $3.97 billion. Net income for the first nine months totaled $167.7 million, or $3.57 per share, including an after-tax gain of $67.1 million, or $1.42 a share, from the sale of Northrop's headquarters complex in Century City. That compared with a loss of $46.9 million in the first nine months of 1989, the equivalent of $1 per share. That loss included a $150 million pretax loss provision for a classified, fixed-price research and development contract in the missiles and unmanned vehicles division. The loss at Northrop's electronics division in the third quarter of 1989 also came because of provisions for losses on fixed-price research and development contracts. Northrop had $15 million in such loss provisions in the electronics division that quarter.

DOC.HEAD: Conrail's Profits Drop 17 Percent
With BC-Earns-Union Pacific
DOC.TEXT: Conrail Wednesday reported a 17.2 percent drop in profit in the third quarter as the freight railroad finished a massive stock buy-back intended to guard against any unwanted takeover. Net income totaled $72 million, or $1.50 a share, on revenue of $847 million for the three months ending Sept. 30. In the same period last year, net income was $87 million, or $1.27 a share, on revenue of $835 million. Since the first quarter of the year, Conrail has spent $1.3 billion to cut the number of outstanding shares by 40.3 percent since the end of last year's third quarter. ``As solid as the third quarter has been, the troublesome economic outlook for the remainder of the year and 1991 concerns us,'' Conrail Chairman James Hagan said. He predicted a continued lowering of the traffic mix, a higher volume of low-revenue freight and a lower volume of high-revenue freight. For the first nine months of the year, Conrail's profits were $171 million, or $3.23 a share, on revenue of $2.531 billion. For the same period in 1989, profit was $229 million, or $3.34 a share, or $2.588 billion

DOC.HEAD: AT&T And Japanese To Build Transpacific Cable
DOC.TEXT: American Telephone & Telegraph Co. and Kokusai Denshin Denwa of Japan on Wednesday announced they are studying the possibility of building a new telephone cable across the Pacific Ocean. The proposed cable system, which would link the United States and Japan, would use optical amplifier technology and operate at eight times the capacity of existing fiber-optic cables, AT&T said in a statement. The new cable network system would help international carriers provide telecommunications services in their countries, said David Bikle, a spokesman for AT&T. Optical amplifiers, which are segments of an optical fiber that contain the element erbium, boost lightwave signals without converting them to electrons and back to light, as is done in conventional systems. The world's first fiber optic transoceanic system went into service in 1988 and is capable of handling 40,000 calls at once, Bikle said. The new optical amplifier cable system, expected to be in service in 1996, would be able to handle 600,000 calls, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Inland Posts 3rd-Quarter Loss; Expects More Red Ink
DOC.TEXT: Inland Steel Industries Inc. reported Wednesday that it lost $2.2 million during the third quarter, largely because of lower sales and expected start-up costs for its venture with Nippon Steel Corp. The loss, which translates to 27 cents a share, compares with a profit of $18.3 million, or 43 cents a share, during the third period last year. Sales declined from $981 million to $960 million. The company said its I-N Tek venture, a sheet-finishing mill, with Nippon cost the company about 40 cents a share during the quarter. ``Clearly, we are very disappointed with these results,'' said Frank W. Luerssen, chairman and chief executive officer. ``Despite a relatively strong steel market, we failed to achieve our volume and mix expectations for the quarter.'' He said the losses are expected to carry over to the final quarter and blamed continuing initial costs associated with I-N Tek, a strike at its largest iron ore mine and a fire at its No. 4 basic oxygen furnace shop. For the first three quarters, Inland reported a net income of $36.5 million, or 55 cents a share, compared with $113 million, or $3.04 a share during the first nine months of 1989. Sales declined by 7 percent, from $3.19 billion to $2.96 billion.

DOC.BYLINE: OIL DEALS: The Stakes Are High But So Are The Potential Profits
DOC.TEXT: NEW YORK - Around an area called the oil pit at the New York Mercantile Exchange, shouting traders crowd into a tight circle to place bets on the future of crude oil - stakes that would scare off most veteran Las Vegas gamblers. The resulting petroleum prices can be felt everywhere from the home heating oil bills in New England to the gasoline pumps in southern California. Slug BC-Oil Speculators. By Business Writer Dirk Beveridge. Moving Wednesday on FFF-level news wires for Sunday, Oct. 21. With LaserPhoto NY304 of Oct. 16.
DOC.BYLINE: HARD WORK: DuPont Uses Endurance Tests To Develop Teamwork
DOC.TEXT: NORTH EAST, Md. - Helmeted and harnessed, Du Pont Co. workers climb 30-foot poles, scale 60-foot walls and zip down a 300-yard wire on the ``Ropes Course'' - the opening of a two-day seminar on teamwork for employees in the fibers department. Slug BC-Du Pont Teamwork. By Theresa Humphrey. Moved Wednesday on FFF-level news wires for Sunday, Oct. 21. With LaserPhoto WIL1 of Oct. 16.
DOC.BYLINE: MOVE OVER DONALD: Belgium Financier Who Flaunted Riches Loses Fortune
DOC.TEXT: BRUSSELS, Belgium - Jean-Pierre Van Rossem once was considered a guru of Belgium's stock market, a self-proclaimed financial whiz who reportedly managed nearly $7 billion of investor money last year alone. He also loved to flaunt his own millions: There was the fleet of red Ferraris he hauled to news conferences, the prestigious Formula One racing team he sponsored. But Van Rossem overextended himself and his empire became unglued over the summer. ``I finally fell on my face,'' he recently told reporters. Slug BC-Personal File-Van Rossem. By Raf Casert. Moved Tuesday on FFF-level news wires for Sunday, Oct. 21. LaserPhoto planned.
DOC.BYLINE: FROM BLADES TO SHADES: Maker Of Popular Pocketknife Expands Product Line
DOC.TEXT: SHELTON, Conn. - The company that brought the all-purpose Swiss Army pocketknife to America is now offering products that do more than open wine bottles, strip wire or gut fish. Forschner Group Inc., the U.S. distributor of the multiblade, red knives with silver crosses, has branched out into the sunglass and watch business with its new subsidiary, Swiss Army Brands Ltd. Slug BC-Swiss Army Brands. By Kim S. Martin. Moved Wednesday on FFF-level news wires for Monday, Oct. 22. With LaserPhoto HF1 of Oct. 16.
DOC.BYLINE: TOO MANY HANG-UPS: Argentina's Antiquated Phone System Getting Revamped
DOC.TEXT: BUENOS AIRES, Argentina - When it rains in parts of Argentina, thousands of telephone lines often go dead because the antiquated system doesn't have waterproof cables. When phones aren't working, it could take weeks - even months - before service is restored. ``It's incomprehensible,'' says an executive with Philadelphia-based Bell Atlantic Corp., which spent months studying the system before recently pulling out of a privatization plan. Slug BC-Argentina-Phones. By Ed McCullough. Moved Wednesday on FFF-level news wires for Monday, Oct. 22.
DOC.BYLINE: A LODE OF WORRY: Ohio Fears New Technologies Won't Save Coal Industry
DOC.TEXT: SALEM CENTER, Ohio - Five years after Ohio voters passed a $100 million bond issue to seek out new ways to clean the state's high-sulfur coal, most of the money has been spent - and miners still fear that their jobs are in jeopardy. Scientists and engineers have several promising ideas, but they may not be embraced quickly enough to save the Ohio coal industry. PM-Coal's Fate. By Rich Harris. Moved Wednesday on FFF-level news wires for for Monday PMs, Oct. 22. Also moved on general news wires.
